headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that duri
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.  
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined as the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measures discuss the reconciliation of the difference between each non-GAAP financial measures and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com, by selecting the press release regarding the company's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp, I ask those who are participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your question to 2 per person. Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Mark.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I think you will all be fairly pleased with our abbreviated format for today's call, which follows our extremely fulsome investor presentation last month. I think that December's presentation was, by far, the
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I think you will all be fairly pleased with our abbreviated format for today's call, which follows our extremely fulsome investor presentation last month. I think that December's presentation was, by far, the strongest, most comprehensive one yet. And I think that, that was affirmed by the extremely positive feedback we got from shareholders and analysts since that day and as reflected in substantially in the stock price since that time as well. So we are still very much on track with a lot of the -- those objectives we put out there about 6 or 7 weeks ago. I think the market is forming up in a way, which will still enable us to be right on track with our fairly aggressive goals that we set for ourselves, and so I'll just take this opportunity now to highlight a few items occurring since that time before opening it up for Q&A. 
Last night, and pretty notably, we achieved a significant milestone in the One Vanderbilt entire process. After lengthy negotiations in numerous with Manhattanville President and her staff, the President has recommended approval of the project, inclusive of certain improvements we agreed to make. There continues to be strong community support from groups like the coalition for better Grand Central and straphangers campaign, both of which greatly helped us achieve this important milestone, along with many other groups for which we are thankful for the support. 
At the Investor conference in December, Rob Shefer explained in some detail that the ULURP process contains 4 key steps, the first being community board followed by the Manhattan President recommendation yesterday, then onto City Planning Commission and finally, City Council. Next week, we'll be presenting the project to the City Planning Commission, the third stop, at a hearing where we hope to receive significant support from all of the key stakeholders, unions, coalitions and civic groups. The Bureau President's approval gives us great momentum as we enter into the final stages of this process, and we remain confident that we will achieve our goal with special permit for One Vanderbilt this coming May, which is consistent with the timeline we set out for everybody in December. 
So turning now towards leasing. We obviously went through a fairly exhaustive amount of information on the portfolio in the market in December and that supported, I think, our contention that rents will be taking a fairly sizable step forward this year and into next year over the next 12 to 18 months. And I will say right now the market environment is such that it's forming up in a way that either leading or exceeding our expectations. Just since December 8, we signed about 230,000 square feet of leases and 18 different transactions back in the Manhattan portfolio. And as you saw for the quarter, fourth quarter, we were up about 13% or slightly more than that, mark-to-market and nearly 15% mark-to-market for the entire year 2014. So I would say that, that still the primary engine on the operating side, the core earnings side, of what we're looking to. And as I go through the pipeline with Steve Durels, we see that we've got, on top of that, another million one in the pipeline as we sit here today, that's as of the 28th, which is about 70-some-odd thousand feet out for signature, 0.5 million square feet of leasing in negotiation and then another 0.5 square feet that are pipeline deals in term sheet negotiations. So again, anytime that pipeline is -- exceeds or approaches a million square feet, I would call that fairly robust or the kinds of targets we had for the year, which Mehta from, if memory serves me right, about 1.8 million square feet for the year, and that's something that I think we still feel very good about given the demand that we see out there and the winnowing supply as the absorption of this market continues to accelerate.
We had a pleasant surprise at the end of the year, which I don't think has been fully -- had not been really communicated in a formal way to the market it as it relates to the suburban leasing activity. Since December 8, the investor meeting, there was 185,000 square feet of leasing. Since then, 122,000 square feet of that represent new leases, total of 19 transactions. And true to form, the suburban group signed 8 of those deals on December 31, right into New Year's eve. 8 different transactions, 60,000 feet, which will encompass in 85,000 feet, which made for quite a exclamation point on the end of the year for an improving suburban market outlook as we see it. And I think you saw some of the metrics relating to mark-to-market and occupancy also trended up in the fourth quarter, so that was good news. 
I think the leasing is also punctuated by 2 of the recent announcement this morning. The Swarovski deal at 10 East 53rd I think is an affirmation of the excellent job, the construction and design team, the leasing team, have done in repositioning and in redeveloping that asset in a way to capture these type of high-quality tenants. is our first new office tenant lease post-redevelopment, and that's on top of the equinox deal we announced previously for major fitness center in that building. So we still are very, very bullish on the prospects with 10 East 53rd this year. And on top of that, you heard -- many of you heard talked about significant mark-to-market in the retail portfolio back in December, and I think one great example of how we now monetize just a small piece. But a significant piece of that mark-to-market was with their announced diesel deal at 625 Madison with many more deals in the pipeline to come from the retail leasing side. So that was very strong. 
In the debt and preferred equity front, our balances remained roughly the same through year-end. I think that people saw a slight dip in the average yield reported on fourth quarter activity, that 8.3%. It's actually fairly consistent with our guidance of around 8.5%, and it's still leaves a portfolio that's averaging 10.5% on 1.4 billion. So I wouldn't get too overly focused on the quarterly ups and downs. We've had some quarters that exceeded 10%. This quarter was 8.3%. I would look to the average on the 1.4 billion at 10.5%. I think that's the best depiction of the earnings power that portfolio for the 2015. And by way of example, just already into this year, we've originated about $111 million of new debt and preferred equity investments, which have a yield of just slightly under 10% in the high 9. So again, that pipeline is still, we think, extremely strong. We have fairly lofty origination goals of adding an incremental $250 million to our net balances by the end of 2015, and that's an increment. That's on top of whatever the expected payoffs and redemptions are this year. So that could approximate activity, certainly in excess of $600 million of gross originations. And looking at a pipeline in front of you now, which is about a dozen deals or so, that would make a significant dent in the total and it's only January. So I think that's reflective of a market that's got a very high amount of transaction activity. And as a result of that transaction activity, it drives financing opportunities in that preferred equity investments for people like us. 
Lastly, Andrew Mathias talked about unlocking opportunity in the liability side of the balance sheet and talked about all the opportunities we saw to take higher rate debt either unsecured certain assets or terming out using lower, more efficient and 2 performs secured corporate bond financing available in today's market. And I think one example of where we've now monetized or illuminated that since the investor meeting is on 3 Columbus where we've signed a commitment with lender for $350 million financing at an interest rate of about 3.6%, which is locked to 10 years, which is a very -- we think a very good piece of financing in terms of both the repatriation of our substantial equity investment for that deal for a long-term lock in that are very advantageous level. And there's more of that to come if you remember when you extrapolate that through the whole portfolio. We showed you the kind of interest savings number that could be achieved on a full mark-to-market at today's rates. And today's rates are lower than what we projected back in December 8 due to the recent rise in treasury prices. So all in all, I think good news to report. It was a very good quarter. And as important, the prospects for 2015 look to be very much in line with how we hope to execute. 
And with that, I will turn it over for questions-and-answers.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just starting out for Steve Durels or anyone in general. At the Investor Day, you commented you see a premium in 2015 for big blocks of space. Can you give your latest thoughts on what's happening on the big block market today in terms of the leas
componenttext: I guess just starting out for Steve Durels or anyone in general. At the Investor Day, you commented you see a premium in 2015 for big blocks of space. Can you give your latest thoughts on what's happening on the big block market today in terms of the lease demand pipeline? And then also your thoughts on competitive big blocks that will be in the market this year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a great step, which I think staff, which I think support which is the fact that the number of scarcity of big block availabilities in Midtown. There's only 5 spaces available in Midtown that are 250,000 square feet or greater compared to 10 uni
componenttext: Sure. It's a great step, which I think staff, which I think support which is the fact that the number of scarcity of big block availabilities in Midtown. There's only 5 spaces available in Midtown that are 250,000 square feet or greater compared to 10 units from a year ago. So from a supply side, certainly it's driving up fast. The number of the large leases that were assigned last year to give you the trend line, was dramatically larger. There were 58 leases signed last year for 100,000 square feet or more compared to 43 leases from the prior year. But more telling was the fact that there were 33 the relocations rather than just renewal deals compared to only 17 large leases the prior year, and those large block deals were 7.5 million square feet compared to 3.4 million square feet. So clearly from the demand side and also by the lack of supply makes us very bullish as to why there's going to be a premium on the big blocks.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly on the suburban market, can you just talk more about who is signing leases out there? And what kind of assets they're looking for? Are they rail? Are they transit served or not? Just a little more color on why there was a pickup in
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly on the suburban market, can you just talk more about who is signing leases out there? And what kind of assets they're looking for? Are they rail? Are they transit served or not? Just a little more color on why there was a pickup in the fourth quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Isaac. You're clearly seeing more activity in the transit-oriented buildings in white plains in Stanford. And in terms of tenant type, it's across-the-board. You got legal, financial services, Tech, health care. We signed probably 3 or 4 lea
componenttext: Sure, this is Isaac. You're clearly seeing more activity in the transit-oriented buildings in white plains in Stanford. And in terms of tenant type, it's across-the-board. You got legal, financial services, Tech, health care. We signed probably 3 or 4 leases north of 50,000 square feet, so there are also larger tenants coming back into the market as well, and that's driving both occupancy and mark-to-market, both of which have been really, really positive. So for example, we signed up a legal aid to close to 30,000 square-feet, coming in lock, which is a law firm for 55,000 feet, Sony for 53,000 feet. So it's a cross -- it's really across-the-board, and this is the first time in the last 2 to 3 years that we've seen positive direction from different tenants types. Not just have health care, not just education, so it's across the entire.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And are these tenants coming out of the city or their local tenant expanding?
componenttext: And are these tenants coming out of the city or their local tenant expanding?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The vast, vast majority are local tenants. They're moving, they're expanding and the positive thing here is we're actually seeing them getting bigger. So was it 20,000 square foot tenant moving from building X to one of ours. They're now thinking 22,000,
componenttext: The vast, vast majority are local tenants. They're moving, they're expanding and the positive thing here is we're actually seeing them getting bigger. So was it 20,000 square foot tenant moving from building X to one of ours. They're now thinking 22,000, 23,000, so that's really, really positive sign.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a note on our portfolio performance versus the market, our performance is towards 84%, which is better than the market. We are -- I think the group -- the rising group in White Plains and Sanford are doing an excellent job of outperforming the mar
componenttext: Just as a note on our portfolio performance versus the market, our performance is towards 84%, which is better than the market. We are -- I think the group -- the rising group in White Plains and Sanford are doing an excellent job of outperforming the market, so I think what Isaac is telling you is the types of tenants we're attracting, and we are winning, and we're doing it on an economic terms that are accretive, which I think is not necessarily -- it was sort of the market as a whole, but improving as rapidly as our portfolio is going.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We saw some market reports that you guys might have made some leasing progress at 280 Park Avenue. Can you talk a little bit about where that project stands currently?
componenttext: We saw some market reports that you guys might have made some leasing progress at 280 Park Avenue. Can you talk a little bit about where that project stands currently?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we sit right now, the one reason that we didn't include the press release covering large deal that we signed in early January with fiduciary trust for 126,000 square feet was generally reported in the local papers. So that was a deal we've been w
componenttext: Sure. As we sit right now, the one reason that we didn't include the press release covering large deal that we signed in early January with fiduciary trust for 126,000 square feet was generally reported in the local papers. So that was a deal we've been working on for quite awhile. It was for 3.5 base force of the building at rents that were well within our underwrite numbers. Leases with 302,000 square feet of remaining office space left in the building, which is about 24% of the office space. We have leases out on another 110,000 square feet of that availability, and then we have another close to 80,000 square feet of term sheets that were very hopeful we'll get converted into leases within the next couple of weeks. So basically completed, I'd say, 95% of the capital program. And as soon as we unveil the lobby, and if you've been through the building, you've seen the second half of the lobby that recently opened -- they really opened up the floodgates as far as tenant demand. And we were very optimistic and bullish on the project early last year. Now it's sort of the high 5 because everybody's coming through sort of 1 right after the other. And we're going -- and we closed everything that we're working at when we're down to only one base square left in the building. And beyond that, a smattering of partial spaces up in the tower. So we'll be -- we should have the building stabilized this year without too much fear. And rents are on the rise. And as we saw all last year, it's all financial services. Nothing but financial services.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. Second question from either Andrew or Mark. General Grant did announce the crown building deal on 1557, so I guess that's a 2-part question. One is are you guys looking at having opportunity of putting some mess on that deal? And then n
componenttext: I appreciate that. Second question from either Andrew or Mark. General Grant did announce the crown building deal on 1557, so I guess that's a 2-part question. One is are you guys looking at having opportunity of putting some mess on that deal? And then number 2, I'm guessing you took a hard look at it in general growth can hit their 6% stabilized yield target in 3 years. I'm curious. It doesn't seem like an unreasonable number relative to our cap rates are in Manhattan. What was it about that deal that you guys didn't see?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Andrew take that one.
componenttext: I'll let Andrew take that one.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are -- I'm not going to not comment on the acquisition. I'll just say we obviously underwrote the deal carefully. We knew the sellers and we didn't see that type of earning potential on our plan for the assets. And the mezzanine where -- I honestly don
componenttext: We are -- I'm not going to not comment on the acquisition. I'll just say we obviously underwrote the deal carefully. We knew the sellers and we didn't see that type of earning potential on our plan for the assets. And the mezzanine where -- I honestly don't know what GGP is doing in terms of debt capital stock there, so it's not an opportunity that's crossed our desk. We will certainly look at it if it did, but he has generally -- the deals he's bought thus, far in Manhattan is generally used lower leverage and used some master leases and other structures to get his debt cost very low. So I don't know if I'll do the same on Crown or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Guinee of the field.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Guinee of the field.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: John Guinee. I'm just curious because you never brought this up before. One Vanderbilt, I guess, you got about 700,000 or 800,000 square feet in place, up zone to about 1.6 million square feet. Can you provide, I guess just on a square foot basis, what yo
componenttext: John Guinee. I'm just curious because you never brought this up before. One Vanderbilt, I guess, you got about 700,000 or 800,000 square feet in place, up zone to about 1.6 million square feet. Can you provide, I guess just on a square foot basis, what you think your land base is going to be, including your building cost, all your fees, infrastructure cost, demo cost. And so people can get a sense for whether your land base is $200 a foot or $2,000 of biddable foot. And then what you think your developmental cost is going to be on one...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe, I think what we said in December -- we went through the building program fairly extensively in the design and the entitlement process. We're completely focused on those elements right now and getting through what's -- it's been a long road of assembl
componenttext: Joe, I think what we said in December -- we went through the building program fairly extensively in the design and the entitlement process. We're completely focused on those elements right now and getting through what's -- it's been a long road of assemblage, acquisition, possession and now entitlements over time. And at the conclusion of that effort when it's done and we know what we have and we know the total cost in and what we're -- total envelope of the building and the exact program, I think we'll go into that in much greater detail, but that's kind of a -- that's a later in the year kind of event for us. I know we've been saying that for some time now, but it still is the case because there's a lot of different moving pieces. You saw even yesterday, we had to make some modifications to the property that we think we're good. Improvements and certainly good for public benefit and public realm improvements. But until everything is sort of -- until we have everything isolated and identified, the premature is going to the numbers. But you can certainly look back and see what our acquisition cost are for the assemblage, and that's the bulk of the cost. But then, obviously, there's all the public realm improvements we've been pretty specific about $210 million of costs associated with public realm improvements. And then obviously, a lot of predevelopment possession cost on top of that, which is, like I said, when it's all settled, we'll be able to get a better picture of.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just intellectual curiosity, when you're taking down 800,000 square feet brick by brick, you have any preliminary demo cost on that yet?
componenttext: Just intellectual curiosity, when you're taking down 800,000 square feet brick by brick, you have any preliminary demo cost on that yet?

componenttextpreview: Yes. In line -- we do a lot of demolition in this business since the first. I would say certainly not the most material of items on the budget, and consistent with the kind of demolition cost we experienced in the city as we do annually, enormous volumes
componenttext: Yes. In line -- we do a lot of demolition in this business since the first. I would say certainly not the most material of items on the budget, and consistent with the kind of demolition cost we experienced in the city as we do annually, enormous volumes of demolition of space and occasionally, efficiently, structures.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael Kors with Michael. Just wondering if you can comment on any changes you're seeing to the investment landscape in Manhattan? And maybe if you could focus on any training trends you're seeing from foreign buyers.
componenttext: Michael Kors with Michael. Just wondering if you can comment on any changes you're seeing to the investment landscape in Manhattan? And maybe if you could focus on any training trends you're seeing from foreign buyers.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think we went through, specifically at the Investor Day, that the trends emerging in terms of a lot of Chinese capital coming into the market, Canadian capital continuing to play a dominant role. Since Investor Day, we've seen Japanese capital with
componenttext: Well I think we went through, specifically at the Investor Day, that the trends emerging in terms of a lot of Chinese capital coming into the market, Canadian capital continuing to play a dominant role. Since Investor Day, we've seen Japanese capital with, making a large investment into Hudson Yards were related. So there's a lot of Japanese capital circulating around a best there's just continued demand from all different points on the globe and in all different property types that are driving the market. I think you're seeing that at the trophy level, and you're also seeing it a very deep level of demand for properties like 315 Park Avenue South, which traded within the last quarter. And other sort of side street and less high-profile glass and steel buildings, which are trading at record levels throughout the city.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any impacts from just the drop include prices more recently? Or has that really not trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet. I read about it as having more direct impact on condo buyers, individuals, but not on a commercial land at all.
componenttext:
Have you seen any impacts from just the drop include prices more recently? Or has that really not trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet. 
I read about it as having more direct impact on condo buyers, individuals, but not on a commercial land at all.

componenttextpreview: Yes, think it's similar. I think stabilized retail is getting slightly more aggressive than stabilized office. Stabilized office is sort of 4 caps, Stabilized retail will be 3.5, 3.75 tap in prime areas. But it's hard to generalize of the property has its
componenttext: Yes, think it's similar. I think stabilized retail is getting slightly more aggressive than stabilized office. Stabilized office is sort of 4 caps, Stabilized retail will be 3.5, 3.75 tap in prime areas. But it's hard to generalize of the property has its own below-market issue or opportunities that play a role in cap rates.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood, that's helpful. And then just maybe second one for Steve Durels. You gave very helpful color on 280 Park. You did -- deal at 10 East 53rd, and I think you're targeting stabilization or leasing about asset more than '16 and ' '15, but can you g
componenttext: Understood, that's helpful. And then just maybe second one for Steve Durels. You gave very helpful color on 280 Park. You did -- deal at 10 East 53rd, and I think you're targeting stabilization or leasing about asset more than '16 and ' '15, but can you give us a sense of how the pipeline shapes up in 10 East 53rd?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Remember, we signed the deal for 2 floors. That was right on the tail of signing the 2 for lease with the Equinox. We have another leased out right now that we just went to documents with yesterday. The capital program is pretty well advanced. If you
componenttext: Yes. Remember, we signed the deal for 2 floors. That was right on the tail of signing the 2 for lease with the Equinox. We have another leased out right now that we just went to documents with yesterday. The capital program is pretty well advanced. If you went over there today, you'd see probably 80% of our lobby work is complete. Still at constructions zone, but when you walk in there, you clearly get a sense of the scale of what's happening at the ground floor and how impactful that's going to be just to reposition this building. But when those wall had been replaced, the precise been recovered a lot of the infrastructure works that's been done and we've got a lot of strong tour activity. From the mix of type of tenants, I'd say 4, 2/3 of the space on the floor is that of the 9,000 footers. It's primarily financial services and international companies. And then downstairs on the few floors that are a little bit larger, 16,000 per floors. Those are more general service businesses. And we've got 4 or 5 proposals out there we're trading with tenants, most of them from the top third of the building. And and that part of the building are anywhere from 95 to 115 a foot, as far as the term sheet numbers that were going back and forth with downtime. So we're feeling that we're right on plan for that.

componenttextpreview: It's a tale of 2 cities in that building. The bottom 9 floors, 2 of which were already been leased now, so there's only some floors left of space to worry about. Our 16,000 feet there, they don't have the big open view of Central Park the way we have upst
componenttext: It's a tale of 2 cities in that building. The bottom 9 floors, 2 of which were already been leased now, so there's only some floors left of space to worry about. Our 16,000 feet there, they don't have the big open view of Central Park the way we have upstairs. But if that's still sort of low 70s rents, which are right in line with underwriting and put it in a very good place as far as being competitive in the market.

componenttext: Yes, the project comes before the city Council as I guess what we would call the last opt or the fourth prong as what I described earlier. So Dan is the local councilman who has been sort of -- were intimately involved knowledgeable with project. I mean, the entire city Council will act on this. headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The numbers in any one quarter so widely driven by whether or not we're doing large deals or small deals and how many deals we're doing. Our renewals as opposed to new transactions on space that's completely wrong, and this is a full confession packet. So
componenttext: The numbers in any one quarter so widely driven by whether or not we're doing large deals or small deals and how many deals we're doing. Our renewals as opposed to new transactions on space that's completely wrong, and this is a full confession packet. So I don't know that you can gleam a lot from the number from one quarter to the next. I'll tell you that wildly speaking, there seems to be greater willingness on tenants to absorb rent increases as opposed to a reduction of concessions. Concessions are slowly coming down a little bit. Certainly by comparisons 2 years ago they're down materially, but I think construction cost for tenants are building up, not only because commodity prices are up and labors up, but also because how much tenants have to spend as they intensify their offices. Their buildout, their needs are greater. More infrastructure, more furniture, more telecom. Everything just goes into putting a lot of people in the same piece of space. And therefore, that explains why the tenants are willing to pay more rent, but resistant to really knocking down the concession. So I think it's going to be a slower reduction in concessions over the year where we'll see alternatively a bigger pop in rents as the year goes forward.

componenttext: I don't know if we have that data. That's hard to tell. With the relative allocation is, I would say that any one who's investing domestically and -- in the commercial sector is, you hear one. I mean, Manhattan is generally the top of the list in terms of desire to allocate. It's hard to say what percentage either of the whole portfolio or vis-à-vis other markets, but I think the -- I can't say the desires increase. I think it's always there as their primary goal. We get calls daily. And I'm not -- that's not an exaggeration or embellishment. So it's hard to put that into a percentage allocation. It's just a it's a very, very deep demand. I think for every asset we have, it's really a matter of price. I mean, the demand is almost always there to question of terms and price, which is I think you see what's driving this market and driving these values to, in many cases, new peak levels over the prior peak in 2006, in '07. But I think I don't now if you have any sense specifically on club percentage [indiscernible] .

componenttextpreview: Right. There still haven't been enough trades to see exactly where cap rates are actually going. And every building, they're so unique in terms of triple net leases. Other buildings are 50% leased. But we have seen some transactions in Connecticut and in
componenttext: Right. There still haven't been enough trades to see exactly where cap rates are actually going. And every building, they're so unique in terms of triple net leases. Other buildings are 50% leased. But we have seen some transactions in Connecticut and in Northern New Jersey that have basically been people who've owned lands or building some Brooklyn Queens, the city, and they're 1031ng out of those assets into deals in Connecticut and Westchester. So we are seeing that as a little bit of a trend.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the sequence is generally the market first, and I think we're seeing market improvement. Then the financing, the financeability of these assets. And we're seeing decent bids out there from lenders and securitized and non-securitized l
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the sequence is generally the market first, and I think we're seeing market improvement. Then the financing, the financeability of these assets. And we're seeing decent bids out there from lenders and securitized and non-securitized lenders willing to lend at attractive rates in some of these mature markets outside of New York city proper. And I think the last piece of that is then the investor demand driving cap rates to compressed, which I would think that's probably will be happening this year just based on the first 2 problems maintenance. Ian say that we can give you evidence or specifics to that effect, but you don't always want to be looking at the rearview mirror. So if you want to go out on the skis a little bit, make a bit of forecast, I would say you will start to see those cap rates compress this year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jordan Sadler from KeyBanc Capital.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up a little bit. I think asked question, and I appreciate the update since the Investor Day in early December, I -- we can't help, but notice that interest rates are down. Full 50 basis points, as you pointed out. And so increases the o
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up a little bit. I think asked question, and I appreciate the update since the Investor Day in early December, I -- we can't help, but notice that interest rates are down. Full 50 basis points, as you pointed out. And so increases the opportunity and the liability side of the balance sheet as you talked about, but what are you guys thinking on the asset side of the balance sheet given this pre-material shift?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that on the asset side, there's really two things. It enhances our strategy of selectively disposing of assets. We did a substantial amount of dispositions in 2014 that was kind of punctuated by the almost $0.5 billion sales 180 Maiden Lane,
componenttext:
Well, I think that on the asset side, there's really two things. It enhances our strategy of selectively disposing of assets. We did a substantial amount of dispositions in 2014 that was kind of punctuated by the almost $0.5 billion sales 180 Maiden Lane, which just closed, I think, this month. So that's a fairly significant deal right on the heels of 2 Herald, which I think also closed in the fourth quarter, December.  So we will continue to sell into that market. I don't think the 50 basis points means we'll sell more for less. I mean, we had a plan we're on plan. Maybe it means some of the margins were going to get some higher pricing. I don't think the 50 basis points of treasury is necessarily basis point for basis point equal to reduction in financing rates because when you get the low 3.5% for 10-year money, I think it starts to get a bit sticky in terms of what the absolute rate will be for tenure I/O money. But clearly, the financing rates have come in, and we'll take advantage of that on the liability side as Andrew talked about. It should add incrementally to the sales. And obviously, on our acquisitions, we're underwriting lower rates right now, so either higher leverage returns or it could drive pricing a bit further. But we tend to model on our underwriting. Everything is towards stabilized market. So we're never just taking the spot market cap rate and the spot market financing rate on acquisitions.
We're always modeling the curve. We often, on live, where we model the curve plus the 50 basis point cushion, which I think many of you know, some of you may not. We hold our exit cap rates pretty stable at levels far in excess of where the spot market to cap rates are today. And I think that hurts as a bit on cap rate, but it certainly protects us in the future against any kind of cap rate increase. And we keep our absolute level of returns pretty consistent looking to stabilize at 6% or more current cash returns and 8% to 10% on leverage returns. And that probably translates into 6.5% to 8% on levered returns. So that, I think, is not varying greatly because of the interest rates decline, but on the margins, it certainly so.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: I would say it's the largest user group in our portfolio as far as prospects right now. If you -- total number of transactions in the pipeline, total square footage. Part of that is reflective of the inventory that we currently have available, so I don't know that, that's -- using that overall market color were based upon the kinds of buildings, the kind the floors, the price points that we current -- where we currently have availability [indiscernible] 53rd Street, Tower 46, 280 Avenue being best examples. 600 likes are all geared towards financial service industry tenants. Behind that, we've got some pretty good pipeline with industry, information services, in particular, where we've got high hopes that we're going to convert some of that over to some significant transactions.

componenttext: I'll just start with another suburban question. Would you describe your sentiments around the suburbs as flexible at all? Not just on cap rates, and financing rates, but given all the leasing sign at the end of December and that you're winning in the market with these assets?  What's your appetite for curtailing this positions? Or is it less a cyclical position and more a secular feel for where you want to focus, long term?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our suburban portfolio has, I think, serves important function in terms of its fairly consistent cash flow. I mean, it's fairly low. It's a low consumer on the capital end of them as compared to the Manhattan portfolio, so that's certainly a great a
componenttext: Well, our suburban portfolio has, I think, serves important function in terms of its fairly consistent cash flow. I mean, it's fairly low. It's a low consumer on the capital end of them as compared to the Manhattan portfolio, so that's certainly a great attraction to the portfolio and why I think it's always played a key role for us is that it's a relatively unencumbered portfolio. It's maintained occupancy in the low '80s I think since we acquired it sort of at a very tough period of time in 2007, in 2008. The capital budget for that portfolio is very manageable, and the market is picking up so it's a contributor to the bottom line. So we like that portfolio. It was proven down from a much larger portfolio at the time we originally closed on the western transaction, and we kept what we felt were the best properties in the best markets, and I think that proved to be true during the downturn. And we have a team of about 30 people up here that run this portfolio in White planes in Stanford that are I think best-in-class. So everything we do, there's no wholesale position to hold. There's no wholesale decision to sell. I think everything is -- we look at is fairly opportunistic. And if we can bring properties to stabilizations and a very strong big comes back in the markets and we have redeployment opportunities, then you'll see us execute on that program as we have in the past. But I don't see current conditions driving that significantly in one direction or the other. I think we're just going to continue with that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Then back on the tenant strength By Verticals. So it's pretty widespread in the suburbs and you also mentioned 280 Park being of financial service, so to speak, and financial services representing the biggest user group now. If you h
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Then back on the tenant strength By Verticals. So it's pretty widespread in the suburbs and you also mentioned 280 Park being of financial service, so to speak, and financial services representing the biggest user group now. If you had to compare the traditional verticals to TAMI though, can you just give us a feel? Did the traditional still panel in comparison to tack? And so fourth, when it comes to growth and your feel for future growth? Or is it really becoming a more balanced market?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think we've been saying for the past couple of years, quite frankly, that the good news is that Manhattan is not as dependent upon financial services as what everybody felt years ago because of one, the emergence of TAMI as being a big driver in th
componenttext: Well I think we've been saying for the past couple of years, quite frankly, that the good news is that Manhattan is not as dependent upon financial services as what everybody felt years ago because of one, the emergence of TAMI as being a big driver in the marketplace. So now, it's TAMI, legal and financial services and then followed by general business services. So you've got really 4 big groups providing diversification as far as tenant demand goes. On the financial service side, I think it's mostly the same as what we've seen for the past year, 1.5 years, which the profile of that group has been asset management, hedge funds, private equity, commercial banking. You haven't yet seen the really big banks and the investment banks active in the market. Although I think there's a couple of requirements kicking around today that weren't there a year, 1.5 years ago. Part of that is driven on the big investment banking requirements either by consolidations or lease expirations that are coming up. And a lot of brokers that I speak to are now, I think, generally have a shared view, which is that the banks are hopefully past understanding the regulation. Their New World environment, their short on space and nobody sitting on a lot of excess inventory. And they're sort of primed to start to come back and in the market as they figure out how they're going to grow their businesses. So think it's going to be a big contributor in the period to come.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that duri
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.  
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined as the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed in the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure, and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com, by selecting the press release regarding the company's fourth quarter and full year 2014 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp, I ask those who are participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your question to 2 per person.
I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I think you will all be fairly pleased with our abbreviated format for today's call, which follows our extremely fulsome investor presentation last month. I think that December's presentation was, by far, the
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. I think you will all be fairly pleased with our abbreviated format for today's call, which follows our extremely fulsome investor presentation last month. I think that December's presentation was, by far, the strongest, most comprehensive one yet. And I think that, that was affirmed by the extremely positive feedback we got from shareholders and analysts since that day and as reflected not in substantially in the stock price since that time as well. So we are still very much on track with a lot of the -- those objectives we put out there about 6 or 7 weeks ago. I think the market is forming up in a way, which will still enable us to be right on track with our fairly aggressive goals that we set for ourselves, and so I'll just take this opportunity now to highlight a few items occurring since that time before opening it up for Q&A. 
Last night, and pretty notably, we achieved a significant milestone in the One Vanderbilt entitlement process. After lengthy negotiations and numerous meetings with Manhattan Borough President, Gale Brewer and her staff, the Borough President has recommended approval of the project, inclusive of certain improvements we have agreed to make. There continues to be strong community support from groups like the coalition for a better Grand Central, and the straphangers campaign, both of which greatly helped us achieve this important milestone, along with many other groups for which we are thankful for their support. 
At the Investor Conference in December, Rob Schiffer explained in some detail that the ULURP process contains 4 key steps: the first being the community board; followed by the Manhattan Borough President recommendation yesterday; then on to City Planning Commission; and finally, City Council. Next week, we'll be presenting the project to the City Planning Commission, the third stop, at a hearing where we hope to receive significant support from all of the key stakeholders, unions, coalitions and civic groups. The Borough President's approval gives us great momentum as we enter into the final stages of this process, and we remain confident that we'll achieve our goal with a special permit for One Vanderbilt this coming May, which is consistent with the timeline we set out for everybody in December. 
So turning now towards leasing. We obviously went through a fairly exhaustive amount of information on the portfolio in the market in December and that supported, I think, our contention that rents would be taking a fairly sizable step forward this year and into next year over the next 12 to 18 months. And I would say right now, the market environment is such that it's forming up in a way that's either needing or exceeding our expectations. Just since December 8, we've signed about 230,000 square feet of leases and 18 different transactions, that's in the Manhattan portfolio. And as you saw for the quarter, fourth quarter, we were up about 13% or slightly more than that, mark-to-market and nearly 15% mark-to-market for the entire year 2014. So I would say that, that's still the primary engine on the operating side, the core earnings side of what we're looking to. And as I go through the pipeline with Steve Durels, I see that we've got, on top of that, another million one in the pipeline as we sit here today, that's as of the 28th, which is about 70-some-odd thousand square feet out for signature, 0.5 million square feet of leasing in negotiation and then another 0.5 million square feet that are pipeline deals in term sheet negotiations. So again, anytime that pipeline is -- exceeds or approaches a million square feet, I would call that fairly robust or the kinds of targets we had for the year, which we added from, if memory serves me right, we're about at 1.8 million square feet for the year, and that's something that I think we still feel very good about given the demand that we see out there and the winnowing supply as the absorption in this market continues to accelerate.
We had a pleasant surprise at the end of the year, which I don't think has been fully -- had not been really communicated in a formal way to the market yet as it relates to the suburban leasing activity. Since December 8, the investor meeting, there was 185,000 square feet of leasing. Since then, 122,000 square feet of that representing new leases, total of 19 transactions. And true to form, the suburban group signed 8 of those deals on December 31, right into New Year's eve. 8 different transactions, 60,000 feet, which will encompass in that 185,000 feet, which made for quite a -- put quite an exclamation point on the end of the year for an improving suburban market outlook as we see it. And I think you saw some of the metrics relating to mark-to-market and occupancy also trended up in the fourth quarter, so that was good news. 
I think the leasing is also punctuated by 2 of the recent announcement this morning. The Swarovski deal at 10 East 53rd, I think is an affirmation of the excellent job, the construction and design team and leasing team have done in repositioning and in redeveloping that asset in a way to capture these type of high-quality profile tenants. Swarovski is our first new office tenant lease post-redevelopment, and that's on top of the Equinox deal we announced previously for major fitness center in that building. So we still are very, very bullish on the prospects with 10 East 53rd this year. And on top of that, you heard -- many of you heard Brett Herschenfeld talked about significant mark-to-market in the retail portfolio back in December, and I think one great example of how we've now monetize just a small piece. But a significant piece of that mark-to-market was with their announced Diesel deal at 625 Madison with many more deals in the pipeline to come from the retail leasing side. So that was very strong. 
In the debt and preferred equity front, our balances remained roughly the same through year-end. I think that people saw a slight dip in the average yield reported on fourth quarter activity, that 8.3%. It's actually fairly consistent with our guidance of around 8.5%, and it still leaves a portfolio that's averaging 10.5% on $1.4 billion. So I wouldn't get too overly focused on the quarterly ups and downs. We've had some quarters that exceeded 10%. This quarter was 8.3%. I would look to the average on the $1.4 billion at 10.5%. I think that's the best depiction of the earnings power that portfolio for 2015. And by way of example, just already into this year, we've originated about $111 million of new debt and preferred equity investments, which have a yield of just slightly under 10%, in the high-9%. So again, that pipeline is still, we think, extremely strong. We have fairly loft the origination goals of adding an incremental $250 million to our net balances by the end of 2015, and that's an increment. That's on top of whatever the expected payoffs and redemptions are this year. So that could approximate activity, certainly in excess of $600 million of gross originations. And looking at a pipeline in front of me now, which is about a dozen deals or so, that would make a significant dent in that total and it's only January. So I think that's reflective of a market that's got a very high amount of transaction activity. And as a result of that transaction activity, it drives financing opportunities in debt and preferred equity investments for people like us. 
Lastly, Andrew Mathias talked about unlocking opportunity in the liability side of the balance sheet, and talked about all the opportunities we saw to take higher rate debt either unsecured certain assets or terming out using lower, more efficient and 2 performs secured and/or corporate bond financing that's available in today's market. And I think one example of where we've now monetized or illuminated that since the investor meeting is on 3 Columbus where we've signed a commitment with a lender for $350 million financing at an interest rate of about 3.6%, which is locked for 10 years, which is a very -- we think a very good piece of financing in terms of both repatriation of our substantial equity investment into that deal for a long-term lock in of rates at a very advantageous level. And there's more of that to come as you remember when you extrapolate that through the whole portfolio. We showed you the kinds of interest savings number that could be achieved on a full mark-to-market at today's rates. And today's rates are lower than what we projected back in December 8 due to the recent rise in treasury prices. So all in all, I think good news to report. It was a very good quarter. And as important, the prospects for 2015 look to be very much in line with how we hope to execute. 
And with that, I will turn it over for questions-and-answers.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, just starting out for Steve Durels or anyone in general. At the Investor Day, you had commented you'd see a premium in 2015 for big blocks of space. Can you give your latest thoughts on what's happening in the big block market today in terms of t
componenttext: I guess, just starting out for Steve Durels or anyone in general. At the Investor Day, you had commented you'd see a premium in 2015 for big blocks of space. Can you give your latest thoughts on what's happening in the big block market today in terms of the lease, the demand pipeline, and then also your thoughts on competitive big blocks that will be in the market this year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. There's a great step, which I think supports that, which is the fact that the number of scarcity of big block availabilities in Midtown. There's only 5 spaces available in Midtown that are 250,000 square feet or greater compared to 10 units from a y
componenttext: Sure. There's a great step, which I think supports that, which is the fact that the number of scarcity of big block availabilities in Midtown. There's only 5 spaces available in Midtown that are 250,000 square feet or greater compared to 10 units from a year ago. So from a supply side, certainly, it's drawing up fast. The number of the large leases that were signed last year sort of give you the trend line, it was dramatically larger. There were 58 leases signed last year for 100,000 square feet or more compared to 43 leases from the prior year. But more telling was the fact that there were 33 relocations rather than just renewal deals compared to only 17 large leases the prior year, and those large block deals were 7.5 million square feet compared to 3.4 million square feet. So clearly from the demand side and -- an offset by the lack of supply makes us very bullish as to why there's going to be a premium on the big blocks.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly on the suburban market, can you just talk more about who is signing leases out there? And what kind of assets they're looking for? Are they rail? Are they transit served or not? Just a little more color on why there was a pickup in
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly on the suburban market, can you just talk more about who is signing leases out there? And what kind of assets they're looking for? Are they rail? Are they transit served or not? Just a little more color on why there was a pickup in the fourth quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Isaac. You're clearly seeing more activity in the transit-oriented buildings in White Plains in Stanford. And in terms of tenant types, it's really across-the-board. You've got legal, financial services, Tech, health care. We signed probably
componenttext: Sure, this is Isaac. You're clearly seeing more activity in the transit-oriented buildings in White Plains in Stanford. And in terms of tenant types, it's really across-the-board. You've got legal, financial services, Tech, health care. We signed probably 3 or 4 leases north of 50,000 square feet, so there are also larger tenants coming back into the market as well, and that's driving both occupancy and mark-to-market, both of which have been really, really positive. So for example, we signed up Legal Aid for -- close to 30,000 square feet; Cummings & Lockwood, which is a law firm for 55,000 feet; Sony for 53,000 feet. So it's a cross -- it's really across-the-board, and this is the first time in the last 2 to 3 years that we've seen positive direction from different tenant types. Not just health care, not just education, so it's across the entire gan [ph].

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And are these tenants coming out of the city? Or they're local tenants that's expanding?
componenttext: And are these tenants coming out of the city? Or they're local tenants that's expanding?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The vast, vast majority are local tenants. They're either moving, they're expanding, though the positive thing here is we have seen them actually getting bigger. So it was a 20,000 square foot tenant moving from building X to one of ours. They're now thin
componenttext: The vast, vast majority are local tenants. They're either moving, they're expanding, though the positive thing here is we have seen them actually getting bigger. So it was a 20,000 square foot tenant moving from building X to one of ours. They're now thinking 22,000, 23,000, so that's actually really, really positive sign.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just as a note on our portfolio performance versus the market, our performance is trending towards around 84%, which is better than the market. We are -- I think the group -- the rising group in White Plains and Stanford are doing an excellent job of
componenttext: Yes. Just as a note on our portfolio performance versus the market, our performance is trending towards around 84%, which is better than the market. We are -- I think the group -- the rising group in White Plains and Stanford are doing an excellent job of outperforming the market, so I think what Isaac is telling you are the types of tenants we're attracting, and we're winning, and we're doing it on an economic terms that are accretive, which I think is not necessarily -- it was sort of the market as a whole, which is improving, but I don't think improving as rapidly as our portfolio is.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We saw some market reports that you guys might have made some leasing progress at 280 Park Avenue. Can you talk a little bit about where that project stands currently?
componenttext: We saw some market reports that you guys might have made some leasing progress at 280 Park Avenue. Can you talk a little bit about where that project stands currently?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we sit right now, we -- the one reason we didn't put a press release out covering is because of large deal that we signed in early January with Fiduciary Trust for 126,000 square feet was generally reported in the local papers. So that was a deal
componenttext: Sure. As we sit right now, we -- the one reason we didn't put a press release out covering is because of large deal that we signed in early January with Fiduciary Trust for 126,000 square feet was generally reported in the local papers. So that was a deal that we've been working on for quite awhile. It was for 3.5 base force of the building at rents that were well within our underwrite numbers. Leases with 302,000 square feet of remaining office space left in the building, which is about 24% of the office space. We have leases out on another 110,000 square feet of that availability, and then we have another close to 80,000 square feet of term sheets that were very hopeful we'll get converted into leases within the next couple of weeks. So we've basically completed, I'd say, 95% of the capital program. And as soon as we unveil the lobby, and if you've been through the building and seen the second half of the lobby that recently opened, they really opened up the floodgates as far as tenant demand. And where we were very optimistic and bullish on the project early last year. Now it's sort of a high 5 because everybody's coming through sort of one right after another. And we're going -- and we closed everything that we're working, and we're down to the only one base floor left in the building. And beyond that, a smattering of partial spaces up in the tower. So we'll be -- we should have the building stabilized this year without too much fear. And rents are on the rise. And as we saw all last year, it's all financial services. Nothing but financial services.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I appreciate that. Second question, either Andrew or Mark. General Growth did announce the Crown Building deal on 1557, so I guess it's a 2-part question. One is, are you guys looking at having opportunity of putting some mezz on that deal? And the
componenttext: Great. I appreciate that. Second question, either Andrew or Mark. General Growth did announce the Crown Building deal on 1557, so I guess it's a 2-part question. One is, are you guys looking at having opportunity of putting some mezz on that deal? And then number two, I'm guessing you took a hard look at it, if General Growth can hit their 6% stabilized yield target in 3 years. I'm curious, it doesn't seem like an unreasonable number relative to our cap rates are in Manhattan. What was it about that deal that you guys didn't see?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Andrew take that one.
componenttext: I'll let Andrew take that one.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are -- I'm going to not comment on the acquisition. I'll just say we obviously underwrote the deal carefully. We knew the sellers and we didn't see that type of earning potential on our plan for the asset. And the mezzanine where -- I honestly don't kn
componenttext: We are -- I'm going to not comment on the acquisition. I'll just say we obviously underwrote the deal carefully. We knew the sellers and we didn't see that type of earning potential on our plan for the asset. And the mezzanine where -- I honestly don't know what GGP is doing in terms of debt capital stock there, so it's not an opportunity that's crossed our desk. We would certainly look at it if it did, but he has generally -- the deals he's bought thus far in Manhattan has generally used lower leverage and used some master leases and other structures to get his debt cost very low. So I don't know if we'll do the same on Crown or not.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Guinee of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Guinee of Stifel.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: John Guinee. I'm just curious because you've never brought this up before, but One Vanderbilt, I guess, you got about 700,000 or 800,000 square feet in place up zone to about 1.6 million square feet. Can you provide, I guess just on a square foot basis, w
componenttext: John Guinee. I'm just curious because you've never brought this up before, but One Vanderbilt, I guess, you got about 700,000 or 800,000 square feet in place up zone to about 1.6 million square feet. Can you provide, I guess just on a square foot basis, what you think your land bases is going to be, including your building cost, all your fees, infrastructure cost, demo cost? And so people can get a sense for whether your land bases is $200 a foot or $2,000 of buildable foot. And then what you think your total developmental cost is going to be on one...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think what we said in December -- we went through the building program fairly extensively in the design and the entitlement process. We're completely focused on those elements right now and getting through what's -- it's been a long road of assemb
componenttext: John, I think what we said in December -- we went through the building program fairly extensively in the design and the entitlement process. We're completely focused on those elements right now and getting through what's -- it's been a long road of assemblage, acquisition, possession and now entitlements over time. And at the conclusion of that effort when it's done and we know what we have and we know the total cost in and what we're -- total envelope of the building and the exact program, I think we'll go into that in much greater detail, but that's kind of a -- that's a later in the year kind of event for us. I know we've been saying that for some time now, but it's still is the case because there's a lot of different moving pieces. You saw even yesterday, we had to make some modifications to the property that we think we're good improvements and certainly good for public benefit and public realm improvements. But until everything is sort of -- until we have everything isolated and identified, the premature is start going through numbers. But you can certainly look back and see what our acquisition cost are for the assemblage, and that's the bulk of the cost. But then, obviously, there's all the public realm improvements we've been pretty specific on, it's $210 million of costs associated with public realm improvements. And then obviously, a lot of predevelopment possession cost on top of that, which, like I said, when it's all settled, we'll be able to give a better picture of.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just intellectual curiosity, when you're taking down 800,000 square feet brick by brick, have you got any preliminary demo cost on that yet?
componenttext: Just intellectual curiosity, when you're taking down 800,000 square feet brick by brick, have you got any preliminary demo cost on that yet?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In line with -- we do a lot of demolition in the city, this isn't the first, I would say it's certainly not the most material of items on the budget, and consistent with the kind of demolition cost we experienced throughout the city as we do annually
componenttext: Yes. In line with -- we do a lot of demolition in the city, this isn't the first, I would say it's certainly not the most material of items on the budget, and consistent with the kind of demolition cost we experienced throughout the city as we do annually, enormous volumes of demolition of space and occasionally, structures.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Bilerman of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Bilerman of Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Manny Korchman here with Michael. Just wondering if you can comment on any changes you're seeing to the investment landscape in Manhattan. And maybe if you could focus on any training [ph] trends you're seeing from foreign buyers.
componenttext: Manny Korchman here with Michael. Just wondering if you can comment on any changes you're seeing to the investment landscape in Manhattan. And maybe if you could focus on any training [ph] trends you're seeing from foreign buyers.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think we went through, specifically at Investor Day, that the trends emerging in terms of a lot of Chinese capital coming into the market, Canadian capital continuing to play a dominant role. I'd say since Investor Day, we've seen Japanese capital
componenttext: Well I think we went through, specifically at Investor Day, that the trends emerging in terms of a lot of Chinese capital coming into the market, Canadian capital continuing to play a dominant role. I'd say since Investor Day, we've seen Japanese capital with Mitsui Fudosan making a large investment into Hudson Yards with related. So there's a lot of Japanese capital circulating around -- there's just continued demand from all different points on the globe and in all different property types that are driving the market. And I think you're seeing that at the trophy level, and you're also seeing it a very deep level of demand for properties like 315 Park Avenue South, which traded within the last quarter. And other sort of side street and less high-profile glass and steel buildings, which are trading at record levels throughout the city.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any impacts from just the drop in crude prices more recently? Or has that really not trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet?
componenttext: Have you seen any impacts from just the drop in crude prices more recently? Or has that really not trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hasn't trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet. I read about it as having more direct impact on condo buyers, individuals, but not on a commercial land at all.
componenttext: Hasn't trickled down to the buyer pool quite yet. I read about it as having more direct impact on condo buyers, individuals, but not on a commercial land at all.

componenttext: The retail and disclosure that you guys provided, it's helpful, I think you talked about that at the Investor Day, when you gave the outlook on the significant amount of rev growth, I think it was around $165 million of rev growth over the next several years. If we look at stabilized retail assets, either kind of retail at the base of an office building or standalone retail, how do you think the valuation of those on a cap rate basis stabilized retail with compared to stabilized office in the city?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's similar. I mean, I think stabilized retail is getting slightly more aggressive bids than stabilized office. So stabilized office is sort of 4 caps, stabilized retail would be 3.5, 3.75 cap in prime areas. But it's hard to generalize beca
componenttext: Yes, I think it's similar. I mean, I think stabilized retail is getting slightly more aggressive bids than stabilized office. So stabilized office is sort of 4 caps, stabilized retail would be 3.5, 3.75 cap in prime areas. But it's hard to generalize because every property has its own below-market issue or opportunities that play a role in cap rates.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, understood, that's helpful. And then just maybe second one for Steve Durels. So you gave very helpful color on 280 Park. You did the Swarovski deal at 10 East 53rd, and I think you're targeting stabilization or leasing of that asset more in '16
componenttext: Yes. Okay, understood, that's helpful. And then just maybe second one for Steve Durels. So you gave very helpful color on 280 Park. You did the Swarovski deal at 10 East 53rd, and I think you're targeting stabilization or leasing of that asset more in '16 and '15, but can you give us a sense of how the pipeline shapes up at 10 East 53rd?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Remember, we signed the Swarovski deal for 2 floors. That was right on the tail of signing the 2 floor lease with Equinox. We have another leased out right now that we just went to documents with yesterday. The capital program is pretty well advanced
componenttext: Yes. Remember, we signed the Swarovski deal for 2 floors. That was right on the tail of signing the 2 floor lease with Equinox. We have another leased out right now that we just went to documents with yesterday. The capital program is pretty well advanced. If you went over there today, you'd see probably 80% of the lobby work is complete. Still a constructions zone, but when you walk in there, you clearly get a sense of the scale of what's happening at the ground floor and how impactful that's going to be there to reposition this building. The windows were all been replaced, the [indiscernible] has been recolored, a lot of the infrastructure works has been done and we've got very strong tour activity. From the mix of type of tenants, I'd say for 2/3 of the space on the floors, that are the 9,000 footers, it's primarily financial services and international companies. And then downstairs on the few floors that are a little bit larger, 16,000-foot floors, those are more general service businesses. And we've got 4 or 5 proposals out there we're trading with tenants, most of them for the top third of the building. And rents in that part of the building are anywhere from $95 to $115 a foot, as far as the term sheet numbers that were going back and forth with downtime. So we're feeling like we're right on plan for that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just -- Steve, quickly. At the base of the building, the rent differential between that sort of 110 at the top.
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just -- Steve, quickly. At the base of the building, the rent differential between that sort of 110 at the top.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a tale of 2 cities in that building. The bottom 9 floors, 2 of which have already been leased now, so there's only 7 floors left of space to worry about. Our 16,000 feet there, they don't have the big open views of Central Park the way we hav
componenttext: Yes. So it's a tale of 2 cities in that building. The bottom 9 floors, 2 of which have already been leased now, so there's only 7 floors left of space to worry about. Our 16,000 feet there, they don't have the big open views of Central Park the way we have upstairs. But that's still sort of low 70s rents, which are right in line with underwriting and put it in a very good place as far as being competitive in the market.
