headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s First Quarter 2015 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, ma
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp.'s First Quarter 2015 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed in the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com, by selecting the press release regarding the company's first quarter 2015 earnings.
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp, I ask those who are participating in the Q&A portion of the call, please limit your question to 2 per person. Thank you. 
I'll now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to have the opportunity to give all of you our perspective on the state of the market now that we are nearly 4 months into the new year. And I can sum up our excitement for SLG's year-to-date p
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to have the opportunity to give all of you our perspective on the state of the market now that we are nearly 4 months into the new year. And I can sum up our excitement for SLG's year-to-date performance in essentially two words: Leasing velocity. As of today, we have concluded over 900,000 square feet of commercial leasing in over 60 individual lease transactions. Most notable among these by size are the leases to Bloomberg, at 919 Third Avenue; Franklin Templeton, a new advisory at 280 Park Avenue; and We Work at 315 West 36 Street, a balance of financial, media and technology uses. It seems likely that having completed this amount of transactions in less than 4 months, we are on track to exceed our full year leasing projections. The Manhattan office and retail leasing teams are taking full advantage of vacancies in the growth portfolio and rolling up markets -- rolling up Winston market in the stabilized portfolio and also by taking advantage of our deeply embedded mark-to-market in our retail portfolio. And by doing this, it should allow us to meet or exceed this year's goals by laying the foundation for a strong future growth in 2016 and beyond when these newly signed leases generally kick in. 
Clearly, this market is benefiting from overall Midtown vacancy rates of under 9.5% on leasing activity that is on pace for between 35 million and 40 million square feet of new and renewal leasing this year. 
From an employment perspective, the first quarter of 2015 was the strongest quarter since the year 2000. New York City added 16,400 office using jobs. And the distribution of jobs among the 3 primary office using sectors: Professional and business services; financial activities; and information, were about equal. Usually, professional and business services accounts for most of the increase in office using jobs of late. But you can see now that's equally distributed between the 3 main office using sectors. 
The good news for our shareholders is that the leasing pipeline also remains robust even after coming out of engaged storm in 2015. We now have over 500,000 square feet of leased documents that are either out for signature or are pending and being negotiated. That compares with about 575,000 square feet at the same time last quarter and to the fourth quarter. And you see how we were able to convert these opportunities into signed lease transactions and then some. These leasing achievements helped to drive a 3% same-store NOI increase in the first quarter that was actually ahead of our budget and is expected to be exceeded for the balance of the year, such that we feel on track to meet our goal of between 3.5% and 4% for the full year. 
On the investments front, we were active closing out year end deals, like the additional ownership interest that we acquired in 800 Third Avenue and the closing of the Stonehenge residential portfolio, along with a successful disposition of 180 Maiden Lane and the net new origination of about $145 million of structured finance investments. This net investment activity, along with the unencumbering of 711 Third Avenue, enabled us to access the ATM and DRiP for modest amounts of equity, issuances that were completed to continue to improve our balance sheet. This steady improvement resulted in an upgrade in credit rating to investment grade for Moody's and an outlook upgrade from S&P.
For the balance of the year, we are expecting to rollout several assets for sale, which will be used in large measure to fund our pipeline of investments for the year without reliance on larger equity issuances.
Turning now to other main objectives for the second quarter and balance of the year, we continue to move forward through the approvals process in support of the Vanderbilt corridor rezoning, and to obtain a special permit for the development of a new commercial tower at One Vanderbilt Avenue. The project has the support of the President, City Planning Commission and our partner organizations at the coalition for a better Grand Central. We are now before city council, which is expected to vote for the project in May, at which point the land review process will be concluded. And we hope and expect that we'll receive this special permit that we've been working on for some period of time now, as most of you know.
Other company recognitions just to make note during the year -- I'm sorry during the first quarter, actually, actually this was just in the past three [ph] months. SL Green was recently recognized by the U.S. EPA as a 2015 ENERGY STAR Partner of the Year on Monday, April 20, during its award ceremony in Washington, D.C. And we got that award for sustained excellence in energy efficiency and the development of market-leading sustainability programs. So we're very proud of that, not only proud of the performance of the company, the balance sheet and then our stock price, but proud to be able to achieve all of that while doing it in a very responsible and environmentally sustainable way, which has now been recognized at a federal level.
Also as I think many or most of you know at this point, we were given admittance, if you will, into the S&P 500, which I think is basically a confirmation of the strategies and direction that we have taken with this company over the period of years to grow and diversify -- diversify within our market, and create a level of size, stability performance and return that we think is now on par with some of the best and biggest public companies on the New York Stock Exchange. And for that, we're very pleased and proud. 
So that is a quick snapshot of how we're looking at this market as its shaping up now. I would say it's basically on par or slightly better than our comments to you back in December at the investor conference, which you remember we have focused on basically 10 drivers of growth. I think those drivers of growth are evidencing themselves in a significant degree. And I think we've called the market fairly correctly for our shareholders, which we tried to do because we look as much as we're in this market, we view that we only have maybe a 6 to 9 to 12-month advantage over people not as deep in this market. So we always want to be as transparent and as early with you on how we see market trends developing. And I think, as I said, the first four months of the year, I think we've called it pretty well, so we're happy with that. And with that, we'll take your questions.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer is yes. We are considering JV alternatives for that asset. And I think the question will just be when shovel is in the ground already, in terms of we're just starting some internal demolition. So the big money spend starts probably in 201
componenttext: Well, the answer is yes. We are considering JV alternatives for that asset. And I think the question will just be when shovel is in the ground already, in terms of we're just starting some internal demolition. So the big money spend starts probably in 2017 and beyond. And by then, I think we'll have determined our capitalization of the project with or without JV partner. But obviously, it's a high consideration right now. We're sitting here in early 2015, it's being financed right now out of cash flow and it's not something that needs to be in our opinion, dealt with right now. We're assured as necessarily be because really value will be created between now and, call it, the next 12 to 24 months.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Steve, could you just give us a little bit of an update on the leasing update in the city in the first quarter? Not just your activity, but how you're thinking about the whole market. I mean it seems like there's this bigger trends in the market looking for space, small space trends seen pretty positive as well. And maybe really back to your portfolio, how you guys might benefit from that over the next year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if you break apart the various submarkets, you've seen strength across the board, both on the small space type tenant, but also on the big tenants and on the high-priced point tenants. I would say from a tenant profile perspective, financial service
componenttext: Well, if you break apart the various submarkets, you've seen strength across the board, both on the small space type tenant, but also on the big tenants and on the high-priced point tenants. I would say from a tenant profile perspective, financial services seem to be more active today than any time in the past couple of years. As we look at our leases out right now, nine of our 10 largest leases that were negotiated are financial-service-related businesses. And there doesn't seem to be a pocket and found where there is a dearth of activity. It's really sort of guns blazing across all submarkets. And we've been pushing rents up sort of every 30, 45 days, as far as we are taking rents are in most of our buildings. I don't think it's unique our portfolio. I hear the same thing back from the brokerage community, which I think is one of the big things to understand that the brokers are out there telling their clients that the balance is shifting towards the landlords, that the market is rising and they don't see it slowing down in the near to intermediate future.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Just lastly on the 919 Third in the Bloomberg lease, can you give us some perspective on the rent-to-rent market there? Is that replacing an expiration in coming years?
componenttext: All right. Just lastly on the 919 Third in the Bloomberg lease, can you give us some perspective on the rent-to-rent market there? Is that replacing an expiration in coming years?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are under a pretty detailed confy with them on that. It replaced several tenants draft, which is a part of Interpublic had rolled out of the building over a year ago. So they took 5 of their floors. And then we ended up 3 floors of tenants whose leases
componenttext: We are under a pretty detailed confy with them on that. It replaced several tenants draft, which is a part of Interpublic had rolled out of the building over a year ago. So they took 5 of their floors. And then we ended up 3 floors of tenants whose leases will be expiring over the next immediate 2 [ph] year or so. So it's a prelet on that. So it's a combination of floors.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from John Guinee of Stifel.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: My two questions may expand a bit, so but very quick answers. Weighted average share count increased by 2 million shares. A little background information on that. Other assets also popped this quarter, any color on that. And third, can Andrew or David tal
componenttext: My two questions may expand a bit, so but very quick answers. Weighted average share count increased by 2 million shares. A little background information on that. Other assets also popped this quarter, any color on that. And third, can Andrew or David talk about why, how the underwriting for your structured finance investments has changed over the last 2 [ph] years as capital has become readily available in that part of the world?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matt.
componenttext: Sure, Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, it's Matt. I guess the first two, so Mark alluded to in his commentary the use of ATM and the Drip plan to issue equity during the first quarter for some investment activity and repayment of the 711 Third Avenue mortgage. So that was -- that's the i
componenttext: John, it's Matt. I guess the first two, so Mark alluded to in his commentary the use of ATM and the Drip plan to issue equity during the first quarter for some investment activity and repayment of the 711 Third Avenue mortgage. So that was -- that's the increase in share counts. As to other assets this quarter, we booked the popular FAS 141 adjustment for 388 Greenwich, an acquisition that we did last year. As you know that bifurcates the real estate assets into real estate and then other. And so that's the increase in other assets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the structured finance side, I would say the underwriting parameters for subordinate financing have held pretty stable. We're benefited by the fact that a lot of the buildings that are being purchased are redevelopment type opportunities without a lot
componenttext: On the structured finance side, I would say the underwriting parameters for subordinate financing have held pretty stable. We're benefited by the fact that a lot of the buildings that are being purchased are redevelopment type opportunities without a lot in place in cash flows. So where you see lending get a lot more aggressive is where significant cash flow in place on assets most of assets that we're financing are lease up, lease to market, redevelopment type opportunities. We've been able to hold our underwriting standards pretty static from the last year and the year before.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just a quick question on the Suburban markets. Again, when you exclude Long Island, you still have fundamentals that seems to have weakened a little bit from versus prior year quarter. So I was hoping you can expand what you're seeing from the Suburb
componenttext: Yes. Just a quick question on the Suburban markets. Again, when you exclude Long Island, you still have fundamentals that seems to have weakened a little bit from versus prior year quarter. So I was hoping you can expand what you're seeing from the Suburban market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Isaac. That was really driven by one particular lease. The year end was obviously very strong. The first quarter, we saw a robust leasing activity of over 200,000 square feet. We're wobbily outperforming the market. Our occupancy is about 85%
componenttext: Hi, this is Isaac. That was really driven by one particular lease. The year end was obviously very strong. The first quarter, we saw a robust leasing activity of over 200,000 square feet. We're wobbily outperforming the market. Our occupancy is about 85% on signed deals, in both Connecticut and Stanford. The overall vacancy is about 23%, 24%. So that mark-to-market, if you exclude Jericho in that one particular deals on commenced deals, it was actually positive 4.4%. And on signed deals, it's about 1%. So fundamentals are still while not the city, they're still improving.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. And then, just another quick question on TIs and leasing commissions going forward. How should we be thinking about that for the development projects you're working on? Should we be thinking about them as potentially being higher at 2
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. And then, just another quick question on TIs and leasing commissions going forward. How should we be thinking about that for the development projects you're working on? Should we be thinking about them as potentially being higher at 280 Park or something that's unique to 280 Park?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well it's generally a function of direct, more so than development or not. We can do a development deal downtown and we wouldn't be offering the kind of concession packages you might offer at 10 East, 53rd and 280 Park. So you sort of have to look at it a
componenttext: Well it's generally a function of direct, more so than development or not. We can do a development deal downtown and we wouldn't be offering the kind of concession packages you might offer at 10 East, 53rd and 280 Park. So you sort of have to look at it as we look at it and I'm sure shareholders look at it on a net-effective basis, the higher rent, the higher margin deals and the bigger deals and savvy tenants are going through traditionally carry higher TI lows. So Steve, at 280 and 10 East, where would you peg those kind of new TI deals?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the high side, they've been as much as $75 to $80 a foot. But typically, they're more than $65 to $70. And to add to the logic of that, one is a function of price points of big rents, therefore, support a bigger TI contribution. But also the profile of
componenttext: On the high side, they've been as much as $75 to $80 a foot. But typically, they're more than $65 to $70. And to add to the logic of that, one is a function of price points of big rents, therefore, support a bigger TI contribution. But also the profile of the tenant that's going into those high rent paying buildings have extraordinarily expensive build outs. So they'll absorb a bigger rent, but they need some level of added support as far as TI contribution because they're build outs, aside from what the landlord may be contributing, they could be easily putting $100 a foot into the buildout on top of our contribution.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and you have to look at lease terms. I mean some of those bigger deals are 15 years terms, so there's 50% more terms because there's clearly not 50% more TI associated with those deals. So it's actually doing a 75 [ph] deal on a 50-year basis is bett
componenttext: Yes, and you have to look at lease terms. I mean some of those bigger deals are 15 years terms, so there's 50% more terms because there's clearly not 50% more TI associated with those deals. So it's actually doing a 75 [ph] deal on a 50-year basis is better than, I guess a $60, $65 on a 10-year [ph] base. You have to adjust the term, adjust for rent and rent margin. And construction costs are going up, I mean you hear that from everybody in New York City. So real TI is sort of holding flat to may be contracting a bit, so the real TI is actually going down as construction cost goes up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Sullivan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Sullivan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you can spend a minute on the speed retail business and just demand. When we've got West field and Brookfield opening, they spaced up downtown. It sounds like Times Square will have some vacancy with Toys "R" Us, and certainly with that stron
componenttext: I was hoping you can spend a minute on the speed retail business and just demand. When we've got West field and Brookfield opening, they spaced up downtown. It sounds like Times Square will have some vacancy with Toys "R" Us, and certainly with that stronger dollar and churns of employees slowing a little bit. What are you guys seeing in terms of tenant demand in the pipeline? And which submarket seem to be standing out?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're seeing very good demand in Times Square. I mean we just had a smashing success with our space at 1515 Broadway with the leases to Skechers and Swatch. We're seeing very strong demand in Soho, and we have a lot of active discussions on our vacant or
componenttext: We're seeing very good demand in Times Square. I mean we just had a smashing success with our space at 1515 Broadway with the leases to Skechers and Swatch. We're seeing very strong demand in Soho, and we have a lot of active discussions on our vacant or available properties in Soho. So we don't have any vacancies, we have some future availabilities, which we're talking to tenants about. And Prime Fifth Avenue and Madison continues to be strong. We did the Diesel lease at 625 which we spoke about in the last call. So we really haven't seen any abatement of tenant demand due to stronger dollar or any impact on tourism. Thus far, there's still a lot of strong tenant activity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, speaking with retail, what about the underwriting side and capital flows and asset values? Is that changing at all?
componenttext: And then, speaking with retail, what about the underwriting side and capital flows and asset values? Is that changing at all?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Continued strength, incredibly competitive to get sites, both leased and available sites, anywhere and we continue to see values escalate.
componenttext: Continued strength, incredibly competitive to get sites, both leased and available sites, anywhere and we continue to see values escalate.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious if you could just comment on sort of capital flows you're seeing into the New York. Obviously the markets are strong. Clearly still seeing some capital coming in. But just curious what your thoughts are with the balance of the year, particula
componenttext: Just curious if you could just comment on sort of capital flows you're seeing into the New York. Obviously the markets are strong. Clearly still seeing some capital coming in. But just curious what your thoughts are with the balance of the year, particularly from the foreign capital side. Do you expect that to be higher than last year and '15? And just thinking about that, in relation to the dollar move, things like that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to have a strong volume of incoming calls looking for opportunities. I would say the Chinese are very much making their presence felt. The purchase of some 717 Fifth, the office portion of that, that tower which traded to a Chinese compa
componenttext: Well, we continue to have a strong volume of incoming calls looking for opportunities. I would say the Chinese are very much making their presence felt. The purchase of some 717 Fifth, the office portion of that, that tower which traded to a Chinese company I'd say was a real bellwether type of transaction. And they're following that up with a lot of interest in other projects. There are voracious demand for residential and development-type opportunities. And Isaac, I don't know if you have anything to add to that. It wouldn't surprise me if this year eclipses last year, given there's a lot of deals in the market right now and there's an enormous amount of capital chasing that usually lead to record capital flows.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would echo with the Chinese. I think the Koreans are looking at the market stronger than they were last year. There are more groups searching more conversations that we're having. The sovereign wealth funds from all over the world as well, particularly
componenttext: I would echo with the Chinese. I think the Koreans are looking at the market stronger than they were last year. There are more groups searching more conversations that we're having. The sovereign wealth funds from all over the world as well, particularly from Norway and the Middle East, are also very, very active looking for yield that have lower cost of capital. So that's -- they're going to be very, very aggressive. And the city is relatively cheap compared to other markets around the world.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just one on the current site here. Just the other income, looks like it's up from where it's been in the last old [ph] quarters. Just curious if you could provide some color on that?
componenttext: And then, just one on the current site here. Just the other income, looks like it's up from where it's been in the last old [ph] quarters. Just curious if you could provide some color on that?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really just the timing of fee income. We recognized the fee in one of our projects in the first quarter as around $3 million. Otherwise, it's really recurring stock just buying million dollars of lease termination income in there as well.
componenttext: It's really just the timing of fee income. We recognized the fee in one of our projects in the first quarter as around $3 million. Otherwise, it's really recurring stock just buying million dollars of lease termination income in there as well.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, Matt, on the exchanges that are currently in the money, can you just give us an update, are these already reflected in the diluted share count? Or how should we be thinking about these? Presumably, the holders of these would convert
componenttext: Two questions. First, Matt, on the exchanges that are currently in the money, can you just give us an update, are these already reflected in the diluted share count? Or how should we be thinking about these? Presumably, the holders of these would convert them considering how they were given money.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: To answer your first question, they're not in the diluted share count based on the nature of the instruments. They remain at their face value in debt. They accrete up to their phase. They're slightly discounted to face on the balance sheet. They are conve
componenttext: To answer your first question, they're not in the diluted share count based on the nature of the instruments. They remain at their face value in debt. They accrete up to their phase. They're slightly discounted to face on the balance sheet. They are convertible at this point. They are convertible last quarter. They are convertible this quarter. The view is people won't exchange those because ultimately you end up adding equivalent yield in a more junior position to where they are today. All that said, it's a 2017 maturity. We've been focused at '17 maturities if we can early. So we are considering alternatives.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. The second question is, on the Street retail Page 47, in the prime retail section, a number of the near-term maturity leases, the mark-to-market doesn't look to be too different to where -- the in place doesn't look to be too differe
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. The second question is, on the Street retail Page 47, in the prime retail section, a number of the near-term maturity leases, the mark-to-market doesn't look to be too different to where -- the in place doesn't look to be too different from where the market rent is, in contrast you go out further and there's definitely an meaningful mark. So are the near-term maturities in the prime JV Street retail portfolio, are those assets that are going to be repositioned so that the mark-to-market is actually higher? Or just surprised that there's really not much of a mark there? And again, this is the JV Street retail, the near-term stuff.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Alex, I've got to go through the specific properties underlying those assumptions and come back you with a more specific answer. Looking at the table, we don't give addresses. So I'll think that through and take a look specifically at that trend.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Well, I think if I can just ask one more for [indiscernible] Matt, was there anything in the first quarter operating margin, why the margin was meaningfully higher than last year?
componenttext: Okay, okay. Well, I think if I can just ask one more for [indiscernible] Matt, was there anything in the first quarter operating margin, why the margin was meaningfully higher than last year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we have seasonal expenses. First and third quarters are higher than second and fourth. And reimbursement revenues don't track proportionately to increased Opex. So our OpEx was high in the first quarter as it has traditionally been, particularl
componenttext: Obviously, we have seasonal expenses. First and third quarters are higher than second and fourth. And reimbursement revenues don't track proportionately to increased Opex. So our OpEx was high in the first quarter as it has traditionally been, particularly high given New York had another cold, wet winter. The reimbursement revenues bleed in on a lag basis. And so I'd say that's really the only trend there. Nothing unusual in line with our expectations as Marc alluded to earlier, both on a same-store an absolute basis after margins for this quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa from Evercore ISI.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mark, at the Analyst Day you guys talked about I think releasing spreads of 10% to 12%, yet you don't have pretty successful New York City number at 17 [ph]. I realized the Suburban number is a little bit weak. But any thoughts as to kind of where that nu
componenttext: Mark, at the Analyst Day you guys talked about I think releasing spreads of 10% to 12%, yet you don't have pretty successful New York City number at 17 [ph]. I realized the Suburban number is a little bit weak. But any thoughts as to kind of where that number may be? And is there anything in that leases that may be Steve is talking about today that would suggest there are some aberration in that 17% [ph], or that the ones currently being negotiated or lower? Or is that likely to move higher throughout the year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We just gave this guidance like 3.5 months ago. So in prep for today's call, we do not go back through all of the goals, if you will, to reassess. So I can't sit here now -- you're saying it's 12%, but usually we have a range, so 10% to 12%. So is the 10%
componenttext: We just gave this guidance like 3.5 months ago. So in prep for today's call, we do not go back through all of the goals, if you will, to reassess. So I can't sit here now -- you're saying it's 12%, but usually we have a range, so 10% to 12%. So is the 10% to 12%, as we sit here high in the first quarter, it was I guess 17%, so that's clearly higher. I don't think we are projecting 17% as run rate, so clearly. It sort of depends on what roles when, some of the leases we're signing or signing for vacancy, not for replacement leases. So I think at this point, we're going to stay with 10% to 12%. It certainly seems like there could be upside to that number, based on the velocity and based on the first quarter's result. But other than just a hunch, I couldn't tell you that we've gone through each of the remaining 200 and some odd leases, we expect to sign for the remainder of the year. And figure out, A, which one of those are in the mark-to-market pool; and B, how it will affect the first quarter. So it's certainly seems like there could be some upside there, but it would be premature of us to say that. And we'll just -- maybe by midyear, Steve will have like better feel for that. We start to forecast for the balance of the year. I think we'll have a better sense. But this early on, I would say if nothing else trending towards the higher end of that range.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess your comment about asset sales. clearly -- the capital flows are extremely strong. I'm just wondering, what sort of dollar volume could that process? And where does the Suburban portfolio sort of fit into that mix? Does that need to
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess your comment about asset sales. clearly -- the capital flows are extremely strong. I'm just wondering, what sort of dollar volume could that process? And where does the Suburban portfolio sort of fit into that mix? Does that need to see more leasing before you think you can bring it to market? Or do you think buyers will be willing to in fact, pay for some of that vacancy?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We gave some guidance at in December. And I think Matt, what was that about $600 million for commercial office?
componenttext: We gave some guidance at in December. And I think Matt, what was that about $600 million for commercial office?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we don't have dispositions, FFO, and $100 million for Suburban. So I think we feel good with those numbers. That's -- we have several assets that are just now, one in the market, several more that we intend to introduce in the market. All extremely go
componenttext: And we don't have dispositions, FFO, and $100 million for Suburban. So I think we feel good with those numbers. That's -- we have several assets that are just now, one in the market, several more that we intend to introduce in the market. All extremely good assets. But again, these are assets where we look at the sort of average growth trend in these assets over the next 5 to 7 to 10 years, 3 to 5 years. And we compared again some of the more opportunistic or value-added opportunities we're looking at. And in those instances, we try to cycle out of the more mature properties and into the less mature core property in this market, because anything that's been sold over the last 2 or 3 years or likely is being sold today, certainly has the potential for significant appreciation in the next 3 to 5 years. But maybe not the same rate as the opportunities we're looking at. And that's how we're calling out the portfolio. And so on that basis, local probably look to do some complete dispositions and/or strategic JVs of assets that we think will get us up to our over the $600 million guidance for the year. I think our plan still is to meet or exceed that. And I would say the same for Suburban. We didn't put those numbers out there without some thought as to which assets we intended to try and dispose of and the timing that we thought would be the optimal timing to do so because in some cases, we're trying to get some leasing done right at the wire before we introduce it to the market. So I think we're still on that kind of trajectory. And again, we can revisit midyear once we have a better sense of the reception to the market that the prices will be at.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Bilerman of Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: If we look at the leases you have, under negotiation or out for signature, can you just drill down a little bit for us, how much of that is existing vacancy, pending '15 role, or next expiration in future years? And then maybe how much is office versus retail?

componenttext: It's almost 50-50 between renewals and new leases. And of that, the dominant type of tenants is financial services and on the new leases, it's I would say the majority of the square footage under negotiation is filling space that's currently vacant as opposed to preleasing space for future vacancy.

componenttext: And how much of that is retail?

componenttextpreview: Retail is a small percentage of the square footage that's out right now.
componenttext: Retail is a small percentage of the square footage that's out right now.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Matt, given the big noncash sort of jumps in 1Q, does any of that benefit FFO for the quarter that we should be thinking about on a run-rate basis?
componenttext: And Matt, given the big noncash sort of jumps in 1Q, does any of that benefit FFO for the quarter that we should be thinking about on a run-rate basis?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the first -- I mean, for as much as comes on generally rolls off. So we had an adjustment for the first quarter that has a little bit of 2014 in it for 388 [ph] but a few million dollars dollars. Otherwise, for the balance of the year, I would expect i
componenttext: In the first -- I mean, for as much as comes on generally rolls off. So we had an adjustment for the first quarter that has a little bit of 2014 in it for 388 [ph] but a few million dollars dollars. Otherwise, for the balance of the year, I would expect it to be pretty close to what it has been historically. That's for our FAS1. On a straight-line basis, that straight-line adjustment would be higher this year. That simply a function of city's free rent at 388 Greenwich, which is going to be in the neighborhood of $80 million to $82 million a share.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Brendan Maiorana of Wells Fargo.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, maybe just an update in terms of a couple of office assets where you got leasing in the growth portfolio, Tower 46, 10 East 53rd. And then can you provide an update at 280 Park where you exceptionally put the bed there on the supplemental, it's 65%
componenttext: Steve, maybe just an update in terms of a couple of office assets where you got leasing in the growth portfolio, Tower 46, 10 East 53rd. And then can you provide an update at 280 Park where you exceptionally put the bed there on the supplemental, it's 65% occupied, but I think it's higher from a lease percentage basis.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So 10 East we have leases out on 5 floors right now. We've signed a couple of leases in the past quarter. At the end of last year, we've already done 4 floors of leases. The capital project there is 90% complete. The lobby will be 100% done in about
componenttext: Yes. So 10 East we have leases out on 5 floors right now. We've signed a couple of leases in the past quarter. At the end of last year, we've already done 4 floors of leases. The capital project there is 90% complete. The lobby will be 100% done in about 2 weeks. Elevator cabs will follow on over the next month or 2 after that. And the Plaza is going in about 45 days, when all infrastructure is already complete. We're rocking and rolling as far as leasing velocity and interactivity and active leased negotiations at that property. Tower 46, we've got a lease out covering 1.5 floor, and we're trading paper with another very large tenant, that it's way early to handicap as to whether there's any life to that are not. But very strong tour activity. That's going to be one of those buildings we're going to take sometime to build up some momentum because it was kind of out of sight, out of mind for the brokerage community, even though it was a brand, newly constructed property, but it was off most brokerage radar. So it's been a big effort to date to reintroduce it back to the brokerage community and get everybody through the property so they understand what it is that we're offering. And 280 Park Avenue is quite frankly on fire right now. We've got several leases out with big, big rents and we'll be down to -- by the end of this year, that building will be from a leasing perspective, it will hit stabilization.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then probably for Matt, although maybe someone else. I'm not sure if you can share any details that rework lease. And I know I got a lot of space on the number with a lot of REITs out there. Are there a lot of capital dollars going into the space? And how do you guys get comfortable? Or how did you get comfortable with the credit and the dollars that go into the space with that lease?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll, look, I mean we're pretty excited about our work as a tenant and as a business. We've spent a lot of time with the principles and their people and at their facilities looking at their business model, which caters to this call working community and
componenttext: We'll, look, I mean we're pretty excited about our work as a tenant and as a business. We've spent a lot of time with the principles and their people and at their facilities looking at their business model, which caters to this call working community and the types of tenants out there that have high demand today, these TAMI-type and technology tenants. And their menu of kind of added, value-added services, we think, we think differentiates them from a lot of other companies we see in that space. It's a unique offering. They have a substantial amount of cash in the bank. They have substantial institutional backing. And we got comfortable that for this kind of building where we think their community of people want to be in this building, it was a perfect fit. So I think where this is a joint venture, we own probably a 1/3 or so of equity but not just us, but our individual partners are all very excited about this lease, both in terms of whatever capital is entailed by it and excited to have them in our stable of tenants. So it's a good lease and great for us and we think we're going to do great in the building.

componenttextpreview: A follow-up on asset sales and sources of capital. Should we think about those sales as completely funding your investment program for the rest of the year? And if it doesn't, how are you looking to fund those between debt and equity?
componenttext: A follow-up on asset sales and sources of capital. Should we think about those sales as completely funding your investment program for the rest of the year? And if it doesn't, how are you looking to fund those between debt and equity?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we generally match fund over the years. So I think that's a good assumption. I can't say exactly pipeline of many, many buildings and talking about selling a number of building timing issues goal is certainly to try and fund the new acquisit
componenttext: Well, I think we generally match fund over the years. So I think that's a good assumption. I can't say exactly pipeline of many, many buildings and talking about selling a number of building timing issues goal is certainly to try and fund the new acquisitions, predominantly with the net proceeds of sale on a tax efficient basis, doing 10-31 [ph] if possible. And then either tweaking up or down with that are equity of if necessary based on the timing of the volume. So -- but I mean, that's the way we've always done it. So there's no change in that front. Traditionally, we've been net growers, so it has required, on a net basis, some amount of debt and equity. But in ratios, we'll not decidedly keep us in the range of investment-grade rating that we would take.

componenttext: Well, it's not a question of preference per se, I would say the plan is to fund the majority of it with asset sales. And then depending on timing and volumes, look to tweak up or down debt and equity as necessary.

How much you would like to grow the book. How you're seeing competition shape up for date? And also how you're thinking about origination yields at this point going forward?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think in terms of the size the portfolio. I think at the end of last year, we said we'd be up about $250 million kind of year-over-year. And I think that still holds. If anything we're kind ahead of budget right now, but we know there's a lot of r
componenttext: Sure. I think in terms of the size the portfolio. I think at the end of last year, we said we'd be up about $250 million kind of year-over-year. And I think that still holds. If anything we're kind ahead of budget right now, but we know there's a lot of repayments coming in the second half of the year. Yields have, in the market generated, I think they continue to compress. We've been able to kind of outperform the expectations that we set out at the beginning of the year at the end of last year. But it's kind of too early to tell what the entire year is going to look like. There's a lot of competition out there through relationships and kind of the different approaches I've laid out at the end of the year, we've been able to kind of keep our volumes up and we're very bullish about the forecast for the rest of the year.

componenttext: Back on the rework lease, and let's throw in Bloomberg as well. Just given the overall shortage of large blocks in Manhattan, how much were the prices of those leases reflective of that? Was it demonstrably stronger or in other words, are prospective tenants acutely aware that there's not much out there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things. There are 2 different products as far as the building of the Bloomberg sign. But I can tell you is, broadly speaking, the availability of large blocks of space, and let's define that as being 250,000 square feet or more, you can
componenttext: Well, a couple of things. There are 2 different products as far as the building of the Bloomberg sign. But I can tell you is, broadly speaking, the availability of large blocks of space, and let's define that as being 250,000 square feet or more, you can count on one hand. And if you're looking for 0.5 million square feet, then maybe there's 2 of them in Midtown. So the big block premium that tenants are confronted paying for a rough cycle is definitely back in the market. And I would expect it to sort of excel as the year goes by because it's not going to be a lot of inventory people in this space. We were building different side Street and it sort of fell into the fringe area of Midtown South kind of the hotspot where TAMI type businesses want to be. And that's the kind of look and feel that we would like to associate themselves with. I can't really, specifically to the rents, but I would tell you that the rents that we got on the building were well in excess of underwriting when we bought the building and well in excess of what we would've budgeted 18 months ago.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we conducted a search to add a board member kind of on heels of Andrew's ascension to the board in order to keep what the governance committee felt was a proper balance between independent and insiders. So we wanted -- that was one of the motivating
componenttext: Well, we conducted a search to add a board member kind of on heels of Andrew's ascension to the board in order to keep what the governance committee felt was a proper balance between independent and insiders. So we wanted -- that was one of the motivating forces to add a board member, and Betsy sort of stood out to everybody on the board asked perfect for the role. She's seasoned. She's been involved with a lot of big company boards and brings a level of experience that's different from the traditional local finance and real estate experience that probably exists from the SL Green board chief. She really comes from the technology sector, if you will, in Venture capital sector. And given the amount of importance we put on those sectors in today's market from a tenancy perspective and nothing else, we think that she can add a lot of value in terms of her role as a corporate governance board member, but also in terms of her knowledge and relationships and ability to access the kind of tenants in this market where we would like to have a bigger presence with. So on a whole number of fronts, she stood out as a great candidate. And was appointed.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up, Steve, to a comment you made earlier about the strong demand at 280 Park. Maybe you can just talk a little bit about the retail demand there? I saw an article the other day about the 4 Seasons restaurant considering its options. headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, let's put it in perspective, the retail on that building is not the driver of NOI. Part of our development plan was to create either one large or 2 medium-sized restaurant spaces. There's side street locations as part of that building. And we've had
componenttext: Look, let's put it in perspective, the retail on that building is not the driver of NOI. Part of our development plan was to create either one large or 2 medium-sized restaurant spaces. There's side street locations as part of that building. And we've had discussions with 4 Seasons. They've been a wonderful addition to the property if they were to come that way. But we're certainly not counting on them, coming over to the building. We're out in the market talking to a number restaurateurs. And now that the development work is essentially completed the property well down the road on the office lease up, we're turning our attention is the client-side the right restauranteur or restaurateurs to fill those 2 spaces. So we view it more as a element of the development plan to add the right look and feel and amenity to the building at street level, as opposed to a typical addition to property, which is a big NOI contributor.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And rent?
componenttext: And rent?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, it's going to depend on the tenant. If we get a world-class tenant that we think really adds to the -- to what the building is all about, then we'll skew the transaction to be more of a less base rent, more percentage rent type of transacti
componenttext: Quite frankly, it's going to depend on the tenant. If we get a world-class tenant that we think really adds to the -- to what the building is all about, then we'll skew the transaction to be more of a less base rent, more percentage rent type of transaction. If we get a more midline type of retailer that has still a high design with good look and feel, then we'll expect more in base rent. And the market value on this basis, probably $100, $125 a foot.

componenttext: Okay. And a maybe question for Steve. Just curious what you're seeing in terms of rent growth momentum in Midtown so for this year. You're pushing rent at a pace that's sort of consistent with your expectations as you kind of sit out the year and if there are any other submarkets surprisingly on the upside of the downside.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well rents across the board are going up. And I always like to use the Great Park building. It's sort of the great barometer of where the Midtown market is. Every lease that we're negotiating, where the negotiations part in the past 60 days, is in the low
componenttext: Well rents across the board are going up. And I always like to use the Great Park building. It's sort of the great barometer of where the Midtown market is. Every lease that we're negotiating, where the negotiations part in the past 60 days, is in the low 60s and square foot. And if you compare that to the height of the last, top of the last market cycle, Graybar got to a point where a week or 2 we did like a couple of deals of like $61 a foot. And now we're at the point where Graybar is no typical view has been sent, $61, $62, $63 starting rent. So I think that speaks volumes as to where the trend line is on rent growth.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: it's Jordan Sadler here for Craig. Just a little bit of color on the investment opportunities you're seeing in front of you today, be it on the office side, retail, resi or sort of better opportunity today.
componenttext: it's Jordan Sadler here for Craig. Just a little bit of color on the investment opportunities you're seeing in front of you today, be it on the office side, retail, resi or sort of better opportunity today.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say we're actively looking at all 3 of those sectors. I mean you have several large deals on the market in 11 Madison and the Trinity portfolio. So those are 2 big big office deals in the market. There are smaller office deals as well. Retail, most of
componenttext: I'd say we're actively looking at all 3 of those sectors. I mean you have several large deals on the market in 11 Madison and the Trinity portfolio. So those are 2 big big office deals in the market. There are smaller office deals as well. Retail, most of our focus continues to be on off market deals. We don't really chase and bit marketed deals much on the retail side and as we think we are very specific in a unique angle on a deal. And then residential, generally, I would say we've been looking at structured type deals, similar type of off market deals, the market to retail deals are very difficult for us to compete on. But opportunities like 605 West 42nd Street, which we closed up at the end of last year and the Stonehenge portfolio, which we closed up in the first quarter of this year are getting most of our attention. We're side of agnostic as to what sector we deploy that capital. And we look more in terms of risk return for any individual deals and mash them up with each other. We're not willing to take lower returns really in any of the sectors. We're trying to take the highest return on the capital be to play so we can find those higher returns across all the sectors, plus structured finance, is where we'll focus the capital.

We're definitely looking in Brooklyn and obviously Manhattan. We have not done much in Queens and not much has crossed our desks in terms of investment opportunities, that pretty granular markets out there. But we're actually seeing some opportunities in Harlem, none the where I would say we're actively pursuing, but that market is also picking up as usually the case when Manhattan gets hyper, hypercompetitive, you see demand pushed to some of the outer areas. I think Brooklyn and Manhattan are still our main focuses.
All right. I think that concludes it for questions. Operator, is the queue empty?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. First Quarter 2015 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded.At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, mana
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. First Quarter 2015 Earning Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded.
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed in the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's first quarter 2015 earnings.
[Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to have the opportunity to give all of you our perspective on the state of the market now that we are nearly 4 months into the new year. And I can sum up our excitement for SLG's year-to-date p
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. We are pleased to have the opportunity to give all of you our perspective on the state of the market now that we are nearly 4 months into the new year. And I can sum up our excitement for SLG's year-to-date performance in essentially 2 words: Leasing velocity.
As of today, we have concluded over 900,000 square feet of commercial leasing in over 60 individual lease transactions. Most notable among these by size are the leases to Bloomberg at 919 Third Avenue; Franklin Templeton, a new advisory at 280 Park Avenue; and WeWork at 315 West 36th Street, a balance of financial, media and technology uses. It seems likely that having completed this amount of transactions in less than 4 months, we are on track to exceed our full year leasing projections.
The Manhattan office and retail leasing teams are taking full advantage of vacancies in the growth portfolio and rolling up markets -- really what brings to [ph] market in the stabilized portfolio and also by taking advantage of our deeply embedded mark-to-market in our retail portfolio. And by doing this, it should allow us to meet or exceed this year's goals while laying the foundation for a strong future growth in 2016 and beyond when these newly signed leases generally will kick in. Clearly, this market is benefiting from overall Midtown vacancy rates of under 9.5% on leasing activity that is on pace for between 35 million and 40 million square feet of new and renewal leasing this year.
From an employment perspective, the first quarter of 2015 was the strongest quarter since the year 2000. New York City added 16,400 office-using jobs. And the distribution of jobs among the 3 primary office-using sectors, professional and business services, financial activities and information, were about equal. Usually, professional and business services accounts for most of the increase in office-using jobs of late. But you can see now that's equally distributed between the 3 main office-using sectors.
The good news for our shareholders is that the leasing pipeline also remains robust even after coming out of the gate strong [ph] in 2015. We now have over 500,000 square feet of leased documents that are either out for signature or are pending and being negotiated. That compares with about 575,000 square feet at the same time last quarter and to the fourth quarter. And you see how we were able to convert these opportunities into signed lease transactions and then some.
These leasing achievements helped to drive a 3% same-store NOI increase in the first quarter that was actually ahead of our budget and is expected to be exceeded for the balance of the year, such that we feel on track to meet our goal of between 3.5% and 4% for the full year.
On the investments front, we were active closing out year-end deals, like the additional ownership interest that we acquired in 800 Third Avenue and the closing of the Stonehenge residential portfolio, along with the successful disposition of 180 Maiden Lane and the net new origination of about $145 million of structured finance investments.
This net investment activity, along with the unencumbering of 711 Third Avenue, enabled us to access the ATM and DRIP for modest amounts of equity, issuances that were completed to continue to improve our balance sheet. This steady improvement resulted in an upgrade in credit rating to investment grade for Moody's and an outlook upgrade from S&P. For the balance of the year, we are expecting to rollout several assets for sale which will be used in large measure to fund our pipeline of investments for the year without reliance on larger equity issuances.
Turning now to other main objectives for the second quarter and balance of the year. We continue to move forward through the approvals process in support of the Vanderbilt Corridor rezoning and to obtain a special permit for the development of a new commercial tower at One Vanderbilt Avenue.
The project has the support of the Borough President, Borough City Planning Commission and our partner organizations at the coalition for a better Grand Central. We are now before the city council, which is expected to vote upon the project in May, at which point', the land review process will be concluded. And we hope and expect that we'll receive this special permit that we've been working on for some period of time now, as most of you know.
Other company recognitions, just to make note, during the year -- I'm sorry, during the first quarter actually. This is just in the past 3 months. SL Green was recently recognized by the U.S. EPA as a 2015 ENERGY STAR Partner of the Year on Monday, April 20, during its award ceremony in Washington, D.C. And we got that award for sustained excellence in energy efficiency and the development of market-leading sustainability programs.
So we're very proud of that, not only proud of the performance of the company, the balance sheet and in our stock price, but proud to be able to achieve all of that while doing it in a very responsible and environmentally sustainable way, which has now been recognized at a federal level.
Also, as I think many or most of you know at this point, we were given admittance, if you will, into the S&P 500, which I think is basically a confirmation of the strategies and direction that we've taken with this company over the period of years to grow and diversify, but diversify within our market, and create a level of size, stability performance and return that we think is now on par with some of the best and biggest public companies on the New York Stock Exchange. And for that, we're very pleased and proud.
So that is a quick snapshot of how we're looking at this market as it's shaping up now. I would say it's basically on par or slightly better than our comments to you back in December at the investor conference, which, you remember, we have focused on basically 10 drivers of growth. I think those drivers of growth are evidencing themselves in a significant degree.
And I think we've called the market fairly correctly for our shareholders, which obviously we try to do because we look -- as much as we're in this market, we view that maybe we only have maybe a 6- to 9- to 12-month advantage over people not as deep in this market. So we always want to be as transparent and as early with you on how we see market trends developing. And I think, as I said, the first 4 months of the year, I think we've called it pretty well, so we're happy about that. And with that, we'll take your questions.

componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Nick. We're going to [indiscernible]. At One Vanderbilt, are you guys contemplating doing a joint venture on that project ahead of putting shovel in the ground? Or can you talk a little bit about how you're thinking about the long-term capital stack for that asset?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer is yes, we are considering JV alternatives for that asset. And I think the question will just be when -- shovel is in the ground already, I mean, in terms of -- just starting some interior demolition. So the big money spend starts in prob
componenttext: Well, the answer is yes, we are considering JV alternatives for that asset. And I think the question will just be when -- shovel is in the ground already, I mean, in terms of -- just starting some interior demolition. So the big money spend starts in probably 2017 and beyond. And by then, I think we'll have determined our capitalization of the project with or without a JV partner. But obviously, it's a high consideration right now. Although sitting here in early 2015, it's being financed right now out of cash flow, and it's not something that needs to be, in our opinion, dealt with right now. And we shouldn't necessarily be because I think there's -- real value will be created between now and call it, the next 12 to 24 months.
