          Yes. Just a quick question on the Suburban markets. Again, when you exclude Long Island, you still have fundamentals that seem to have weakened a little bit versus prior quarters. Just hoping you can expand what you're seeing in the Suburban markets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            This is Isaac. That was really driven by one particular lease. The year-end was obviously very strong. The first quarter, we saw a robust leasing activity of over 200,000 square feet. We're wildly outperforming the market. Our occupancy is
componenttext:
:  
          This is Isaac. That was really driven by one particular lease. The year-end was obviously very strong. The first quarter, we saw a robust leasing activity of over 200,000 square feet. We're wildly outperforming the market. Our occupancy is about 85% on signed deals in both Connecticut and Stamford. The overall vacancy is about 23%, 24%. So that mark-to-market, if you exclude Jericho in that one particular deal, on commenced deals, it was actually positive 4.4%. And on signed deals, it's about 1%. So fundamentals are still -- while not the city, they're still improving.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, that's helpful. And then, just another quick question on TIs and leasing commissions going forward. How should we be thinking about that for other development projects you're working on? Should we think of them as potentially being as
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, that's helpful. And then, just another quick question on TIs and leasing commissions going forward. How should we be thinking about that for other development projects you're working on? Should we think of them as potentially being as high as at 280 Park or that's something very unique to 280 Park?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, it's generally a function of direct, more so than development or not. We could do a development deal downtown and we wouldn't be offering the kind of concession packages that you might offer at 10 East 53rd and 280 Park. So I think yo
componenttext:
:  
          Well, it's generally a function of direct, more so than development or not. We could do a development deal downtown and we wouldn't be offering the kind of concession packages that you might offer at 10 East 53rd and 280 Park. So I think you'd sort of have to look at it as we look at it, and I'm sure shareholders will get, on a net-effective basis, the higher rent, higher margin deals are going -- and the bigger deals for savvier tenants are going to traditionally carry higher TI levels. So Steve, at 280 and 10 East, where would you peg those kind of new TI deals?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            On the high side, they've been as much as $75 to $80 a foot. But typically, they're more in the $65 to $70. And to add to the logic of that, one is a function of price points of big rents, therefore, support a bigger TI contribution. But al
componenttext:
:  
          On the high side, they've been as much as $75 to $80 a foot. But typically, they're more in the $65 to $70. And to add to the logic of that, one is a function of price points of big rents, therefore, support a bigger TI contribution. But also, the profile of the tenant that's going into those high rent paying buildings have extraordinarily expensive buildouts. So they'll absorb a bigger rent, but they need some level of added support as far as TI contribution because their buildouts, aside from what the landlord may be contributing, they could easily be putting another $100 a foot on -- into the buildout on top of our contribution.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. And you have to look at lease terms obviously. I mean, some of those bigger deals are 15 years terms, so there's 50% more term, but there's clearly not 50% more TI associated with those deals. So it's actually doing a $75, $80 deal on
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. And you have to look at lease terms obviously. I mean, some of those bigger deals are 15 years terms, so there's 50% more term, but there's clearly not 50% more TI associated with those deals. So it's actually doing a $75, $80 deal on a 15-year basis is better than, I guess, a $60, $65 on a 10-year basis. You have to adjust the term, you have to adjust for rent and rent margin. And construction costs are going up. I mean, you hear that from everybody in New York City. So real TI is sort of holding flat to may be contracting a bit, so the real TIs are actually going down as construction cost goes up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Our next question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext:
:  
          Our next question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could spend a minute on the street retail business and just demand. I mean we've got Westfield and Brookfield opening, they're spaced up downtown. It sounds like Times Square will have some vacancy with Toys“R”Us. And certainly, with
componenttext: I was hoping you could spend a minute on the street retail business and just demand. I mean we've got Westfield and Brookfield opening, they're spaced up downtown. It sounds like Times Square will have some vacancy with Toys“R”Us. And certainly, with the stronger dollar and tourism slowing a little bit, what are you guys seeing just in terms of tenant demand in the pipeline? And which submarkets seem to be standing out?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            We're seeing very good demand in Times Square. I mean, we just had a smashing success with our space at 1515 Broadway with the leases to Skechers and Swatch. We're seeing very strong demand in Soho, and we have a lot of active discussions o
componenttext:
:  
          We're seeing very good demand in Times Square. I mean, we just had a smashing success with our space at 1515 Broadway with the leases to Skechers and Swatch. We're seeing very strong demand in Soho, and we have a lot of active discussions on our vacant or available properties in Soho. We really don't have any vacancies. We have some future availabilities which we're talking to tenants about. And prime Fifth Avenue and Madison continues to be strong as well. And then we did the Diesel lease at 625 which we spoke about in the last call. So we really haven't seen any abatement of tenant demand due to stronger dollar or any impact on tourism. Thus far, there's still a lot of strong tenant activity.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, sticking with retail, what about on the underwriting side and capital flows and asset values? Is that changing at all?
componenttext: And then, sticking with retail, what about on the underwriting side and capital flows and asset values? Is that changing at all?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Continued strength, incredibly competitive to get sites, both leased and available sites anywhere and we've continued to see values escalate.
componenttext:
:  
          Continued strength, incredibly competitive to get sites, both leased and available sites anywhere and we've continued to see values escalate.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext:
:  
          Our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Just curious if you could just comment on sort of capital flows you're seeing into New York. Obviously, the rental markets are strong, clearly still seeing some capital coming in. But just curious what your thoughts are with the balance of
componenttext:
:  
          Just curious if you could just comment on sort of capital flows you're seeing into New York. Obviously, the rental markets are strong, clearly still seeing some capital coming in. But just curious what your thoughts are with the balance of the year, particularly from the foreign capital side. Do you expect that to be higher than last year and in '15? And just thinking about that in relation to the dollar move, things like that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, we continue to have a very strong volume of incoming calls looking for opportunities. I would say the Chinese are very much making their presence felt. The purchases of 717 Fifth, the office portion of that tower which traded to a Chi
componenttext:
:  
          Well, we continue to have a very strong volume of incoming calls looking for opportunities. I would say the Chinese are very much making their presence felt. The purchases of 717 Fifth, the office portion of that tower which traded to a Chinese company, I'd say, was a real bellwether-type transaction, and they're following that up with a lot of interest in other projects. There are voracious demand for residential and development-type opportunities. And Isaac, I don't know if you have anything to add to that. And we've -- it wouldn't surprise me if this year eclipses last year given the amount of -- there's a lot of deals on the market right now and there's an enormous amount of capital chasing it so usually that leads to record capital flows.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes, I would just echo with the Chinese. I think the Koreans are looking at the market stronger than they were last year. There are more groups searching more conversations that we're having. The sovereign wealth funds from all over the wor
componenttext:
:  
          Yes, I would just echo with the Chinese. I think the Koreans are looking at the market stronger than they were last year. There are more groups searching more conversations that we're having. The sovereign wealth funds from all over the world as well, particularly from Norway and the Middle East, are also very, very active looking for yield that have lower cost of capital. So that's -- they're going to be very, very aggressive. And the city is still relatively cheap compared to other markets around the world.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And then, just one on the accounting side here. Just other income looks like it's up from where it's been in the last couple of quarters. Just curious if you could provide some color on that.
componenttext:
:  
          Okay. And then, just one on the accounting side here. Just other income looks like it's up from where it's been in the last couple of quarters. Just curious if you could provide some color on that.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            It's really just the timing of fee income. We recognized a fee in one of our projects in the first quarter as around $3 million. Otherwise, it's really recurring stuff, just probably $1 million of lease termination income in there as well.
componenttext:
:  
          It's really just the timing of fee income. We recognized a fee in one of our projects in the first quarter as around $3 million. Otherwise, it's really recurring stuff, just probably $1 million of lease termination income in there as well.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Our next question comes from Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Two questions. First, Matt, on the exchangeables that are currently in the money, could you just give us an update? Are these already reflected in the diluted share count? Or how should we be thinking about these? Presumably, the holders of
componenttext:
:  
          Two questions. First, Matt, on the exchangeables that are currently in the money, could you just give us an update? Are these already reflected in the diluted share count? Or how should we be thinking about these? Presumably, the holders of these would convert them given how they're in the money.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            So to answer your first question, they're not in the diluted share count based on the nature of the instrument. They remain at their face value in debt. They accrete up to their face. They're slightly discounted to face on the balance sheet
componenttext:
:  
          So to answer your first question, they're not in the diluted share count based on the nature of the instrument. They remain at their face value in debt. They accrete up to their face. They're slightly discounted to face on the balance sheet. They are convertible at this point. They were convertible last quarter. They are convertible this quarter. The view is people won't exchange those because ultimately, you'll end up adding equivalent yield in a more junior position to where they are today. All that said, it's a 2017 maturity. We've been focused on attending to '17 maturities if we can early, so we are considering alternatives.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay, that's helpful. The second question is, on the street retail, Page 47, in the prime retail section, a number of the near-term maturity leases, the mark-to-market doesn't look to be too different to where -- the in-place doesn't look t
componenttext:
:  
          Okay, that's helpful. The second question is, on the street retail, Page 47, in the prime retail section, a number of the near-term maturity leases, the mark-to-market doesn't look to be too different to where -- the in-place doesn't look to be too different from where the market rent is. In contrast, you go out further and there's definitely a meaningful mark. So are the near-term maturities in the prime JV street retail portfolio, are those assets that are going to be repositioned so that the mark-to-market is actually higher or -- just surprised that there's really not much of a mark there. And again, this is on the JV street retail, the near-term stuff.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Alex, I've got to go through the specific properties underlying those assumptions and come back you with a more specific answer. And looking at the table, we don't give addresses. So I'd have to go through and take a look specifically at th
componenttext:
:  
          Alex, I've got to go through the specific properties underlying those assumptions and come back you with a more specific answer. And looking at the table, we don't give addresses. So I'd have to go through and take a look specifically at that trend.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay, okay. Well, then if I can just ask one more just to replace that. Matt, was there anything in the first quarter operating margin -- why the margin was meaningfully higher than last year?
componenttext:
:  
          Okay, okay. Well, then if I can just ask one more just to replace that. Matt, was there anything in the first quarter operating margin -- why the margin was meaningfully higher than last year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Obviously, we had seasonal expenses. First and third quarters are higher than second and fourth. And reimbursement revenues don't track proportionately to increased Opex. So our OpEx was high in the first quarter as it has traditionally bee
componenttext:
:  
          Obviously, we had seasonal expenses. First and third quarters are higher than second and fourth. And reimbursement revenues don't track proportionately to increased Opex. So our OpEx was high in the first quarter as it has traditionally been, particularly high given New York had another cold, wet winter. The reimbursement revenues bleed in on a lag basis. And so I'd say that's really the only trend there. Nothing unusual in line with our expectations, as Marc alluded to earlier, both on a same-store and absolute basis in terms of margin for this quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.
componenttext:
:  
          Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Mark, at the Analyst Day, you guys talked about, I think, releasing spreads of 10% to 12%, yet had pretty successful New York City number at 17%. I realize the Suburban number is a little bit weak. But any thoughts as to kind of where that
componenttext:
:  
          Mark, at the Analyst Day, you guys talked about, I think, releasing spreads of 10% to 12%, yet had pretty successful New York City number at 17%. I realize the Suburban number is a little bit weak. But any thoughts as to kind of where that number may be? And is there anything in the leases that maybe Steve is talking about today that would suggest there was some aberration in that 17% or that the ones currently being negotiated are lower? Or is that just likely to move higher throughout the year?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            I wouldn't -- we just gave this guidance like 3.5 months ago. So in prep for today's call, we did not go back through all of the goals, if you will, to reassess. So I can't sit here now and say whether -- well, you're saying it's 12%, but w
componenttext:
:  
          I wouldn't -- we just gave this guidance like 3.5 months ago. So in prep for today's call, we did not go back through all of the goals, if you will, to reassess. So I can't sit here now and say whether -- well, you're saying it's 12%, but we usually give a range, so it's at 10% to 12%. So is it 10% to 12%? Yes, as we sit here high, well, first quarter, it was, I guess, 17%, so that's clearly higher. I don't think we are projecting 17% as run rate. So clearly, it sort of depends on what rolls when, some of the leases we're signing, we're signing for vacancy, not for replacement leases. So I think at this point, we're going to stay with 10% to 12%. It certainly seems like there could be upside to that number based on the velocity and based on the first quarter's result. But other than just a hunch, I couldn't tell you that we've gone through each of the remaining 200 and some-odd leases we expect to sign for the remainder of the year and figured out, a, which one of those are a, in the mark-to-market pool; and b, how it will affect the first quarter. So it certainly seems like there could be some upside there, but it would be premature of us to say that. And we'll just -- maybe by mid-year, Steve will have like better feel for that when we start to reforecast for the balance of the year, and I think we'll have a better sense. But this early on, I would say, if -- nothing else, trending towards the higher end of that range.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Okay. And then, I guess, your comment about asset sales. Clearly, capital flows are extremely strong. I'm just wondering, what sort of dollar volume could that possess? And where does the Suburban portfolio sort of fit into that mix? Does t
componenttext:
:  
          Okay. And then, I guess, your comment about asset sales. Clearly, capital flows are extremely strong. I'm just wondering, what sort of dollar volume could that possess? And where does the Suburban portfolio sort of fit into that mix? Does that need to see more leasing before you think you can bring it to market? Or do you think buyers will be willing to, in effect, pay for some of that vacancy?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, we gave some guidance at -- in December. And I think, Matt, if I'm not wrong, was that about $600 million for commercial office?
componenttext:
:  
          Well, we gave some guidance at -- in December. And I think, Matt, if I'm not wrong, was that about $600 million for commercial office?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  Correct.
componenttext:
:  
Correct.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  And we don't have dispositions, just probably [ph] FFO, and $100 million for Suburban. So I think we feel good with those numbers. That's -- we have several assets that are just now -- one in the market, several more that we intend to introduce at th
componenttext:
:  
And we don't have dispositions, just probably [ph] FFO, and $100 million for Suburban. So I think we feel good with those numbers. That's -- we have several assets that are just now -- one in the market, several more that we intend to introduce at the market. All extremely good assets. But again, these are assets where we look at the sort of average growth trend in these assets over the next 5 to 7 to 10 years, 3 to 5 years. And we compare it against some of the more opportunistic or value-added opportunities that we're looking at. And in those instances, we try to cycle out of the more mature properties and into the less mature. It's hard to call any property mature in this market because anything that's been sold over the last 2 or 3 years or likely is being sold today certainly has the potential for significant appreciation in the next 3 to 5 years. But maybe not at the same rate as the opportunities we're looking at. And that's how we're culling out the portfolio. So on that basis, we'll probably look to do some complete dispositions and/or strategic JVs of assets that we think will get us up to or over the $600 million guidance for the year, I think our plan still is to meet or exceed that. And I would say the same for Suburban. So we didn't put those numbers out there without some forethought as to which assets we intended to try and dispose of and the timing that we thought would be the optimal timing to do so because in some cases, we're trying to get some leasing done right at the wire before we introduce it to the market. So I think we're still on that kind of trajectory. And again, we can revisit mid-year once we have a better sense of the reception to the market at the prices we'll be asking.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

How much of that is existing vacancy, pending '15 roll or the acceleration in future years? And maybe how much is office versus retail?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Let's see. On the -- we've got -- it's almost 50-50 between renewals and new leases. And of that, the dominant type of tenant is financial services and on the new leases, it's -- I would say, the majority of the square footage under negotia
componenttext:
:  
          Let's see. On the -- we've got -- it's almost 50-50 between renewals and new leases. And of that, the dominant type of tenant is financial services and on the new leases, it's -- I would say, the majority of the square footage under negotiation is filling space that's currently vacant as opposed to preleasing space for future vacancy.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

          In the first -- I mean, for as much as comes on generally rolls off. So we had an adjustment for the first quarter that has a little bit of 2014 in it for 388, but a few million dollars. Otherwise, for the balance of the year, I would expect it to be pretty close to what it has been historically. That's for our FAS 141. On a straight line basis, the straight line adjustment will be higher this year. That's simply a function of city's free rent at 388 Greenwich, which is going to be in the neighborhood of $80 million to $82 million this year.

componenttext:

          Steve, maybe just an update in terms of a couple of office assets where you've got leasing in the growth portfolio, Tower 46, 10 East 53rd. And then can you just provide an update at 280 Park? Are you exceptionally put to bed there? I know on the supplemental, it's 65% occupied, but I think it's higher from a lease percentage basis.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Yes. So 10 East, we have leases out on 5 floors right now. We've signed a couple of leases in the past quarter. At the end of last year, we had already done 4 floors of leases. The capital project there is 90% complete. The lobby will be 10
componenttext:
:  
          Yes. So 10 East, we have leases out on 5 floors right now. We've signed a couple of leases in the past quarter. At the end of last year, we had already done 4 floors of leases. The capital project there is 90% complete. The lobby will be 100% done in about 2 weeks. Elevator cabs will follow on over the next month or 2 after that, and the plazas will be done in about 45 days and all infrastructure is already complete. So we're rocking and rolling as far as leasing velocity and tour activity and active leased negotiations at that property. Tower 46, we've got a lease out covering 1.5 floors, and we're trading paper with another very large tenant, that it's way early to handicap as to whether there's any life to that or not, but very strong tour activity. That's going to be one of those buildings where it takes some time to build up some momentum because it was kind of out of sight, out of mind for the brokerage community, even though it was a brand-newly constructed property, but it was off most broker's radar. So it's been a big effort to date to reintroduce it back into the brokerage community and get everybody through the property so they understand what it is that we're offering. And 280 Park Avenue is -- quite frankly, it's on fire right now. We've got several leases out at big, big rents, and we'll be down to -- by the end of this year, that building will be -- from a leasing perspective, it will hit stabilization.

But -- and I know that they've got a lot of space with a number of other REITs that are out there. But just -- are there a lot of capital dollars going into the space? And how do you guys get comfortable? Or how did you get comfortable with the credit and the dollars that go into the space with that lease?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            We'll, look, I mean, we're pretty excited about WeWork as a tenant and as a business. We've spent a lot of time with their principles and their people and at their facilities, looking at their business model, which caters to this coworking
componenttext:
:  
          We'll, look, I mean, we're pretty excited about WeWork as a tenant and as a business. We've spent a lot of time with their principles and their people and at their facilities, looking at their business model, which caters to this coworking community and the types of tenants out there that have high demand today, these TAMI-type and technology tenants. And their menu of kind of added -- value-add services, we think, differentiates them from a lot of other companies we see in that space. It's a unique offering. They have a substantial amount of cash in the bank. They have substantial institutional backing. And we got comfortable that for this kind of building where we think their community of people want to be in this building, it was a perfect fit. So I think we're -- this is a joint venture, we own probably 1/3 or so of equity. And not just us, but our individual partners, we're all very excited about this lease, both in terms of whatever capital is entailed by it and excited to have them in our stable of tenants. So it's a good lease and great for us, and we think WeWork's going to do great in the building.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            A follow-up on asset sales and sources of capital. Should we think about those sales as completely funding your investment program for the rest of the year? And if it doesn't, how are you looking to fund those between debt and equity?
componenttext:
:  
          A follow-up on asset sales and sources of capital. Should we think about those sales as completely funding your investment program for the rest of the year? And if it doesn't, how are you looking to fund those between debt and equity?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, I think we generally match fund over the years. So I think that's a good assumption. I can't say exactly because we have pipeline of many, many buildings and we're talking about selling a number of buildings, so there's timing issues
componenttext:
:  
          Well, I think we generally match fund over the years. So I think that's a good assumption. I can't say exactly because we have pipeline of many, many buildings and we're talking about selling a number of buildings, so there's timing issues and everything else. But the goal is certainly to try and fund the new acquisitions predominantly with the net proceeds of sale on a tax efficient basis, doing 1031 where possible, and then either tweaking up or down with debt or equity, if necessary, based on the timing and the volume. So -- but I mean, that's -- I think that's the way we've always done it, so there's no change in that front. And traditionally, we've been net growers, so it has required, on a net basis, some amount more of debt and equity. But in ratios, that will now decidedly keep us in the range of the investment-grade rating that we've obtained.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

          Well, it's not -- I mean, it's not a question of preference per se, I would say the plan is to fund the majority of it with asset sales and then depending on timing and volumes, look to tweak up or down with debt and equity as necessary.

          Okay, that's helpful. And another follow-up actually on structured finance. Just wanted to get an update on how you're thinking about the outlook for income for that business, how much you'd like to grow the book, how you're seeing competition shape up for the year and also, how you're thinking about origination yields at this point going forward.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Sure. I think in terms of the size of the portfolio, I think at the end of last year, we said we'd be up about $250 million kind of year-over-year. I think that still holds -- if anything, we're kind ahead of budget right now, but we know t
componenttext:
:  
          Sure. I think in terms of the size of the portfolio, I think at the end of last year, we said we'd be up about $250 million kind of year-over-year. I think that still holds -- if anything, we're kind ahead of budget right now, but we know there's a lot of repayments coming in the second half of the year. Yields have -- in the market generally, I think they continue to compress. We've been able to kind of outperform the expectations that we set at the beginning of the -- or I guess, the end of last year. But it's kind of too early to tell what the entire year is going to look like. There's a lot of competition out there. But through relationships and kind of the different approaches I laid out at the end of the year, we've been able to kind of keep our volumes up, and we're very bullish about the forecast for the rest of the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  Back on the WeWork lease and let's throw in Bloomberg as well, just given the overall shortage of large blocks in Manhattan, how much was the pricing on those leases reflective of that, was it demonstrably stronger? In other words, are prospective te
componenttext:
:  
Back on the WeWork lease and let's throw in Bloomberg as well, just given the overall shortage of large blocks in Manhattan, how much was the pricing on those leases reflective of that, was it demonstrably stronger? In other words, are prospective tenants acutely aware that there's just not much out there?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, a couple of things. There are 2 different products as far as the building that Bloomberg signed at. But I can tell you is, broadly speaking, the availability of large blocks of space, and let's define that as being 250,000 square feet
componenttext:
:  
          Well, a couple of things. There are 2 different products as far as the building that Bloomberg signed at. But I can tell you is, broadly speaking, the availability of large blocks of space, and let's define that as being 250,000 square feet or more, you can count on one hand. And if you're looking for 0.5 million square feet, then maybe there's 2 of them in Midtown. So the big block premium that tenants are confronted with having to pay on a -- from a rent perspective is definitely back in the market. And I would expect it to sort of excel as the year goes by because there's not going to be a lot of inventory coming online for big block space. WeWork's building, different animal, side street, and it sort of fell into the fringe area of Midtown South kind of the hotspot where the TAMI-type businesses want to be. And that's the kind of look and feel that WeWork likes to associate themselves with. So I can't really comment specifically to the rents but would tell you that the rents that we got on the building were well in excess of underwriting when we bought the building and well in excess of what we would've budgeted 18 months ago.

          Okay, that's helpful. And then I just wanted to give you a chance to comment on Betsy being out as a Director earlier this month. Maybe just share with us why she's the right person and what she brings to the table.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, we conducted a search to add a board member kind of on the heels of Andrew's ascension to the board in order to keep what the governance committee felt was a proper balance between independents and insiders. So we wanted -- that was o
componenttext:
:  
          Well, we conducted a search to add a board member kind of on the heels of Andrew's ascension to the board in order to keep what the governance committee felt was a proper balance between independents and insiders. So we wanted -- that was one of the motivating forces to add a board member, and Betsy just sort of stood out to -- everybody on the board as perfect for the role. She's seasoned, she's been involved with a lot of big company boards and brings a level of experience that's different from the traditional local finance and real estate experience that probably exists on the SL Green board. She really comes out of the technology sector, if you will, in venture capital sector. And given the amount of importance we put on those sectors in today's market from a tenancy perspective if nothing else, we think that she can add a lot of value in terms of her role as a corporate governance board member, but also in terms of her knowledge and relationships and ability to access the kind of tenants in this market where we would like to have a bigger presence with. So on a whole number of fronts, she stood out as a great candidate and was appointed.

          Just a quick follow-up, Steve, to a comment you made earlier about the strong demand at 280 Park. Maybe you could just talk a little bit about the retail demand there? I saw an article the other day about the Four Seasons Restaurant considering its options. I just want to get a sense of what the demand is today, what you thought the lease up opportunities and the rents were?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, let's put it in perspective. The retail on that building is not the driver of NOI. Part of our development plan was to create either one large or 2 medium-sized restaurant spaces. They are side street locations as part of the building
componenttext:
:  
          Well, let's put it in perspective. The retail on that building is not the driver of NOI. Part of our development plan was to create either one large or 2 medium-sized restaurant spaces. They are side street locations as part of the building. And we've had discussions with Four Seasons. They'd be a wonderful addition to the property if it were to come that way. But we're certainly not counting on them coming over to the building. We're out in the market talking to a number of restaurateurs. And now that the development work is essentially complete at the property and we're well down the road on the office lease up, we're turning our attentions to try and to find the right restaurateur or restaurateurs to fill those 2 spaces. So we view it more as a element of the development plan to add the right look and feel and amenity to the building at street level, as opposed to a typical retail addition to a property which is a big NOI contributor.

componenttextpreview: :            It's -- quite frankly, it's going to depend on the tenant. If we get a world-class tenant that we think really adds to the -- to what the building is all about, then we'll skew the transaction to be more of a less base rent, more percentage
componenttext:
:  
          It's -- quite frankly, it's going to depend on the tenant. If we get a world-class tenant that we think really adds to the -- to what the building is all about, then we'll skew the transaction to be more of a less base rent, more percentage rent type transaction. If we get a more mid-line type of retailer that has still a high design with good look and feel, then we'll expect more in base rent. And I think the market value on this space is probably $100, $125 a foot.

componenttext:

          Okay. And maybe a question for Steve. Just curious what you're seeing in terms of rent growth momentum in Midtown so far this year. I mean are you pushing rents at a pace that's sort of consistent with your expectations as you kind of sit out the year and if there are any other submarkets that are surprising you on the upside or the downside.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, rents across the board are going up. And I always like to use the Graybar Building as sort of the great barometer of where the Midtown market is. Every lease that we're negotiating, where the negotiations start in the past, call it, 6
componenttext:
:  
          Well, rents across the board are going up. And I always like to use the Graybar Building as sort of the great barometer of where the Midtown market is. Every lease that we're negotiating, where the negotiations start in the past, call it, 60 days, is in the low $60s a square foot. And if you compare that to the height of the last -- top of the last market cycle, Graybar got to a point where, I think, for a week or 2, we did a couple of deals at like $61 a foot. And here it's -- and now we're at a point where Graybar is -- the typical deal that's being signed, $61, $62, $63 starting rent. So I think that speaks volumes as to where the trend line is on rent growth.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :  It's Jordan Sadler here with Craig. Just maybe a little bit of color on the investment opportunities you're seeing in front of you today, be it on the office side, retail, resi, where is sort of better opportunity today?
componenttext:
:  
It's Jordan Sadler here with Craig. Just maybe a little bit of color on the investment opportunities you're seeing in front of you today, be it on the office side, retail, resi, where is sort of better opportunity today?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: :            Well, I'd say we're active looking at all 3 of those sectors. I mean, you have several large deals on the market in 11 Madison and the Trinity portfolio. Those are 2 big office deals in the market. There are smaller office deals as well. Re
componenttext:
:  
          Well, I'd say we're active looking at all 3 of those sectors. I mean, you have several large deals on the market in 11 Madison and the Trinity portfolio. Those are 2 big office deals in the market. There are smaller office deals as well. Retail, most of our focus continues to be on off-market deals. We don't really chase and bid marketed deals much on the retail side, unless we think we have a very specific and unique angle on a deal. And then residential, generally, I would say we've been looking at structured-type deals, similar type of off-market deals. The marketed retail deals are very difficult for us to compete on. But opportunities like 605 West 42nd Street, which we closed up the end of last year, and the Stonehenge portfolio, which we closed up in the first quarter of this year, are getting most of our attention. We're side of agnostic as to what sector we deploy the capital in. And we look more in terms of risk return for any individual deal and match them up with each other. We're not willing to take lower returns really in any of the sectors. We're trying to get the highest return on the capital we deploy, so wherever we can find those higher returns across all the sectors plus structured finance is where we'll focus the capital.

But that market is also picking up as is usually the case when Manhattan gets hypercompetitive, you start to see demand pushed to some of the outer areas. So I think Brooklyn and Manhattan are still our main focuses.
