headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, manage
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC's Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's second quarter 2015 earnings.
[Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We are pleased to take you through our second quarter results which are certainly representative of the investment strategy that's paying off in the form of outside gains, and
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We are pleased to take you through our second quarter results which are certainly representative of the investment strategy that's paying off in the form of outside gains, and an operational approach that is producing sector-leading, same-store performance. 
Accomplishments for the quarter are numerous and they are highlighted by the following: accelerating FFO growth; outside same-store cash NOI increase; over 1 million square feet of leasing executed in the quarter; strong occupancy gains; premium debt and preferred equity origination; and several large and strategically important acquisitions and dispositions.
I think the best way to summarize our current thoughts on the market is to look at our -- things in the context of how they will drive our future growth and build upon our portfolio quality and liquidity. Our leasing efforts continue to benefit by having well position and fully be developed properties in Manhattan's most desirable submarkets against the backdrop of a strong local economy producing record private sector job growth and robust demand for office space.
Last year, New York city generated 54,000 private sector jobs in the first six months, en route to 104,000 private sector jobs added for the full calendar year 2014. 
So far, in 2015, first half of private sector job additions are at 62,000 jobs added, eclipsing last year's first half amount and setting the stage for the fifth consecutive year in which private sector job growth would exceed 90,000 incrementally.
These kinds of job growth statistics will produce approximately 4 million square feet of new demand and annually around the city, which is the driving force behind the declining vacancy rates, which Cushing and Wakefield now pegs at 8.9% for Midtown and 6.2% for Midtown South. The city economy is growing rapidly, notwithstanding an only moderate recovery in the financial services sector, emphasizing New York's increasingly diversified business base. What's important here is not only by how much office using tenants are growing, but where they are growing. Midtown leasing has been exceptionally strong, reaching 10.5 million square feet of leasing and accounting for 94% of total Manhattan absorption in the first half. And no one in the city is better positioned to benefit from this dynamic market than us. We have leased over 1.3 million square feet through June. And for good measure we have already signed leases for an excess of 250,000 square feet in the first 22 days of July.
As importantly, the leasing is being done at rental levels that are representative of a resurging Midtown market, and we are routinely the achieving double-digit mark-to-market increases, both with expiring, same-store lease expirations. 
With over 1.5 million square feet of office leases signed in Manhattan, and another 1.1 million square feet in our current pipeline, by the way an amount that is the highest in the last 4 quarters, we are raising our leasing guidance to 2.2 million square feet for the full calendar year, which is still composed raising of the bar on the amount of leasing activity to be completed in just over the next 5 months. 
So these leasing results, the economy, the leasing backdrop, is clearly going to help drive the momentum behind the drivers of growth that we have, in great detail, stepped through back in December. And we repeat often to our tenant base and shareholder base, stabilized office, mark-to-market, we expect to be significant and we expect that to continue through the balance of the year. Our growth portfolio is leasing at a very fast clip as evidenced by the fact we had a dominant amount of renewal leases in the second quarter and the retail portfolio leasing continues to be strong, as evidenced by the Adidas lease that we just signed, but in combination with the other retail leases signed throughout the year. 
However, another means of driving growth and increasing quality of the portfolio away from the operational metrics is through our investment strategy and the strategic rationale, which is underpinned by our purchase of 11 Madison Avenue, which was also announced during the second quarter. 11 Madison achieved a number of things for the company, some of which we put up on the deck on our website. So for those who haven't seen it, we encourage you to pull up 11 Madison transaction summary. And some of the highlights therein is that this represents for us another trophy asset added to SL Green's core portfolio. We are buying this property at substantially below in place escalated rents, resulting in long-term embedded growth opportunities. And we are gaining more exposure to the desirable Midtown South submarket, something that we have made a primary objective of ours, and a stated objective of ours over the years. We will now become the dominant owner in Midtown South, with over 3.5 million square feet of properties located immediately adjacent to Madison Square Park, which we think is one of the best areas in the Midtown South, plus other properties scattered throughout.
In terms of the economics of the deal, we think the deal is excellent in terms of the going-in cap rate of 4.6%, which is much higher than almost full recent comparable trades for buildings of this quality and scope and even buildings of lesser quality and -- and lesser duration.
And to put that in perspective, our belief is that the money to be made on 11 Madison is as much about having bought it right, and capitalizing it right, because we will be capitalizing it with 10-year fixed-rate financing that will be sub-4% in cost. So we will have positive leverage going into this deal, with only somewhere around I think 60% -- 55%, 60% financing that will put our yields in excess of 5% cash-on-cost. And this is the kind of deal that I believe once all the tenants are fully installed, going through their free rent, and all the TI and capital work is completed, that is squarely a 4-cap for a less asset. If you apply that kind of cap rate on a stabilized NOI, that's a $3 billion asset, which is only $1,300 a foot, which is actually not only unprecedented by Manhattan standards, but it's actually lower than many comparable Midtown office rate that are priced between $1,500 and $1,800 a foot. And we think that, that -- given it's the market -- the best market, the building is not institutional quality, but basically rebuilt in terms of systems and redesign specifically for the heavy use of somebody like Credit Suisse and Sony, which are very infrastructure-sensitive tenants, that this is an asset that will provide long-term earnings growth near-term value accretion, and serve as a receiver for the sales and numerous sales that we will be either completing over the next 4 to 6 months or have already announced, backing all of that in a very tax-efficient manner into 11 Madison, to serve as a receiver with all those attributes and credit quality long-term lease durations. 
So very happy with the way this is turning out. We obviously have more work ahead of us in terms of achieving the full amount of sales and refinancings that we have highlighted within the deck, that I'm referring to. But when I look at it as sort of a transaction that stands on its own just for those merits, add on top of that the fact that we expect to achieve anywhere between $0.15 near-term and $0.30 over 3 [ph] years of accretion, deriving from the series of integrated transactions and I think that certainly puts it in one of the top 2 or 3 transactions we've been here in the company. So very happy with how this is turning out. More work to do. We'll have an update for you in the next conference call. With that, let me turn it over to Andrew Mathias.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. In addition to the 11 Madison transaction, we have an incredibly productive quarter just completed, highlighted really by 2 sales that were part of the strategic plan for the company for the year and then sort of became part of the 11 Madiso
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. In addition to the 11 Madison transaction, we have an incredibly productive quarter just completed, highlighted really by 2 sales that were part of the strategic plan for the company for the year and then sort of became part of the 11 Madison funding plan as well. Tower 45 is an asset we marketed a little more than 2 years ago and we are not satisfied with the offers we received at that time. We pulled it off the market. And Steve did an excellent job of leasing the building up, and the decision to put off that sales and subsequently the contract announced within the last couple of weeks, earned us about $100 million above the offers we had received at the time of the earlier marketing. So at $830 a foot and a sub 3/4% [ph] cap rate, the sale is a very powerful endorsement for Midtown Manhattan office values. 
Moving on to 131 Spring Street. If one wants to see the power of the retail platform from the off-market acquisition to a redevelopment of assets and conversion of a lot of space, from stairwells, hallways and ancillary office space into prime retail space, reletting in terms of redoing both of the anchor retail leases of the property, and then recapitalizing, 131 Spring is sort of the perfect case study for SL Green value creation. 
We created about $150 [ph] million of gross profit in the 2.5 years since we purchased the asset, with an unlevered IRR for the company of 30% and a strong potential for future performance due to the incentivized JV we entered into the asset with our partner. 
Given the returns on this asset and our other investments in the market, we continue to focus heavily on the SoHo market and its growth potential and we'll talk about that a little bit more when we go through the acquisition of 110 Greene Street. But I'd tell you, Green -- SL Green's ability to buy assets right, capitalize them right and then take them to market and sell or recapitalize, taking profits, really, both these assets show just how significant the embedded gains we have in a lot of our assets are. We have dozens more assets on our balance sheet that we're sitting on like these where we can go out and demonstrate value and put up enormous returns to shareholders. We look forward to doing more of that in the months to come as we continue through our aggressive sales program this year. 
On the acquisition side, we are also excited to announce agreements to acquire 2 classic SL Green deals, both off market, both incredibly well located and both with enormous upside potential.
110 Greene is a great blend for us of huge retail upside and prime office and residential space, an irreplaceable asset of one of the most desirable full blocks in SoHo. This building sits a few short blocks from 131 Spring where I just took you through our results there. And we have very high expectations for investment in this property. We think we're going to be able to do some very creative things given that we purchased the building next door, 102 Greene within the last 12 months and we're exploring synergies already there, it gives us quite a lot of flexibility in terms of adding value. 
And 187 Broadway is on a stretch of Broadway we're very familiar with, having completed our retail and dormitory building at 180 Broadway, which is directly across the street from 187. On 187, we have a lot of flexibility in terms of uses for this property. And our basis gives us a lot of flexibility in what we decide to do here. We're still studying all the various uses. We have an maximum flexibility in terms of zoning. And we look forward to updating our shareholders as our business plan for this asset really crystallizes, what we're taking a lot of meetings with third parties in terms of the best way to maximize the value in the site.
Moving onto the structured finance book. We saw another strong quarter, with $302 million of gross originations, and a current balance on our book of $1.7 billion. Spreads continue to hold up, as volatility in CMBS has really kept the lid on overaggressive senior leading, which has kept mezzanine spreads and mezzanine advance rates stable and very comfortable for us. 
Our pipeline in the second half of the year is very healthy, and we will continue to use the capital markets to optimize our returns on those interests we decide to retain. 
I would just in closing say it's been an incredibly busy summer around here. And I would like to acknowledge the efforts of our investment and retail teams, and leasing and management and underwriting teams, in putting together really a stunning series of transactions on the acquisition and disposition side that we believe set us up for enormous future growth and profits.
So with that, I will turn it over to Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. As evidenced in our reported results for the first two quarters, our operating fundamentals are very strong, as is Manhattan market backdrop. However that performance in our view of months to come, we have our increased FFO guidance range
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. As evidenced in our reported results for the first two quarters, our operating fundamentals are very strong, as is Manhattan market backdrop. However that performance in our view of months to come, we have our increased FFO guidance range for 2015 to $6.30 [ph] to $6.34 [ph] a share, a meaningful increase of $0.05 over the midpoint of our previous guidance range and putting us on track for growth in FFO of over 8% versus last year.
In our real estate portfolio, the velocity of leasing of rents at the upper end of our expectations will contributed to earnings in 2015 or even more meaningful for growth in the years to come. During the first 6 months of the year, our Manhattan office leasing volume has been brisk. Pat on the back to Steve and his team. But at SL Green, we were reward outperformance by moving the goalposts hence the increased target of 2.2 million square feet. 
On the retail side of the business, we leased almost 90,000 square feet in the first six months at over 80% mark-to-market and the pipeline remains robust. And not to be outdone, our Suburban leasing volume, has also far outpaced our expectation, with over 400,000 square feet leased in the first six months. All of this activity drove meaningful increases in same-store these occupancy in the second quarter, with the Manhattan portfolio near an all-time high of 97% and the Suburban portfolio north of 84%. 
Occupancy increases driving the revenue line, coupled with seasonably lower operating expenses in the second quarter, after a brutal first quarter, improved our operating margins and allowed us to achieve same-store cash NOI growth of almost 5% for the quarter. This puts us well on pace to achieve our full year same-store cash NOI growth target of at least 3.6%, sitting at 4% for just the first 6 months. 
In the category of other income, we recognized leased termination income of $7.7 million in the second quarter, including $5.8 million at 919 Third Avenue, bringing our total for the year to $8.8 million. We have only recognized so far in 2015 is consistent with what was included in our initial FFO guidance range, and is also very close to the average lease termination income that we have recorded over the last several years, which is obviously the basis for what we include in our guidance. 
We include lease termination income in our guidance because it is a very consistent, recurring income stream and has been for many years. Simply the accelerated recognition of leased income that we would otherwise would've received over time. More importantly, like at 919 3rd, incentive paid to termination fees is often vacating space that we are re-leasing. They actually increased the income we're recognizing on that same space. We often see people looking to carve out lease termination income as nonrecurring. We see that as misleading, inaccurate and understating FFO because that income stream is so consistent. 
One additional comment on the termination income that we recognized at 919 3rd, in response to some the questions that we received. No, this amount was not included in our calculation of same-store cash NOI growth of 4.9% for the quarter and 4% for the year-to-date, because it is structured to be paid out over a period of several years. 
In the debt preferred equity portfolio, we continue to outpace our expectations with regard to the volume of originations and the yields at which we are originating product. To accomplish this, we have not relied our underwriting standards, gone out further on the risk curve or even left the New York City marketplace. 
Specific to yield, recall that our initial FFO guidance assumed the yields on new originations of 8.5%. For the first six months, the weighted average yields that are over $400 million of net originations was north of 10%. In addition, the pace of repayments has been slower than we anticipated, all of which is contributing directly to FFO. 
Finally, we have the effect on FFO on real estate investment activity. Our real estate transaction volume for 2015 is on track toward the highest trending 1 year in the company's history. Clearly, 11 Madison is the highlight of this activity. As we have outlined in the thorough presentation on our website, as well as in our 8-K, hopefully everyone has studiEd, the acquisition of 11 Madison at a 4 [ph] 6 [ph], which will be funded primarily with $1.4 billion of long-term fixed-rate sub-4% debt, and up to 11 asset sales for recapitalization at an average cap rate below 3.5%, was highly accretive for years to come. It is also contributory to FFO in 2015, albeit to a lesser extent given the timing of closing. More broadly, the totality of our acquisitions and dispositions for the year, versus the very modest activity we included in our initial guidance, has contributory to our FFO. Based upon the price of which we are acquiring new assets, the NOI of those assets, the form of consideration paid and the timing of acquisitions as compared to our decision. We're not just upgrading the portfolio, we're doing it accretively. 
There's a lot of good news for the bottom line coming from virtually all aspects of our business, but there's one significant offset that actually kept a lid on what would have otherwise been an even larger upward guidance provision. That could be summarized in 2 words: Transaction cost. Recall that our initial 2015 FFO guidance, includes transaction cost of approximately $4 million. You can see in our financials we actually exceeded that amount in the first six months, and 11 Madison deal among others hasn't even closed. In total, we now project third-party cost to execute our investment activity that will need to run through day rates to find FFO, for this year will be $7 million to $8 million higher than our initial estimates, with limiting the upward guidance provision by that amount. 
I'll now spend a couple of minutes on the balance sheet. Our investment grade strategy is in full effect now that we're fully investment grade by all 3 rating agencies and we remain focused on the pillars of the strong credit profile, which include among other things, liquidity, leverage, debt maturity and interest rate exposure. 
Specific to leverage, we have reduced leverage dramatically over a period of several years, which impart drove the new investment-grade rating. And we continue to see a trend towards further reducing balance sheet leverage, inclusive of the 11 Madison acquisition. 
Looking out through 2016, given consideration to the benefits of our upcoming acquisitions and dispositions, as well as enormous EBITDA growth over that period of time, we see debt-to-EBITDA even lower in 2016, sub-8% [ph] than we would have been in 2015, even before 11 Madison acquisition. That's coupled with an improvement in all other credit metrics as a result of the significant EBITDA growth and a balanced funding strategy.
With that, I'll turn it back over to Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you for that summary. I think it really does a good job in highlighting what almost sounds like an annual December investor meeting, only it's not. It's actually just 90 days worth of effort. And I'd got to keep reminding ourselves that
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you for that summary. I think it really does a good job in highlighting what almost sounds like an annual December investor meeting, only it's not. It's actually just 90 days worth of effort. And I'd got to keep reminding ourselves that just how much we can do in 90 days. And hopefully we can do that more in the coming third quarter because we are very passionate about executing on all fronts and continuing to have sector-leading operational results. 
So with that said, let's open it up for -- what I hope is just a bunch of accolades and attaboys, but I suspect there must be some questions. We'll take some questions.

And there is the so-called balance of the strategy to use that in a way monetize everything that we're looking to do and/or do some refinancings and some JVs, which will help drive the accretion going forward and result in a set of ratios as Matt referred to earlier, not even back to where they were, but even much better going forward, which is where we want to be. So does that answer it? Or is it more to that?

componenttext: Well, I think what we've been saying is a combination of construction loan and JV equity that is something we would be leaning toward, but not necessarily committed to, because there's other options on the table that we're evaluating. And that the timing of such and all cases is probably late '16, early '17 because that's when the money spent starts. That really hasn't changed. That still the path we've been on, that path we're on as I expect we will stay on unless we come back to you if there is a change of plan.

componenttext: First, what changed obviously is 2 things. One is the velocity of leasing is much more rapid than we originally projected. Secondly, we had a couple of very large deals in the quarter that were unbudgeted, primarily Bloomberg and the 56 Street. But the pipeline, as we look forward, is very full. As Marc said, we're 278,000 square feet signed in the first three weeks of July. And my guess is by this time next year, I'll have another 40,000 square feet in the can as well. So we combine that, we look forward as to where we're going in the pipeline. the tenant demand is strong. And we knocked that out, get to a bigger number, where the market is headed and the sustainability of the market.

componenttext: Well it's a combination of both, right? We're setting a new target for ourselves based upon the performance to date. Yes, there were 2 big deals, but the velocity overall, either way, we would reset the target because the demand has been so strong. The leasing velocity has been so successful, and the pipeline is so full that, that's -- we step back, we evaluate it and that's how we came up with a bigger number.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't -- to be 400,000 feet on a 28 million square foot portfolio, that's pretty good shooting. We -- the market is strong and the vacancy rate is dropping and that's creating more competition for tenants and there are tenants who are going earlier.
componenttext: I wouldn't -- to be 400,000 feet on a 28 million square foot portfolio, that's pretty good shooting. We -- the market is strong and the vacancy rate is dropping and that's creating more competition for tenants and there are tenants who are going earlier. So that's the trajectory is positive. But I think when you step back and look at not just leasing, but I think the 16 [ph] different metrics we put on that table every December, plus or minus. And where we are, I think we're pretty much on target. We're setting a higher bar. We may not reach that $2.2 million. It really depends on how the fourth quarter shapes up because the third quarter is looking very good. If the fourth quarter remains strong, we should get to $2.2 million. if it's a little less strong, we can easily have a couple of deals trip from December to January, and then everybody is going to write oh, my God leasing is slowing. We have a big January first quarter. So I wouldn't don't read too much into unless I follow our guidance more than anything. It seems to us like it's an achievable number based on where we are today. But that means we'll have to have a pretty strong fourth quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Mark. And then the second question is probably for Matt. As you guys look at the mortgage on 280 Park, I think it matures in June of next year althought it looks to be prepayable. Is your sense that you will be fully stabilized that
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Mark. And then the second question is probably for Matt. As you guys look at the mortgage on 280 Park, I think it matures in June of next year althought it looks to be prepayable. Is your sense that you will be fully stabilized that building ahead of the maturity and then you will be refi-ing it on a fully stabilized number? Or do you think that there's a way you can refi it ahead of stabilizing REITs and so get a really good economic on a refi-ed despite meeting ahead of getting stabilized?

componenttext: So as I said the building, it is approaching, rapidly approaching stabilization. But as the maturity itself, we have starting conversations with our partner. Our maturity schedule is very modest, so it's the next big thing in line. And we'll start conversations and sort of finance it when it's appropriate.

Whether we want to incur a prepayment obviously for prices, it matures next year, there's an open period late first quarter, early second. It's a discussion for us to have with our partner.

componenttext: A few quick questions. First, I couldn't help but notice you that sold an asset in New Jersey. And given that a lot of the 7 [ph] interest in the New Jersey real estate offices were, can you walk through the underwriting the buyer made to justify $200 a foot and kind of the quality assets, et cetera?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, it's David Schonbraun. It's an asset we've gone with a partner for a couple of years. We were out and compete be development and repositioning of assets and stabilized it. I think that market has started to recover, which is why we sold it. I think
componenttext: John, it's David Schonbraun. It's an asset we've gone with a partner for a couple of years. We were out and compete be development and repositioning of assets and stabilized it. I think that market has started to recover, which is why we sold it. I think given where rates are right now, I think they can kind of finance it and expect kind of low double-digit returns, which is what they were looking for in the deal. And I think there is a market for well leased Suburban assets and I think we have to get kind of close to fuller occupancy to kind of hit that market. But once you have an asset that is now well-leased and put away, and long-term finance I think there is a strong market for it that's why you're seeing such a high [indiscernible] for it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then second, I guess, Andrew, you sold Tower 45 for $840 [ph] a foot. By our numbers Manhattan only SL Green portfolio at $115 a share is basically a $795 a square foot portfolio. Where did the Tower 45 fit in in the overall quality continue on that S
componenttext: And then second, I guess, Andrew, you sold Tower 45 for $840 [ph] a foot. By our numbers Manhattan only SL Green portfolio at $115 a share is basically a $795 a square foot portfolio. Where did the Tower 45 fit in in the overall quality continue on that SL Green?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the important metric in addition to per foot on that sale which I went through in my remarks was the sub 3/4 [ph] cap, and I would say reconsider Tower 45 probably a B+ or A- asset, where the majority of our portfolio, vast majority has been
componenttext: Well, I think the important metric in addition to per foot on that sale which I went through in my remarks was the sub 3/4 [ph] cap, and I would say reconsider Tower 45 probably a B+ or A- asset, where the majority of our portfolio, vast majority has been in Class A asset. But just in terms of nominal rents, the in place rent in Tower 45 were low 60, guys?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: In the low 60s. So when you look at those rents versus the average rents in other buildings and we'll generally evaluate buildings on a rent-to-rent basis and let those rents be the arbiter of sort of what's sort of highly desirable by location or by quality of building or otherwise. So it's sort of in the lower middle pack of the buildings we own.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Manny Korshman with Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman here with Manny. Marc, I was wondering if you could give maybe just something that's a feedback that was raised after you left Madison and the stuff you went through on the call and the booklet is helpful. But some of the concerns th
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman here with Manny. Marc, I was wondering if you could give maybe just something that's a feedback that was raised after you left Madison and the stuff you went through on the call and the booklet is helpful. But some of the concerns that were raised by investors was they're going to have a very large asset, so a big part of the balance sheet that while you're able to trade up accretively versus what you're selling today does have some flat leases and so it's a large part of the balance sheet does not going to have as much growth in call it years 3 to 10. The second being while it's being a receiver for assets you're selling, there's an element of you could have sold those assets and paid a special dividend, you can pay 80% in stocks a so you don't lever up when you do that. And then I recognized the deal wasn't a necessity for that, but the people like being able to take advantage of the sales. And the last part was competing with others that have sovereign capital and being able to beat them out using wholly-owned, effectively SL Green equity versus sovereign capital, which arguably would come at a pretty cheap cost and so maybe you could address some of those.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think 3 points. As much as I heard [indiscernible]. The first is mortgage asset that's a big part of the balance sheet that doesn't have a lot of near-term growth. I think there's a presumption made, not sure why it's made or where it comes from, tha
componenttext: So I think 3 points. As much as I heard [indiscernible]. The first is mortgage asset that's a big part of the balance sheet that doesn't have a lot of near-term growth. I think there's a presumption made, not sure why it's made or where it comes from, that we have no ability to kind of after we acquire this property, as I said earlier in my remarks, get through the period of stabilization because there is a period to finish doing work with a tenant, at which point  we will get to a valuation that's much higher than our basis just for basically getting through the period of having that income stream identified and putting the big financing in place. I wouldn't presume and I wouldn't know anyone would presume we couldn't reach an asset in 6, 12, 18 or 24 months. So when you talk about a large asset lying around the balance sheet for decades, this is SL Green, so I'm not sure -- I'm sure you dialed into the right call. We tend to not sort of buy and hold and sit on assets in perpetuity, We tend to try and buy right, capitalize right, execute. And when the moment is there, monetize the JV. This asset -- it will be closed in a series of ticks that will give us complete flexibility in a private REIT or in a JV or in a partnership or otherwise are in and name format to bring in choose to or not choose to add in comp. So I think it relates to looking out in the future, yes, we haven't made any -- we haven't given any guidance on the future, what we see on the 3 years on the books. What we have said is that the accretion, this deal will generate over the next 3 years varies between $0.15 roughly and, 2016, and I think $0.30 in 2018. So I wouldn't look beyond that because that's what are out there talking about now. If and when we ever feel this assets or any other assets, I mean 11 Madison is not unique when it comes to maximizing values and recent stabilization, if we feel we hit that with this asset, and I think it safe to assume, we probably look to monetize it in a way to create a gain, because I think any asset we sold in the company in 17 years has resulted in a gain. I don't see where this is different. Anything would be more so if we think it's a very good buy. And we wouldn't allow this or any other assets to take down the growth profile of the company over the next whatever period of time you were talking about 5, 10 or 15 years, because we do the exact opposite. I think as you have seen -- because I think we sell more than any other certainly in New York, maybe office REIT, in terms of volume of sales to kind of illuminate value and monetize and harvest. So I would -- i would kind of look at this asset as sort of on a 3 to 5-year period and then we'll always readjust from there. As you talk about the second point to lever up, again, I don't want Matt to repeat his commentary, but if you look at what's on the web for replay Matt's commentary, he talks about after the buys and sells, the debt ratios are improved. So there's no lever up, unless you're talking about in this month -- several months for it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wasn't saying lever up, I was just saying you talked about being a receiver.
componenttext: I wasn't saying lever up, I was just saying you talked about being a receiver.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I heard you say lever up, so that's what I was responding to. There's no lever up here. I mean if you measure it month-by-month, my guess is the ratios are up for August or September. But then, I don't know when the deal start to close October, November,
componenttext: I heard you say lever up, so that's what I was responding to. There's no lever up here. I mean if you measure it month-by-month, my guess is the ratios are up for August or September. But then, I don't know when the deal start to close October, November, December, that combined with our FFO projections we have for next year, lead us to a place where we believe debt-to-EBITDA will be lower than where we started and leverage ratios will be lower than where we started. So again, I don't want to -- and obviously, credit quality is way up because you compare what we sell into what we're buying at least in our eyes. And that's [indiscernible] the [indiscernible] on this management team so if we feel the credit quality is up, then that's people can differ, but I wouldn't know how the building is rock solid, the market is the best and the credit is impeccable. So we feel this credit upgrade, a leverage improvement and accretion over a 3-year period and complete flexibility up to 3 years, to figure out ways to make money on the asset in a capital markets and away. So honestly, I forget the 3rd point and write it down, I only broke those 2. If you remember it, asset again. If not, I forgot. [indiscernible]

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sovereign, Sovereign. So when you say we beat Sovereign, I'm not -- there were 4 or 5 bidders at the end of the process. It was a mixture of domestic and sovereign, REIT and non-REIT. I don't know what kind of particular insight you have at that bidding r
componenttext: Sovereign, Sovereign. So when you say we beat Sovereign, I'm not -- there were 4 or 5 bidders at the end of the process. It was a mixture of domestic and sovereign, REIT and non-REIT. I don't know what kind of particular insight you have at that bidding rate, but we think we know the bidding rate and it was a mixture, everybody was pretty much on top of the number. If the presumption is we had to bid more to get it, that assumption is wrong. We were all at least, as we understand it, right about the same number and it was when you narrow the field down to 4 or 5 people, it's already been through around it till you got to select the winner. And I think the Fed or the [indiscernible] cap is amongst some the very best and biggest names in the industry, SL Green was awarded the deal in no small part because we had preexisting relationships with both ends of the seller of the partnership. We actually had financed this building. If you recall, back in 2004, maybe? 2004, So we refinanced the delay back when tracking this asset for 3 years plus in an acquisition sense, the moment is here, we acted quickly. I think the relationships were solid, the trust and credibility was there. And when somebody -- you get that call on the contract in a 5-day period, I'm not sure every other Sovereign bidder is swift enough afoot where they can necessarily match up to our ability to do speed of execution, which I think is how we won the deal. So in terms of price, I'm not -- I don't believe price was the deciding factor at the end.

componenttextpreview: Just one question. If you were to sort of look at 11 Madison, and look at the growth profile over the next 5 or 10 years, I think there's a presumption that the asset's got grat credit but flat growth. So if you were to compare the cash NOI growth of this
componenttext: Just one question. If you were to sort of look at 11 Madison, and look at the growth profile over the next 5 or 10 years, I think there's a presumption that the asset's got grat credit but flat growth. So if you were to compare the cash NOI growth of this asset, say over 10 years and compared to the current SL Green portfolio, what does that difference look like?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Boy, that is over the mix. We have been taking it out 10 years because the amount of assumption, compared to the whole portfolio you have to bake in on the growth profile, is we look at this over 3 and 5 years it was highly accretive to the assets we were
componenttext: Boy, that is over the mix. We have been taking it out 10 years because the amount of assumption, compared to the whole portfolio you have to bake in on the growth profile, is we look at this over 3 and 5 years it was highly accretive to the assets we were selling.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe if it, the 3 to 5 years.
componenttext: Maybe if it, the 3 to 5 years.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: 3 to 5 is highly accretive. Steve, you got to look at 3.3% cap rate on the assets sold, that's what you're -- so there's got to be 130 basis points of NOI accretion in those assets in order to reach a level that 11 Madison is throwing off at Day 1. That's
componenttext: 3 to 5 is highly accretive. Steve, you got to look at 3.3% cap rate on the assets sold, that's what you're -- so there's got to be 130 basis points of NOI accretion in those assets in order to reach a level that 11 Madison is throwing off at Day 1. That's really been more of our focus. I mean Steve -- if we sold on a basis exactly as we bought and it wasn't accretive, we got nothing more than a credit upgrade, you can follow that basis. That's something we've been -- if you look at the portfolio and you I think appreciate we've been there since day 1, if you look back at that 17 years, looks at what it is today both in scale and quality and institutional nature, you get there in part by being valued at but in part it's rotating assets. I mean you have to work assets to increase quality. This is a serious, serious office building. 2.3 million feet, right out of Madison Park, with bulletproof credit. And as I said earlier, the proof will just be in the pudding down the road, we bought it well and we have the ability to monetize value out of this asset going forward. You don't -- value isn't only about the positioning. I think we do about as anybody as and we put a couple of sales on the board just now and we always do prove that, but sometimes we can make it [indiscernible] and I think we did here. I think we made a good buy and I think we monetize value. I don't know if they see this as a then, 15, 20 year old and with that, we compared to the portfolio in that sense. We look at it as achieving a lot of strategic goals for us in terms of quality and durability of cash flow and presence in that market, which is sort of I mean its an unmatched presence now, 3.5 [ph] million square feet on 2 blocks of Midtown south, with buildings that can cater to large tenants where most buildings in Midtown South can't and having not just tenants like Credit Suisse and Sony but Yelp and others that are growing tenants. And they may grow in that building and grow hopefully elsewhere in our portfolio. There's a whole host of other strategic element to this deal, the connectivity to 1 Madison, the fact now that we have Credit Suisse we nut just half of their presence in the market, but all of their presence, because I think it gives us a better opportunity to have a productive relationship with CS, controlling both ends of that, there's also sorts of stuff there. 10 years, I don't know, 3 to 5 years, highly accretive. I would assume at the end of the 3 to 5-year period, if we haven't figured out a way to further the growth trajectory, then there would be an opportunity to JV and monetize significant value.

componenttext: Operating margin are strong than we seen in several years. Was there anything in particular that drove strong margin in the quarter? Or is it simply a function of being 97% occupancy in Manhattan?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things. One, we have an outstanding management team that is always operating this portfolio at the utmost efficiency and looking at every way to make it more efficient. Whether it's utilities, fixed price contract, whatever case it might be. And then
componenttext: Two things. One, we have an outstanding management team that is always operating this portfolio at the utmost efficiency and looking at every way to make it more efficient. Whether it's utilities, fixed price contract, whatever case it might be. And then you have seasonality. This is the opposite conversation of what we're having the first quarter, margin is likely deteriorating, what's going on, I'd say seasonality, same thing as the second quarter and get to in total, ahead on a margin basis, but that is a large part due to our operations team, as much as seasonality.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Expanding in something you mentioned in response to Michael's question. I think it was the start of the mentioned getting multiple calls everyday from private bidders, foreign and domestic. So any change in the interest level in Manhattan assets the past
componenttext: Expanding in something you mentioned in response to Michael's question. I think it was the start of the mentioned getting multiple calls everyday from private bidders, foreign and domestic. So any change in the interest level in Manhattan assets the past few months, especially as you look to sell these assets by year-end? And flip side to that, is the demand strength strong that it presents more meaningful competition when you look to acquire? Or is that still far outweighed by the relationships and the speed of execution?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the market has accelerated. And the demand, we're setting new pricing levels in the sales that we're making, and in some of the comparable sales in the market. So there are just additional foreign capital, domestic capital that are out there, aggr
componenttext: I think the market has accelerated. And the demand, we're setting new pricing levels in the sales that we're making, and in some of the comparable sales in the market. So there are just additional foreign capital, domestic capital that are out there, aggressively competing on deals. And acquisitions, as we said a lot of times before and as the announcements we made, other than the 11 Madison, we don't -- most of our acquisitions are off market. They're structured deals, they're win-win deals for the sellers and for us as a buyer. And where we do compete on a deal like 11 Madison, we have to use a creativity in terms of capitalization, speed and flexibility on the contract in order to beat up the competition and the competition is fierce. But most of our work is unfortunately, done on off market for sellers that inflates us in different markets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Just quickly, the yield of preferred equity investments it's funny lower and you guided toward higher eventually. Is there any update as we would a rising rate environment that tolerates less quickly is there any impact there? Do you
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Just quickly, the yield of preferred equity investments it's funny lower and you guided toward higher eventually. Is there any update as we would a rising rate environment that tolerates less quickly is there any impact there? Do you think higher mix or anything else is going to help support deals at all?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think we're trending ahead of our guidance. We're still -- modified our guidance, so we're protecting against further tightening. But our management team again is doing a superior job in terms of being capital market delivering above market yields i
componenttext: And I think we're trending ahead of our guidance. We're still -- modified our guidance, so we're protecting against further tightening. But our management team again is doing a superior job in terms of being capital market delivering above market yields in our portfolio. So we don't expect that to change. It's a competitive business, but we have incredible market share in New York where the first call for many, many buyers and people are looking to recapitalize assets and fortunately, that has not changed.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we look at it more as in-place rents versus market rent, and that's sort of a function of its location in Midtown South where you have some extraordinary market rents. I think my answer, at least, would be likely, yes, we would do that deal in Mid
componenttext: I think we look at it more as in-place rents versus market rent, and that's sort of a function of its location in Midtown South where you have some extraordinary market rents. I think my answer, at least, would be likely, yes, we would do that deal in Midtown if the property was of equivalent quality and if you have the same discounts the market rents with the in-place rent.

componenttext: It looks like retail rent across Manhattan continue to move up in vacancy rates have also been moving up even with the prime retailer. I'm just curious if you're seeing kind of pushing back on the retail rent, and If you're feeling some of that vacancy impact and pricing on the portfolio on the retail side?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of availabilities we have, we have great activity as evidenced by the Adidas press release in the last day or 2. And we have -- we haven't -- we've avoided a lot of corridors, but there's vacancies. We don't have a lot of space available
componenttext: I think in terms of availabilities we have, we have great activity as evidenced by the Adidas press release in the last day or 2. And we have -- we haven't -- we've avoided a lot of corridors, but there's vacancies. We don't have a lot of space available on those. We're seeing the effect of the competition. I haven't heard much are seeing evidence of rents backing up much because I think generally, Landers are pretty patient and are willing to wait out vacancy in order to take advantage of then demand and it's still think overall, trend is beckoning at retail and retailers come around they get their hedge around paying higher rent because ultimately location at the end of the day. So it hasn't impacted our portfolio much.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, manage
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us, and welcome to the SL Green Realty Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC's Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measures can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's second quarter 2015 earnings.
[Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We are pleased to take you through our second quarter results which are certainly representative of an investment strategy that is paying off in the form of outside gains, and
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. We are pleased to take you through our second quarter results which are certainly representative of an investment strategy that is paying off in the form of outside gains, and an operational approach that is producing sector-leading, same-store performance. 
Accomplishments for the quarter are numerous and they are highlighted by the following: Accelerating FFO growth; outsized same-store cash NOI increase; over 1 million square feet of leasing executed in the quarter; strong occupancy gains; premium debt and preferred equity originations; and several large and strategically important acquisitions and dispositions.
I think the best way to summarize our current thoughts on the market is to look at our -- things in the context of how they will drive our future growth and build upon our portfolio of quality and liquidity. Our leasing efforts continue to benefit by having well positioned and fully redeveloped properties in Manhattan's most desirable submarkets against the backdrop of a strong local economy producing record private sector job growth and robust demand for office space.
Last year, New York city generated 54,000 new private sector jobs in the first six months, en route to 104,000 private sector jobs added for the full calendar year 2014. 
So far, in 2015, first half private sector job additions are at 62,000 jobs added, eclipsing last year's first half amount and setting the stage for the fifth consecutive year in which private sector job growth would exceed 90,000 incrementally.
These kinds of job growth statistics will produce approximately 4 million square feet of new demand annually around the city, which is the driving force behind a declining vacancy rate, which Cushman & Wakefield now pegs at 8.9% for Midtown and 6.2% for Midtown South. The city economy is growing rapidly, notwithstanding an only moderate recovery in the financial services sector, emphasizing New York's increasingly diversified business base. What's important here is not only by how much office using tenants are growing, but where they are growing. Midtown leasing has been exceptionally strong, reaching 10.5 million square feet of leasing and accounting for 94% of total Manhattan absorption in the first half. And no one in the city is better positioned to benefit from this dynamic market than us. We have leased over 1.3 million square feet through June. And for good measure, we have already signed leases for an excess of 250,000 square feet in the first 22 days of July.
As importantly, the leasing is being done at rental levels that are representative of a resurging Midtown market, and we are routinely achieving double-digit mark-to-market increases, both with expiring, same-store lease expirations. 
With over 1.5 million square feet of office leases signed in Manhattan, and another 1.1 million square feet in our current pipeline, by the way, an amount that is the highest in the last 4 quarters, we are raising our leasing guidance to 2.2 million square feet for the full calendar year, which is a self-imposed raising of the bar on the amount of leasing activity to be completed in just over the next 5 months. 
So these leasing results, the economy, the leasing backdrop, is clearly going to help drive the momentum behind the drivers of growth that we have, in great detail, stepped through back in December. And we repeat often to our tenant base and our shareholder base, stabilized office, mark-to-market, we expect to be significant and we expect that to continue through the balance of the year. Our growth portfolio is leasing at a very fast clip, as evidenced by the fact we had a dominant amount of renewal leases in the second quarter and the retail portfolio leasing continues to be strong, as evidenced by the Adidas lease we just signed, but in combination with the other retail leases signed throughout the year. 
However, another means of driving growth and increasing quality of portfolio, away from the operational metrics is through our investment strategy and the strategic rationale, which is underpinned by our purchase of 11 Madison Avenue, which was also announced during the second quarter. 11 Madison achieves a number of things for the company, some of which we put up on a deck on our website. So for those that haven't seen it, I would encourage you to pull up the 11 Madison transaction summary. But some of the highlights therein is that this represents for us another trophy asset added to SL Green's core portfolio. We are buying this property at substantially below in place escalated rents, resulting in long-term embedded growth opportunities. And we are gaining more exposure to the desirable Midtown South submarket, something that we have made a primary objective of ours, and a stated objective of ours, over the years. We will now become the dominant owner in Midtown South, with over 3.5 million square feet of properties located immediately adjacent to Madison Square Park, which we think is one of the best areas in Midtown South, plus other properties scattered throughout.
In terms of the economics of the deal, we think the deal is excellent, in terms of the going-in cap rate of 4.6%, which is much higher than almost all recent comparable trades for buildings of this quality and scope, and even buildings of lesser quality and -- and lesser duration.
And to put that in perspective, our belief is that the money to be made on 11 Madison is as much about having bought it right, and capitalizing it right, because we will be capitalizing it with a 10-year fixed-rate financing that will be sub-4% in cost. So we will have positive leverage going into this deal, with only somewhere around I think 60% -- 55%, 60% financing that will put our yields in excess of 5% cash-on-cost. And this is the kind of deal that I believe, once all the tenants are fully installed, earn through their free rent, and all the TI and capital work is completed, that is squarely a 4-cap or less asset. If you apply that kind of cap rate on a stabilized NOI, that's a $3 billion asset, which is only $1,300 a foot, which is actually not only unprecedented by Manhattan standards, it's actually lower than many comparable Midtown office trades that are priced between $1,500 and $1,800 a foot. And we think that, that -- given it's the market -- the best market, the building is not only institutional quality, but basically rebuilt, in terms of systems and redesigned specifically for the heavy use of somebody like Credit Suisse and Sony, which are very infrastructure-sensitive tenants, that this is an asset that will provide long-term earnings growth, near-term value accretion, and serve as a receiver for the sales and numerous sales that we will be either completing over the next 4 to 6 months or have already announced, backing all of that in a very tax-efficient manner into 11 Madison, to serve as a receiver with all those attributes and credit quality long-term lease durations. 
So very happy with the way this is turning out. We obviously have more work ahead of us in terms of achieving the full amount of sales from refinancings that we have highlighted within the deck that I'm referring to. But when I look at it as a transaction that sort of stands on its own just for those merits, add on top of that the fact that we expect to achieve anywhere between $0.15 near-term and $0.30 over through years of accretion, deriving from this series of integrated transactions, then I think it makes it, certainly puts it in one of the top 2 or 3 transactions I think we've been here at the company. So very happy with how this is turning out. More work to do. We'll have an update for you on the next conference call. With that, let me turn it over to Andrew Mathias.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. In addition to the 11 Madison transaction, otherwise we have an incredibly productive quarter just completed, highlighted really by 2 sales that were part of a strategic plan for the company for the year, and then sort of became part of the
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. In addition to the 11 Madison transaction, otherwise we have an incredibly productive quarter just completed, highlighted really by 2 sales that were part of a strategic plan for the company for the year, and then sort of became part of the 11 Madison funding plan as well. Tower 45 is an asset we marketed a little more than 2 years ago, and we are not satisfied with the offers we received at the time. We pulled it off the market. And Steve Durels and his team did an excellent job of leasing the building up, and the decision to put off that sale and then subsequently the contract we announced within the last couple of weeks, earned us about $100 million above the offers we had received at the time of the earlier marketing. So at $830 a foot and a sub 3.25% cap rate, this sale is a very powerful endorsement for Midtown Manhattan office values. 
Moving on to 131 Spring Street. If one wants to see the power of the retail platform from the off-market acquisition to a redevelopment of the asset and conversion of a lot of space, from stairwells, hallways and ancillary office space into prime retail space, reletting, in terms of redoing both of the anchor retail leases of the property, and then recapitalizing, 131 Spring is sort of the perfect case study for SL Green value creation. 
We created about $150 million of gross profit in the 2.5 years since we purchased the asset, with an unlevered IRR to the company of 30% and a strong potential for future outperformance due to the incentivized JV we entered into on the asset with our partner. 
Given the returns on this asset and our other investments in the market, we continue to focus heavily in the SoHo market and its growth potential and we'll talk about that a little bit more when we go through the acquisition of 110 Greene Street. But I'd tell you, Green -- SL Green's ability to buy assets right, capitalize them right and then take them to market and sell or recapitalize, taking profits, really, both these assets show just how significant the embedded gains we have in a lot of our assets are. We have dozens more assets on our balance sheet that we're sitting on like these, where we can go out and demonstrate value and put up enormous returns to shareholders. And we look forward to doing more of that in the months to come as we continue through our aggressive sales program this year. 
On the acquisition side, we are also excited to announce agreements to acquire 2 classic SL Green deals, both off market, both incredibly well located and both with enormous upside potential.
110 Greene is a great blend for us of huge retail upside and prime office and residential space, and an irreplaceable asset on one of the most desirable blocks in SoHo. This building sits a few short blocks from 131 Spring, where I just took you through our results there. And we have very high expectations for investment in this property. We think we're going to be able to do some very creative things, given that we purchased the building next door, 102 Greene, within the last 12 months and we're exploring synergies already there, it gives us quite a lot of flexibility in terms of adding value. 
And 187 Broadway is on a stretch of Broadway we're very familiar with, having completed our retail and dormitory building at 180 Broadway, which is directly across the street from 187. On 187, we have a lot of flexibility in terms of uses for this property. And our basis gives us a lot of flexibility in what we decide to do here. We're still studying all the various uses. We have maximum flexibility in terms of zoning. And we look forward to updating our shareholders as our business plan for this asset really crystallizes, what we're taking a lot of meetings with third parties in terms of the best way to maximize the value in the site.
Moving onto the structure finance book. We saw another strong quarter, with $302 million of gross originations, and a current balance on our book of $1.7 billion. Spreads continue to hold up, as volatility in CMBS has really kept a lid on overaggressive senior lending, which has kept mezzanine spreads and mezzanine advance rates stable and very comfortable for us. 
Our pipeline for the second half of the year is very healthy, and we'll continue to use the capital markets to optimize our returns on those interests we decide to retain. 
I would just, in closing, say it's been an incredibly busy summer around here. And I'd like to acknowledge the efforts of our investment and retail teams, and leasing and management and underwriting teams, in putting together really, a stunning series of transactions on the acquisition and disposition side, that we believe set us up for enormous future growth and profits.
So with that, I'll turn it over to Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. As evidenced in our reported results for the first two quarters, our operating fundamentals are very strong, as is the Manhattan market backdrop. [indiscernible]  that performance in our view of months to come, we have increased our FFO gu
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. As evidenced in our reported results for the first two quarters, our operating fundamentals are very strong, as is the Manhattan market backdrop. [indiscernible]  that performance in our view of months to come, we have increased our FFO guidance range for 2015 to $6.30 to $6.34 a share, a meaningful increase of $0.05 over the midpoint of our previous guidance range and putting us on track for growth in FFO of over 8% versus last year.
In our real estate portfolio, the velocity of leasing at rents that are at the upper end of our expectations will contribute to earnings in 2015 for even more meaningful for growth in the years to come. During the first 6 months of the year, our Manhattan office leasing volume has been brisk. Pat on the back to Steve and his team. But at SL Green, we reward outperformance by moving the goalposts, hence the increased target of 2.2 million square feet. 
On the retail side of the business, we leased almost 90,000 square feet in the first six months at an over 80% mark-to-market, and the pipeline remains robust. And not to be outdone, our Suburban leasing volume has also far outpaced our expectation, with over 400,000 square feet leased in the first six months. All of this activity drove meaningful increases in same-store lease occupancy in the second quarter, with the Manhattan portfolio near an all-time high of 97% and the Suburban portfolio north of 84%. 
Occupancy increases driving the revenue line, coupled with seasonably lower operating expenses in the second quarter, after a brutal first quarter, improved our operating margins and allowed us to achieve same-store cash NOI growth of almost 5% in the quarter. This puts us well on pace to achieve our full year same-store cash NOI growth target of at least 3.6%, sitting at 4% for just the first 6 months. 
In the category of other income, we recognized lease termination income of $7.7 million in the second quarter, including $5.8 million at 919 Third Avenue, bringing our total for the year to $8.8 million. What we have recognized so far in 2015 is consistent with what was included in our initial FFO guidance range, and is also very close to the average lease termination income that we have recorded over the last several years, which is obviously the basis for one, including guidance. 
We include lease termination income in our guidance because it is a very consistent, recurring income stream and has been for many years. Simply, the accelerated recognition of lease income that we otherwise would've received over time. More importantly, like at 919 3rd, incentive paid to termination fee is often vacating space that we are re-leasing. They're actually increasing the income we're recognizing on that same space. We often see people looking to carve out lease termination income as nonrecurring. We see that as misleading, inaccurate and understating FFO because that income stream is so consistent. 
One additional comment on the termination income that we recognized at 919 3rd, in response to some the questions that we received. No, this amount was not included in our calculation of same-store cash NOI growth of 4.9% for the quarter and 4% for the year-to-date, because it is structured to be paid out over a period of several years. 
In the debt and preferred equity portfolio, we continue to outpace our expectations with regard to the volume of originations and the yields at which we are originating product. To accomplish this, we have not relaxed our underwriting standards, gone out further on the risk curve or even left the New York City marketplace. 
Specific to yield, recall that our initial FFO guidance assume the yields on new originations of 8.5%. For the first six months, the weighted average yields that are over $400 million of net originations was north of 10%. In addition, the pace of repayments has been slower than we anticipated, all of which is contributing directly to FFO. 
Finally, we have the effect on FFO on our real estate investment activity. Our real estate transaction volume for 2015 is on track to be one of the highest for any 1 year in the company's history. Clearly, 11 Madison is the highlight of this activity. As we have outlined in the thorough presentation on our website, as well as in the 8-K, hopefully everyone has studied, the acquisition of 11 Madison at a 4, 6 cap, which will be funded primarily with $1.4 billion of long-term fixed-rate sub-4% debt, and up to 11 asset sales or recapitalizations at an average cap rate below 3.5%, is highly accretive in years to come. It is also contributory to FFO in 2015, albeit to a lesser extent given the timing of closing. More broadly, the totality of our acquisitions and dispositions for the year, versus the very modest activity we included in our initial guidance, as contributory to FFO. Based upon the price at which we are acquiring new assets, the NOI of those assets, the form of consideration paid and the timing of the acquisitions, as compared to our dispositions. We're not just upgrading the portfolio, we're doing it accretively. 
There's a lot of good news for the bottom line coming from virtually all aspects of our business, but there's one significant offset that actually kept a lid on what would have otherwise been an even larger upward guidance revision. And that could be summarized in 2 words: Transaction costs. Recall that our initial 2015 FFO guidance included transaction costs of approximately $4 million. You can see in our financials that we've actually exceeded that amount in just the first six months, and the 11 Madison deal, among others, hasn't even closed. In total, we now project third-party cost to execute our investment activity that will need to run through [indiscernible] defined FFO, for this year will be $7 million to $8 million higher than our initial estimates, with limiting the upward guidance revision by that amount. 
Now spending a couple of minutes on the balance sheet. Our investment grade strategy is in full effect. Now we're fully investment grade by all 3 rating agencies and we remain focused on the pillars of a strong credit profile, which include among other things, liquidity, leverage, debt maturities and interest rate exposure. 
Specific to leverage, we have reduced leverage dramatically over a period of several years, which in part drove the new investment-grade ratings. And we continue to see a trend towards further reducing balance sheet leverage, inclusive of the 11 Madison acquisition. 
Looking out through 2016, giving consideration to the benefits of our upcoming acquisitions and dispositions, as well as enormous EBITDA growth over that period of time, we see debt-to-EBITDA even lower in 2016, sub-8%, than we would have been in 2015, even before the 11 Madison acquisition. That's coupled with an improvement in all other credit metrics as a result of this significant EBITDA growth and a balanced funding strategy.
With that, I'll turn it back over to Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you for that summary. I think it really does a good job in highlighting what almost sounds like an annual December investor meeting, only it's not. It's actually just 90 days worth of effort. And we got to keep reminding ourselves that -
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you for that summary. I think it really does a good job in highlighting what almost sounds like an annual December investor meeting, only it's not. It's actually just 90 days worth of effort. And we got to keep reminding ourselves that -- of just how much we can do in 90 days. And hopefully we can do that more in the coming third quarter, because we are very passionate about executing on all fronts and continuing to have sector-leading operational results. 
So with that said, let's open it up for -- what I hope are just a bunch of accolades and attaboys, but I suspect there might be some questions. We'll take some questions.

componenttext: Yes. Just, I guess maybe we should at least take a shot of this one. I heard the first part of the question. The dispositions, which we put in this investment summary, will be hopefully tied up, buttoned up by end of year. And then, there is the so-called, the balance of the strategy to use that in a way to monetize everything that we're looking to do and/or do some refinancings and some JVs, which will help drive the accretion going forward and result in a set of ratios as Matt referred to earlier, not even back to where they were, but much better going forward, which is where we want to be. So does that answer it? Or is it more to that?

componenttext: Yes, no. I think that's helpful. componenttext: Well, I think what we've been saying is, a combination of construction loan and JV equity that is something we would be leaning towards, but not necessarily committed to, because there's other options on the table that we're evaluating. And that the timing of such in all cases, is probably late '16, early '17 because that's when the money spend starts. That really hasn't changed. That still the path we've been on, that path we're on, the path I expect we will stay on, unless we come back to you and tell you, there's a change of plan.

componenttext: Well, first, what changed obviously is 2 things: One is the velocity of leasing is much more rapid than we originally projected. Secondly, we had a couple of very large deals in the quarter that were unbudgeted, primarily Bloomberg and the deal on 36th Street. But the pipeline, as we look forward, is very full. As Marc said, we're 278,000 square feet signed in the first three weeks of July. And my guess is by this time next week, I'll have another 40,000 square feet in the can as well. So we combine that, we look forward as to where we're going on the pipeline. the tenant demand is strong. And we mapped that out, you get to a bigger number and feel very strong about where the market is headed and the sustainability of the market.
