headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A few quick questions. First, I couldn't help but notice you that sold an asset in New Jersey. And given that a lot of us have an interest in what New Jersey office real estate is worth, can you kind of walk through the underwriting that the buyer made to
componenttext: A few quick questions. First, I couldn't help but notice you that sold an asset in New Jersey. And given that a lot of us have an interest in what New Jersey office real estate is worth, can you kind of walk through the underwriting that the buyer made to justify $200 a foot and kind of the quality of the asset, et cetera?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, it's David Schonbraun. That's an asset that we've owned with a partner for a couple of years. We worked out a complete redevelopment and repositioning of the asset and have stabilized it. I think that market has started to recover, which is wh
componenttext: Sure, John, it's David Schonbraun. That's an asset that we've owned with a partner for a couple of years. We worked out a complete redevelopment and repositioning of the asset and have stabilized it. I think that market has started to recover, which is why we sold it. I think given where rates are right now, I think they can kind of finance it and come to really expect kind of low double-digit returns, which is what they were looking for in the deal. And I think there is a market for well leased suburban assets, and I think we have to get it to kind of close to fuller occupancy to kind of hit that market. But once you have an asset that is now well-leased and put away, and long-term financeable, I think there is a strong market for it, and that's why you're seeing such a high [indiscernible] for it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then second, I guess, Andrew, you sold Tower 45 for about $840 a foot. By our numbers, Manhattan-only SL Green portfolio at $115 a share is basically a $795 a square foot portfolio. Where did Tower 45 fit in, in the overall quality continue on
componenttext: Great. And then second, I guess, Andrew, you sold Tower 45 for about $840 a foot. By our numbers, Manhattan-only SL Green portfolio at $115 a share is basically a $795 a square foot portfolio. Where did Tower 45 fit in, in the overall quality continue on that, at SL Green?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I mean, I think the important metric in addition to per foot on that sale which I went through in my remarks was sub 3 1/4 cap, and I would say, we consider Tower 45 probably a B+, A- asset, where the majority of our portfolio, vast majority is in Cl
componenttext: Well I mean, I think the important metric in addition to per foot on that sale which I went through in my remarks was sub 3 1/4 cap, and I would say, we consider Tower 45 probably a B+, A- asset, where the majority of our portfolio, vast majority is in Class A assets. But just in terms of nominal rents, the in-place rents in Tower 45 were below 60, guys, I think?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the low 60s. So you look at those rents versus the average rents in other buildings and we'll generally evaluate buildings on a rent-to-rent basis and let those rents be the arbiter of what's sort of highly desirable by location or by quality of buildi
componenttext: In the low 60s. So you look at those rents versus the average rents in other buildings and we'll generally evaluate buildings on a rent-to-rent basis and let those rents be the arbiter of what's sort of highly desirable by location or by quality of building or otherwise. So it's sort of in the lower middle pack of the buildings we own.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Manny Korchman with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Manny Korchman with Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman here with Manny. Marc, I was wondering if you can maybe address something, that's your feedback, that was raised after you left Madison and the stuff you went through on the call and the booklet is helpful. But yet some of the concer
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman here with Manny. Marc, I was wondering if you can maybe address something, that's your feedback, that was raised after you left Madison and the stuff you went through on the call and the booklet is helpful. But yet some of the concerns that were raised by investors was, they're going to have a very large asset, so a big part of the balance sheet that while you're able to trade up accretively versus what you're selling today, does have some flat leases and so it's a large part of the balance sheet that's not going to have as much growth in, call it, years 3 to 10. The second being, while it's being a receiver for assets you're selling, there's an element of, you could have sold those assets and paid a special dividend, you can pay the 80% in stock, so you don't lever up when you do that. Then I recognized the deal wasn't a necessity for that, but I think people like being able to take advantage of the sales. And the last part was competing with others that had sovereign capital and being able to beat them out using wholly-owned, effectively SL Green equity versus sovereign capital, which arguably would come at a pretty cheap cost, and so maybe you could just address some of those.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I think, 3 points. At least as I heard, and so trying to hit all those. The first is large asset, that's a big part of the balance sheet that doesn't have a lot of near-term growth. I think there's a presumption made, not sure why it's made or wh
componenttext: Okay, so I think, 3 points. At least as I heard, and so trying to hit all those. The first is large asset, that's a big part of the balance sheet that doesn't have a lot of near-term growth. I think there's a presumption made, not sure why it's made or where it comes from, that we have no ability to kind of, after we acquire this property, as I said earlier in my remarks, get through the period of stabilization because there is a period to finish doing the work and install a tenant, at which point, I think we will get to a valuation that's much higher than our basis, just for basically getting through the period of having that income stream identified and putting the big financing in place. I wouldn't presume and I wouldn't know why anyone would presume we couldn't re-JV that asset in 6, 12, 18 or 24 months. So when you talk about a large asset lying around the balance sheet for decades, this is SL Green, so I'm not sure -- I'm sure you dialed into the right call. We tend to not just sort of buy and hold and sit on assets in perpetuity, we tend to try and buy right, capitalize right, execute. And when the moment's there, monetize our JV. This asset -- is being, it will be closed in a series of ticks that will give us complete flexibility in a private REIT or in a JV or in a partnership or otherwise, or in a tick format, to bring in any party as we choose to or not choose to, sort of at any times. So I think as it relates to looking out in the future, yes, we haven't made any -- we haven't given any guidance on the future, what we've -- beyond the 3 years that are in the books, so. What we have said is that the accretion this deal will generate over the next 3 years varies between $0.15 roughly, in 2016, I think $0.30 now in 2018. So I wouldn't look beyond that, because that's what are out there, I would say, talking about now. If and when we ever feel this asset or any other asset, I wouldn't -- I mean 11 Mad is not unique when it comes to maximizing values and reaching stabilization, if we feel we hit that with this asset, then I think it's safe to assume, we probably look to monetize it in a way to create a gain, because I think any asset we've ever sold in the company in 17 years has resulted in a gain. So I don't see where this would be different. I think this, if anything, would be even more so, because I think it's a very good buy. And we wouldn't allow this or any other asset to take down the growth profile of the company over the next, whatever period of time you were talking about, 5, 10, 15 years, because we do the exact opposite that I think as you have seen -- because I think we sell more than any other, certainly in New York, or even maybe office REIT, in terms of volume of sale to kind of illuminate value and monetize and harvest. So I would -- I would kind of look at this asset as sort of, on a 3- to 5-year period and then we'll always readjust from there. As you talk about the second point, lever up, again, I don't want Matt to repeat his commentary, but the -- if you look at what's on the web and/or replay Matt's commentary, he talks about after the buys and the sells, the debt ratios are improved. So there's no lever up, unless you're talking about an interim several months to it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wasn't saying lever up, I was just saying that, you talked about being a receiver of...
componenttext: Yes, I wasn't saying lever up, I was just saying that, you talked about being a receiver of...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I heard lever up. That's the only -- I heard you say lever up, so that's what I was responding to. There's no lever up here. This is, this will be in -- I mean if you measure it month-by-month, my guess is the ratios are up for August, September. But
componenttext:
Well I heard lever up. That's the only -- I heard you say lever up, so that's what I was responding to. There's no lever up here. This is, this will be in -- I mean if you measure it month-by-month, my guess is the ratios are up for August, September. But then, I don't know when the deal starts to close October, November, December, that, combined with the FFO projections we have for next year, lead us to a place where we believe debt-to-EBITDA will be lower than where we started, and leverage ratios will be lower than where we started. So again, I don't want to -- and obviously, credit quality is way up, because you compare what we're selling to what we're buying, at least in our eyes, and that's what -- you're -- the shareholders are betting on this management team so, if we feel the credit quality is up, then that's -- people can differ, but I wouldn't know how it's -- the building is rock solid, the market's the best and the credit is impeccable. So we feel it's a credit upgrade, a leverage improvement and accretion over a 3-year period and complete flexibility after to 3 years to figure out ways to make money on the asset in a capital market kind of way. So honestly, I forget the 3rd point, didn't write it down, I only wrote down those 2. So if you remember it, I ask again, if not, I forgot it. 
It's sovereign, sovereign. I'm sorry. Thank you, Steve. Sovereign capital. So when you say we beat sovereign, I'm not -- there were 4 or 5 bidders at the end of the process. It was a mixture of domestic and sovereign, REIT and non-REIT. I don't know what kind of particular insight, you haven't said the bidding array, but we think we know the bidding array, and it was a mixture, everybody was pretty much on top of the number. If the presumption is we had to bid more to get it, that assumption is wrong. We were all at least, as we understand it, right about the same number, and it was a matter of, when you narrow a field down to 4 or 5 people, it's already been through 1 round or 2, you got to select a winner. And I think the feather in our cap is amongst some the very best and biggest names in the industry, SL Green was awarded the deal in no small part because we had preexisting relationships with both ends of the seller, because it was a partnership. We actually had financed this building, if you recall, back in 2004, maybe? 2004, So we financed the acquisition from the Shapiro family way back when, we've been on, sort of tracking this asset for 3 years plus in an acquisition sense, the moment was here, we acted quickly. I think the relationships were solid, the trust and credibility was there. And when somebody gets -- you get that call, to go to contract in a 5-day period, I'm not sure every other sovereign or bidder is fleet enough of foot, where they can necessarily match up to our ability to do speed of execution, which I think is how we won the deal. So in terms of price, I'm not -- I don't believe price was the deciding factor at the end.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Sakwa with Evercore ISI.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one question. If you were to sort of look at 11 Madison, and look at the growth profile over the next, you want to pick 5 years or 10 years, I think there's a presumption that the asset's got great credit, but flat growth. So if you were to compare t
componenttext: Just one question. If you were to sort of look at 11 Madison, and look at the growth profile over the next, you want to pick 5 years or 10 years, I think there's a presumption that the asset's got great credit, but flat growth. So if you were to compare the cash NOI growth of this asset, say over 10 years, and compare to the current SL Green portfolio, what does that difference look like?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Boy, that is over the next -- we haven't taken it out 10 years, Steve, because the amount of assumption, to compare it to the whole portfolio, you have to bake in on the growth profile is, we looked at this over like, 3 and 5 years, and it was highly accr
componenttext: Boy, that is over the next -- we haven't taken it out 10 years, Steve, because the amount of assumption, to compare it to the whole portfolio, you have to bake in on the growth profile is, we looked at this over like, 3 and 5 years, and it was highly accretive to the assets we're selling.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, well maybe just say, 3 to 5 -- what about 3 to 5 years? Is the NOI...
componenttext: Okay, well maybe just say, 3 to 5 -- what about 3 to 5 years? Is the NOI...

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well 3 to 5, it's highly accretive. Steve, you got to look at 3.3% cap rate on the assets sold, that's what you're -- so there's got to be 130 basis points of NOI accretion in those assets in order to reach the level that 11 Madison is throwing off Day 1.
componenttext: Well 3 to 5, it's highly accretive. Steve, you got to look at 3.3% cap rate on the assets sold, that's what you're -- so there's got to be 130 basis points of NOI accretion in those assets in order to reach the level that 11 Madison is throwing off Day 1. And that's really been more of our focus. I mean, look, Steve -- you can make a, an argument that if we sold on a basis exactly as we bought, and it wasn't accretive, we got nothing more than a credit upgrade, you can justify it on that basis. And that's something we've been -- if you look at the portfolio and you I think, can appreciate this more than most because you've been there with us since Day 1, if you look back 17 years to what the portfolio looked like then, maybe and to what it is today, both in scale and quality and institutional nature, you get there in part by being an optimist in part, by value add. But in part it's rotating assets. I mean you have to rotate assets to increase quality. This is a serious, serious office building. 2.3 million feet, right on Madison Square Park, with bulletproof credit. And as I said earlier, the proof will just be in the pudding down the road, we think we bought it well, and we'll have the ability to monetize value out of this asset going forward. You don't -- value isn't only about repositioning. I mean, I think we do that about as good as anybody else and we put a couple of sales on the board just now, and we always do prove that, but sometimes you could make a good buy. And I think we did here. I think we made a good buy, and I think we'll monetize value. I don't know if I see this as a 10, 15, 20 year hold, and we didn't compare to the portfolio in that sense. We looked at it as achieving a lot of strategic goals for us, in terms of quality and durability of cash flow and presence in that market, which is sort of, I mean it's an unmatched presence now, 3.5 million square feet on 2 blocks of Midtown South, with buildings that can cater to large tenants where most buildings in Midtown South can't, and having not just tenants like Credit Suisse and Sony, but Yelp and others that are growing tenants. And they may grow in that building and they grow hopefully elsewhere in our portfolio. And there's a whole host of other strategic elements to this deal, the connectivity to 1 Madison, the fact now that we have Credit Suisse, not just, half of their presence in the market, but all of their presence, which I think gives us a better opportunity to have a productive relationship with CS, controlling both ends of that, there's all sorts of stuff there. So 10 years, don't know, 3 to 5 years, highly accretive. I would assume at the end of the 3 to 5-year period, if we haven't figured out a way to further the growth trajectory, then there would be an opportunity to JV and monetize significant value.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brendan Maiorana with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brendan Maiorana with Wells Fargo.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick one for Matt. So your operating margins, they look like they were the strongest that we've seen in several years, and was there anything particular that drove strong margin in the quarter? Or is it simply a function of being 97% occupancy in Manha
componenttext: A quick one for Matt. So your operating margins, they look like they were the strongest that we've seen in several years, and was there anything particular that drove strong margin in the quarter? Or is it simply a function of being 97% occupancy in Manhattan?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things. One, we have an outstanding management team that is always operating this portfolio at the utmost efficiency and looking at every way to make it more efficient. Whether that's utilities, fixed price contracts, whatever the case may be. And the
componenttext: Two things. One, we have an outstanding management team that is always operating this portfolio at the utmost efficiency and looking at every way to make it more efficient. Whether that's utilities, fixed price contracts, whatever the case may be. And then you have, just truly, seasonality. And this is, kind of the opposite conversation of what we're having in the first quarter, when people said, well your margins look like they deteriorated, what's going on, I said, well it's seasonality. Same thing happened in the second quarter, and gets you, in total, ahead on a margin basis, but that is in large part due to our operations team, as much as just seasonality.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vance Edelson with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vance Edelson with Morgan Stanley.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, just expanding on something you mentioned in response to Michael's question. I think it was around the start of the year that you mentioned getting multiple calls everyday from private bidders, foreign and domestic. So any change in the interest
componenttext: So first, just expanding on something you mentioned in response to Michael's question. I think it was around the start of the year that you mentioned getting multiple calls everyday from private bidders, foreign and domestic. So any change in the interest level in Manhattan assets the past few months, especially as you look to sell these assets by year-end? And flip side to that, is the demand strength strong enough that it also presents more meaningful competition when you look to acquire? Or is that still far outweighed by the relationships and the speed of execution?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, and I think the market has accelerated. And the demand-- we're setting new pricing levels in the sales that we are making, and in some of the comparable sales in the market. So there are just additional foreign capital, and domestic capital that are
componenttext: Well, and I think the market has accelerated. And the demand-- we're setting new pricing levels in the sales that we are making, and in some of the comparable sales in the market. So there are just additional foreign capital, and domestic capital that are out there, aggressively competing on deals. And acquisitions, as we said a lot of times before, and as the announcements we made, other than 11 Madison bear out, we don't -- most of our acquisitions are off market. They're structured deals, they're win-win deals for the sellers and for us as a buyer. And where we do compete on a deal like 11 Madison, we have to use our creativity in terms of capitalization, speed and flexibility on the contract in order to beat out the competition and the competition is fierce. But most of our work is, unfortunately, done on an off market basis for sellers, that's what insulates us a bit from the market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, just quickly, the yield on debt and preferred equity investments, it's slowly trending lower, and you've guided toward high single digits eventually. Is there any update as we move closer to a rising rate environment, the l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, just quickly, the yield on debt and preferred equity investments, it's slowly trending lower, and you've guided toward high single digits eventually. Is there any update as we move closer to a rising rate environment, the longer term rates aren't expected to move as quickly, so is there any impact there? And do you think a higher mezz mix or anything else is going to help support yields at all?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think we're trending ahead of our guidance. We're still -- we even modified our guidance, so we're protecting against further tightening. But our management team again is doing a superior job in terms of being fleet of foot in the capital markets a
componenttext:
Well I think we're trending ahead of our guidance. We're still -- we even modified our guidance, so we're protecting against further tightening. But our management team again is doing a superior job in terms of being fleet of foot in the capital markets and delivering sort of above market yields in our portfolio. So we don't expect that to change. It's a competitive business, but we have an incredible market share in New York where the first call for many, many buyers and people are looking to recapitalize assets and fortunately, that has not changed.
Operator, we're running a bit past time here. I know everyone has other earnings calls and we have a lot to do as well as you know. So we're going to take 2 more, hopefully quick ones, and then we'll wrap it up.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Craig Mailman with KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question comes from Craig Mailman with KeyBanc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow-up on 11 Madison. Just curious here how Midtown South kind of played into your thinking strategically, as you guys kind of look to reposition the portfolio? I guess asked another way, would you have done that deal in Midtown, same cr
componenttext: I just want to follow-up on 11 Madison. Just curious here how Midtown South kind of played into your thinking strategically, as you guys kind of look to reposition the portfolio? I guess asked another way, would you have done that deal in Midtown, same credit, same quality, same yield? Or was it -- was Midtown South that much a draw to do an acquisition of that size?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we look at it more as in-place rents versus market rents, and that's sort of a function of its location in Midtown South where you have some extraordinary market rents. I think my answer, at least, would be likely, yes, we would do that deal
componenttext: Yes, I think we look at it more as in-place rents versus market rents, and that's sort of a function of its location in Midtown South where you have some extraordinary market rents. I think my answer, at least, would be likely, yes, we would do that deal in Midtown if the property was of equivalent quality and if you have the same discount to market rents with the in-place rents.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jed Reagan with Green Street Advisors.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It looks like retail rents across Manhattan continue to move up with vacancy rates, have also been moving up even in some the prime retail areas. I'm just curious if you're seeing kind of pushing back on the retail rents, and if you're feeling some of tha
componenttext: It looks like retail rents across Manhattan continue to move up with vacancy rates, have also been moving up even in some the prime retail areas. I'm just curious if you're seeing kind of pushing back on the retail rents, and if you're feeling some of that vacancy impacting pricing power on your portfolio on the retail side?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of the availabilities we have, we have great activity, as evidenced by the Adidas lease we press released in the last day or two. And we haven't -- we've avoided a lot of the corridors, where there's vacancies. We don't have a lot of spac
componenttext:
I think in terms of the availabilities we have, we have great activity, as evidenced by the Adidas lease we press released in the last day or two. And we haven't -- we've avoided a lot of the corridors, where there's vacancies. We don't have a lot of space and -- available on those where we're seeing the effect of the competition. I haven't heard much or seen evidence of rents backing up much, because I think generally, landlords are pretty patient and are willing to wait out a vacancy in order to take advantage of tenant demand and I still think overall, the trend is towards tightening of retail and retailers come around, they get their heads around paying higher rents because ultimately the location sort of wins at the end of the day. So it hasn't impacted our portfolio much.
Okay. that's it, Operator. Thank you very much, everyone, for those that are still with us. Appreciate you taking the time listening in, and we look forward to speaking again in 3 months.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, manag
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded. 
At this time, the company would like to remind listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed in the reconciliation of the differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's third quarter 2015 earnings. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
I will now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome. Just to confirm, you're dialed into the SL Green third quarter earnings call and what a quarter it was. We had an enjoyable summer executing on 9 different disposition transactions that were part of the design and d
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome. Just to confirm, you're dialed into the SL Green third quarter earnings call and what a quarter it was. We had an enjoyable summer executing on 9 different disposition transactions that were part of the design and delivered strategy to take advantage of favorable market conditions that exist currently, reduced structural complexity where it exists and reduced overall leverage, and back fund the closing of the acquisition of 11 Madison Avenue, a $2.6 million iconic asset located on Madison Square Park and housed in the U.S. headquarters of CS and Sony. 
In total, these transactions aggregated to $1.7 billion of activity, which upon closings will generate almost $680 million of net proceeds for the company. And most importantly, the Manhattan sales, which transacted at an average cap rate of 3.3% on current cash NOI, that's less than the 3.5% cap rate bogie we had set forth to shareholders in June.
This should dispel, in my opinion for now, any notion that macro external forces have reduced or repressed the desire of international investors to covet prime Manhattan real estate assets. And a list of very recent transactions that I'll run through right now and as recent is defined as the last 3 or 4 months since the end of Q2 was the purchase of a substantial interest in the Trinity portfolio by Norgis, a Norwegian investor; a recently announced deal in excess of $5 billion to acquire the residential complex in combination with Canadian investor, Cambridge, Alliances recapitalization of 114 Fifth Avenue, with a German investor; 520 Fifth Avenue acquisition by a Chinese investor done not too long ago; 370 Lexington was purchased by a Japanese investor; and in the list of dispositions I mentioned earlier, there were 2 specific transactions that involve foreign capital.
So clearly, that market still seems to be, in our opinion, very much -- very, very much alive. And while we were busy negotiating and documenting the terms of these dispositions, we also managed to take advantage the several value opportunities, such as our acquisition of the SoHo building, at 110 Greene Street, the development assemblage of 187 Broadway and the development assemblage on the Upper East side.
I hope our shareholders will join me in extending my compliments to the men and women SL Green team that worked with urgency throughout the summer to bring about this extraordinary results.
The net result is that we will meet our funding goals for the $3 billion 2015 acquisitions, obviously, inclusive of 11 Madison, upon the sale of just one more asset, 1745 Broadway, which we have just introduced into the market and the completion of several pending refinancings.
Notwithstanding these achievements, we will continue to sell additional assets in order to accretively fund a significant pipeline of investment opportunities that we are currently working on.
We will -- we look at asset sales of the kind that we are executing right now as being the absolute, best form of equity capital to fund this opportunistic pipeline. And in looking at how the cap rate, the resulting sale cap rates relate to our portfolio and the valuation of our portfolio, interested by the fact that at a $120 a share roughly where our stock price rates today, that's an implied cap rate on Manhattan assets of 5.3%. And to sort of get right to it, if you were to value that same portfolio, Manhattan Assets, at a 4 [ph] cap rate, that would be $153 [ph] a share. And at a 3.5 [ph] cap rate, that's $173 a share. So it's not an opinion of any of per se, one way or the other. It's simply a street math that results when you apply the kind of cap rates that we routinely see, not just in the deals that we executed on during the last 3 or 4 months. But really, if you look back over the last year or 2, the kind of results we get when we put our prime stable Manhattan assets for recycling, that these are the kind of results we get time and time again. So, however, that gets digested, we wanted to bring that to light.
I want to turn now to the leasing side. And the leasing should not at all be overshadowed by the enormous volume of activity on the transactional side. But the leasing results for the quarter were once again exceptionally strong and in line with our increased goals for the year. We continue to achieve approximately 15% [ph] mark-to-market on New Manhattan office leases. And in fact, that number is higher for the same store leases we have executed during just the first three weeks of October.
So in total, we've leased 63,000 [ph] square feet in October on the first three weeks of summer, which were same-store summer, which were not. And more importantly, we have a pipeline of leasing activity totaling 1.4 million square feet, which is substantially higher than each of the last 3 quarters, I would say each of the last 3 quarters averaged about 1 million square feet of pipeline. We announced it at 1.4 million square feet of pipeline, of which 750,000 square feet of leases are either in negotiation or out for signature, mostly that's in negotiation. But as I said before, the leases in negotiation had a very, very high probability traditionally of closing. And we would hope to close most if not all of that 750,000 square feet, although not necessarily all by year-end. But that pipeline is growing, not shrinking. So I'm sure we will be asked to expound upon that activity during the Q&A portion of the call. But the takeaway, I would hope, is a vibrant piece of the market that did not take a pause during the slow and volatile summer months. 
So with that, I'm going to turn it over to Andrew Mathias who I think is going to give you a little more insight into some of this activity as well as the structured finance activities for the quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Our big announcement this quarter were the sales of our key position at 885 Avenue and our new student housing development at 33. 885 brings to a close the last of 2007, 2008 fee positions key purchased. Our returns in this program were ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Our big announcement this quarter were the sales of our key position at 885 Avenue and our new student housing development at 33. 885 brings to a close the last of 2007, 2008 fee positions key purchased. 
Our returns in this program were extraordinary, taking highly secure senior position and assets, applying appropriate fixed-rate long-term leverage and letting the positions appreciate. 885 will generate an IRR in excess of 10%, combined with over 17% IRR into Harold, and 15.5% IRR on 292 Madison. Extraordinary returns for our shareholders on AAA risk type positions.
Don't think this business line is discontinued, as we continue to actively look for additional opportunities to compliment 635 Madison Avenue and 562 Fifth Avenue in our current key portfolio. 
At 33 Beekman, on Tuesday our team joined Pace University's senior management team to cut the ribbon on what we believe to be the tallest student housing project in the country, at 382 feet. I'm very proud with our construction team for delivering this ground-up project on time and on-budget, successfully navigating the many complexities of the site. Base is thrilled and Wednesday we announced a contract to sell the assets to a foreign buyer at a very compelling cap rate of 3.9%. 
In addition to an extraordinary return on our investment, with a projected property level IRR in excess of 40%, we expect to receive promote on a deal in excess of $10 million when it closes early next year.
Needless to say, we're hard at work identifying new sites to continue this business line as well where we've had extraordinary profits in our student housing division. We expect more news on the sales fronts in the fourth quarter as we continue to take advantage of great market conditions in Manhattan.
On DPE, preferred equity, net originations slow down a bit this quarter as several repayments we anticipated rolled in over the course of the quarter. That said, we have very fulsome pipeline for the fourth quarter. And debt market dislocation, which shook things up a bit in August, is giving us an extraordinary opportunity to maintain or in some cases, even increase, retained deal on positions in that pipeline so we'd expect to close the year on target and with extraordinary profitability and high relative returns.
With that, I'd like to turn it over to Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. Our third quarter results showcase the strong performance from both our real estate net preferred equity portfolios, as well as the successful execution of our disseminated real estate disposition reinvestment strategy. Taking into consi
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. Our third quarter results showcase the strong performance from both our real estate net preferred equity portfolios, as well as the successful execution of our disseminated real estate disposition reinvestment strategy. 
Taking into consideration these results and looking ahead to the fourth quarter after just increasing guidance back in July, we're again increasing our FFO guidance range to 634 [ph] to 637 [ph] per share, putting us on track to almost 9% as of FFO growth per year. 
Looking through the third quarter results, in the real estate portfolio, the effect of the acquisition of 11 Madison on August 18 and 110 Greene Street at the end of July contributed to an increase in several line items on the income statement as well as cash NOI, partially offset by the sale of an interest in 131, 137 Spring Street on August 4. 
Excluding the effect of these transactions, our property operating results continue to see the benefit of increasing portfolio occupancy in Manhattan, which now stands at over 97% on a lease basis with same-store portfolio and mark-to-market in excess of our expectations, coupled with the continued containment of operating expenses. 
The historically operating expenses are much higher in the third quarter than they are in the second, and that is what we saw, again, this year with a much more modest increase than expected. All these factors contribution to same-store NOI growth of 4.6% through the first 9 months and put us on a past to end the year well ahead our goal of 3.6%.
The debt and preferred equity portfolio, the balance decreased to $1.5 million as we received repayments totaling $262 million during the quarter, which was consistent with our expectations. As Andrew outlined we have significant pipeline of originations for the fourth quarter at yields that exceeds the 8.5% [ph] we expected to achieve 2015. This pipeline of activity, which is weighted towards back half of the quarter, will bring our portfolio balance to between $1.7 billion and $1.8 billion by the end of the year with the overall portfolio yields remaining over 10%. 
In other income, the FFO from our real estate investment preferred equity portfolio was complemented by a $5 million reduction in by the overall portfolio yield. This benefit comes as a result of enormous amount of our analysis review the cost structure between our ERS and operating partnership, including reimbursement of corporate overhead by the CRS. As you all know, we are very focused on operating efficiencies through tax structuring and strategy and everything we do. So kudos to our tax director for his efforts in this regard. 
Also included in other income during the quarter was the recognition of lease termination payments totaling about $4 million. As we have said in the past, we don't view lease termination as nonrecurring, which historically recognized some level of lease termination income every quarter. This is simply the accelerated recognition of lease income that we otherwise would have received over time. 
On the expense side, given all of our investment activity during the quarter highlighted by the acquisitions of 11 Madison and 123, we recognized a significant amount of transaction costs somewhat more than we anticipated. As always, we are conservative in our view of transaction cost given that we are so active. And that conservatism remains to be ahead into the fourth quarter with a full pipeline of activity ahead.
All things considered, we are very pleased to be raising guidance for the second consecutive quarter. I think we are set up very nicely ahead for 2016. We're excited for the quarters ahead and we look forward to unveiling our 2016 earnings guidance in early December. 
In that regard before turning it back to Marc, I want to remind everyone that our 18th Annual Investor Conference is being held on December 7 in New York City. It is hard to believe that we're holding this now for 18 years. It's a full day event, chock-full of information and may be a bit of entertainment. Invitations will be going out in the next couple of weeks. If you like more information in the meantime, please email us. The email addresses in our press release, it's slg2015@slgreen.com. 
With that, back to Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Matt. And we're going to open it up for Q&A. I just want to echo Matt's sentiments that we certainly hope everyone listening in will be able to make it to the shareholder event in December, and that's where we're going to really get into
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Matt. And we're going to open it up for Q&A. I just want to echo Matt's sentiments that we certainly hope everyone listening in will be able to make it to the shareholder event in December, and that's where we're going to really get into not so much a review of the past, but really a look forward to 2016 [ph] because we are extremely excited as we are sitting here now about the development opportunities, embedded growth within the portfolios and the -- all the other things that we have lined that we'll be ready to talk you about in 2016. So I look forward to seeing you in December. And with that, we'll open it up to Q&A.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the structured finance book? In particular, it sounds like a pretty bullish about potential originations here stemming from some of the turmoils in the fixed income markets. But I'm curious how you think about whether what'
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the structured finance book? In particular, it sounds like a pretty bullish about potential originations here stemming from some of the turmoils in the fixed income markets. But I'm curious how you think about whether what's going on in the fixed income market has been a bit of a canary in the coal mine. And perhaps you can use this opportunity to let some of the portfolio roll off and do you risk that part of the business, how do you balance those 2 views?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's more of an opportunity to get better risk-adjusted returns, which means either charging more for capital at a similar position on the capital structure, or taking the opportunity to move more senior in the capital structure and charge fo
componenttext: Yes, I think it's more of an opportunity to get better risk-adjusted returns, which means either charging more for capital at a similar position on the capital structure, or taking the opportunity to move more senior in the capital structure and charge for the same as we are previously getting for new. We have quite a bit of dislocation in the CMBS market in August. And every time there's kind of dislocation, we find extraordinary opportunity sort of shaking out capital structures that are short proceeds because people get carved back in the CMBS market. So I think it's less, we do it in a less time to pause and more time to take advantage, but make sure that we're increasing our risk-adjusted returns at sort of whatever portion of the capital structure we're lending at.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm going to let Nick ask our second question.
componenttext: Okay. I'm going to let Nick ask our second question.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you tell us a little bit more about New York City. Where do you think the overall market is right now for rent growth? I mean, it's sort of a debate whether it's 5%, whether it's lower than that, whether it's 10% for the best buildings. Maybe
componenttext: I was hoping you tell us a little bit more about New York City. Where do you think the overall market is right now for rent growth? I mean, it's sort of a debate whether it's 5%, whether it's lower than that, whether it's 10% for the best buildings. Maybe you can talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the market for rent growth and how it's trending this year and how you think it might move into next year in the overall market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well you can slice and dice it in 20 different ways. The quality of the building, submarket, base power, the sizes of tenant requirement and the profile of the requirement itself. I would say, generally speaking, and let's sort of focus on Midtown because
componenttext: Well you can slice and dice it in 20 different ways. The quality of the building, submarket, base power, the sizes of tenant requirement and the profile of the requirement itself. I would say, generally speaking, and let's sort of focus on Midtown because Midtown has been extremely active this year. The rent growth this year has been strong across the board. We haven't really seen any let up in demand on whether it's the bottom or the top or price-sensitive versus the high price point product. I would say that overall midtown has got more opportunity for rent growth than Midtown South, at least in the near-term because there's more inventory available. And the demand is going to follow where the supply is. And there's a lot of -- we see a lot of velocity in deals in the pipeline for Midtown right now. So to put a number on it, between now and 12 months from now, I'd be very surprised if we didn't see at least 7% to 8% of rent growth.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Manny Corchman of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Manny Corchman of Citi.

And I'm just wondering if you can share or perhaps Andrew can share sort of what does that encompass, in terms of sizing, but also the types of deals that we should be expecting from this pipeline?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- I mean, I don't want to completely give it away. So we generically describe it as this kind of stuff we didn't buy to some extent. So it's a mixture of high-quality office and more opportunistic, mixed-use, meaning they're resi retai
componenttext: Well, I think that -- I mean, I don't want to completely give it away. So we generically describe it as this kind of stuff we didn't buy to some extent. So it's a mixture of high-quality office and more opportunistic, mixed-use, meaning they're resi retail or office retail products in some of the Midtown South market. So I think it's a combination of those 2 types of profiles. That's just on the equity portion, not speaking to the structured finance pipeline, which Andrew spoke to separately or can add more commentary to separately. I'm just talking about the opportunities that we are working on currently that is being set up with the right process and the right pricing could result in some additional acquisitions over the next 3 or 5 months.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just add, Michael, and if you look at 110 Greene, 187 Broadway, the 2 transactions that we announced in the quarter, those are completely off market. Never marketed one-on-one negotiations and structured deals where we were able to deliver the sel
componenttext: I would just add, Michael, and if you look at 110 Greene, 187 Broadway, the 2 transactions that we announced in the quarter, those are completely off market. Never marketed one-on-one negotiations and structured deals where we were able to deliver the seller equivalent or more in net proceeds without them going and taking a full cash price for the market. We're still seeing those types of opportunities as sort of we always have. They're just -- they're longer lead time and they mature as they're ready without the pressure of the marketed process. So we still do have a lot of those types of deals in the pipeline.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Manny here with Michael. If we look at the 885 third [ph] deal. Can you just close in and say how that was structured, why there's such a big equity component? And on the preferred, if you could just give us the term and the rate?
componenttext: It's Manny here with Michael. If we look at the 885 third [ph] deal. Can you just close in and say how that was structured, why there's such a big equity component? And on the preferred, if you could just give us the term and the rate?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean I think -- the preferred equity term is 5 years. The rate will wind up being the high 5% range. And I think -- our thinking there was the structure contains a lot of variability in 2020. And part of the motivation for selling the asset now wa
componenttext: Sure. I mean I think -- the preferred equity term is 5 years. The rate will wind up being the high 5% range. And I think -- our thinking there was the structure contains a lot of variability in 2020. And part of the motivation for selling the asset now was to have certainty as opposed to that variability of outcome in 2020. So us providing the preferred would have allowed us to get a good cash return in the interim and not be sort of first in line depending on what happens with the asset in 2020.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

Can you give us some views on how you see that space particularly as it relates to tenant credit and venture funding and how you guys think about that right now?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you got to remember, Tony, we -- I don't have the number in front of me. I'm going to guess we have 5% or less exposure to pure tax tenant. And certainly, the type of TAMI tenant you're talking about, with the credit concern tenets, are a very small
componenttext: Well, you got to remember, Tony, we -- I don't have the number in front of me. I'm going to guess we have 5% or less exposure to pure tax tenant. And certainly, the type of TAMI tenant you're talking about, with the credit concern tenets, are a very small portion of the portfolio. And traditionally, we've had very little loss in that segment, even when there were time to distress back in 2000, 2001 et cetera. So I think that the way we think about it is kind of the way we run the business, which is oriented towards companies that are largely investment-grade established bigger companies. We have made some investments in the Midtown South area, like 635, 646. But even in that building, which has a fair amount of tech tenants, they're all very high-quality, like In 4, Microsoft, and who else do we have there? Yelp. I don't know that, that doesn't raise any red flags for us on the credit side of things. I think we've sold properties in the past where we felt there were some credit exposures to try and head off what may be coming down the pipe. But I would simply say that just look at the supplemental with the disclosure of our tenant profile and you'll see that regardless of how that market developed over time and there's always going to be ups and downs and what's essentially a cyclical and emerging kind of industry. I don't see that having any impact, any material impact, on the portfolio as it has in years past.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a very small fraction of the 5% tech Marc referred to is an all reliant venture funding, which I think is 81% [ph] almost, I mean, 1% of the 5% may be. Not 20% of the 5%. I don't think venture funding at all is relevant to our tenant, whatsoever.
componenttext: I think a very small fraction of the 5% tech Marc referred to is an all reliant venture funding, which I think is 81% [ph] almost, I mean, 1% of the 5% may be. Not 20% of the 5%. I don't think venture funding at all is relevant to our tenant, whatsoever. Tech tenants we have our large public tenants. And we took a measure this quarter to sell the 36th Street asset, which had an exposure to venture funded type tenant.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. My second question on One Vanderbilt. Can you give us a sense as to how you think about depth of market for tenants at that price point? I think there are some other product going up at a fairly similarly high price point. And then you have sort
componenttext: Got you. My second question on One Vanderbilt. Can you give us a sense as to how you think about depth of market for tenants at that price point? I think there are some other product going up at a fairly similarly high price point. And then you have sort of the alternative of the West side or downtown at a much lower and new construction price point focus. So as you guys move forward with that project, how do you think about just the pot out there that you can go get that price point?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tony. I think we're going to go through that in an extensive amount of detail in December. And I would sort of urge you to wait till then to hear from Steve and some of the brokers we have working on the deal. We'll take you through the building, the
componenttext: Yes, Tony. I think we're going to go through that in an extensive amount of detail in December. And I would sort of urge you to wait till then to hear from Steve and some of the brokers we have working on the deal. We'll take you through the building, the special aspects of the way it's designed, the way it's [indiscernible]. The kind of tenants it will appeal to, the way in which we are marketing, we'll begin marketing that building. It really, I think, when you say there's other buildings going up of a similar is really almost none. So maybe 425 Park, that already the majority is anchored and what's left is very small 4 [ph] plate. So I actually don't know anything that is going up that we'll be delivering in 2020 that I would call competitive product in a AAA location. And the tenants that we'll be looking for large blocks of uses between 500,000 and 1 million square feet and over on the West side really don't really answer even our target market for the most part, because we see this building likely being tenanted by tenants ranging anywhere from 50,000 feet to 250,000 feet, looking for very high end, very highly amenitized, very well designed, very well located, brand-new office space, with views that are sort of unparalleled in Midtown because of the height of the building. I don't think there's a lot of competition. That doesn't mean we don't have to think long and hard about who is that tenant base and how we can attack them. And that will go into in great detail in December. But suffice it to say, the reception to the building in the tenant community so far has been excellent. And if anything, given that it's only 2015, we're talking about occupancy in 2021, 2020 possession dates for occupancy in 2020 [ph], 2021 [ph] for tenants in that 50,000 to 250,000 [ph] square foot range, it's a little early, which I think is obvious, but I just wanted to state that. But the reception, generally, has been excellent. And I don't think the price points we have established for the building are going to be a resistance level for these types of tenants.

componenttext: With only 2 months left to guard at the end of the year is pretty solid at this point. A lot of what we reported in the third quarter was expected ups downs and otherwise slightly ahead on a handful of things that put us in a position of generally increased sequentially 2 quarters, unless outperformance and there has been. But by and large, this stuff we saw in the third quarter with a lot of expectations, a lot of the leasing momentum we have when we say we're excited about 2016, now that's really going to have an impact in '16 and beyond, not for the last 2 months, 3 months of the year.

componenttext: Financial services, what was missing in the last conversation was it's not so much where TAMI is although that was historical last year. The difference this year if the financial services has been the driver of leasing activity across the Manhattan market. Certainly within our pipeline, we've got leases out 100,000 square feet of that is financial services related. And in the term sheet stage, we got almost 300,000 square feet of the deals stemming with financial service type tenants. So strong demand there. The other driver, health there continues to be a big push in Manhattan. So does education, the administrative side of education. We're seeing large leases on the pipeline coming off that as well.

componenttext: Had a couple of questions on retail. This period you signed a high rent deal at 125 Park Avenue. Can you provide some color on the type of tenant you signed there, whether this was a conversion space? And if it was conversion space, how many opportunities do you have to convert office or lobby into retail?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess at 125 Park I think we signed 2 deals this quarter. Hayworth, which is the showroom tenant on the ground and second floor, and we did convert a bunch of basement and storage space into retail, combined with a unit on the first floor and signed a m
componenttext:
I guess at 125 Park I think we signed 2 deals this quarter. Hayworth, which is the showroom tenant on the ground and second floor, and we did convert a bunch of basement and storage space into retail, combined with a unit on the first floor and signed a major fitness operator into the space open gym.
So I think that is very indicative of the work day and the retail group is doing, diligence and the assets we owned in addition to the assets we're purchasing to try to find areas where we can expand the retail footprint and convert lower revenue generating space into higher revenue generating space. So there is a lot more of opportunity in the portfolio.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have an estimate of how much that might be?
componenttext: Do you have an estimate of how much that might be?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have put up a slide in December. That will have to be modified because some of the leasing that has taken place this year. But the slide in December I recall was something like $160 million of incremental NOI over the next 5 years, our share, that repr
componenttext: We have put up a slide in December. That will have to be modified because some of the leasing that has taken place this year. But the slide in December I recall was something like $160 million of incremental NOI over the next 5 years, our share, that represents our share, coming strictly from retail assets. Now in that regard, there's been some retail leasing but we've added retail assets. So we have to do that reconciliation for you in December. But suffice it to say, it's enormous. I look at that number as coming from the retail, which is not a segment of business we have a lot of capital devoted to like we do on the office sector, much more capital devoted there. So pound for pound, that kind of NOI lift over the next 5 years, coming from that segment, is enormous. But like I said, we don't -- I can't tell you at the moment the kind of NOI expectation we have from retail over the next 5 years. We will have that for you in December.

componenttext: About 100%. So I think its fair to say on average, there are some properties we have in local prime, prime retail segment, where rents may be marking 200%, 300%, 400% literally to market. And then there's other aspects, which are 20%, 30%, 40%. But on average, at least as of last December, it was about 100%. And as Andrew said, we're not -- we have not reduced retail rents, I don't think anywhere in the portfolio. Do you see it anywhere? So it has to be solely mixed or the occupancy that is coming up in any given year, some has higher mark-to-market, some slower. But again, I would look at it more portfolio basis as opposed to any individual quarter of a year. And on that basis, about 100% embedded growth.

componenttext: Matt just a quick one for you. When we do think about the sources and uses of funds over the next few quarters, again, the slight GAAP you have left to fully fund 11 Madison, can you tell me how large that is and whether you expect on that to come from the debt refinancing that you're talking about? headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: So Marc talked about incremental assets there over and above 17 45 [ph] as being sources of capital for other accretive opportunities just speaking to what we like to call the 11 Madison rubric, the totality of the acquisition and the sales that got fed into it. 5% [ph] of 17 45 [ph], the sales have all been completed as in our plan. So that leaves us with financings and refinancings that are in process that generate incremental capital to the program.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And just to expand on that. In June, we put up a presentation, which showed a funding plan for 11 Madison, but also for $400 million of additional acquisitions. We are about $200 million of equity of that $400 million. So that we will sell more ass
componenttext: Right. And just to expand on that. In June, we put up a presentation, which showed a funding plan for 11 Madison, but also for $400 million of additional acquisitions. We are about $200 million of equity of that $400 million. So that we will sell more assets likely beyond 1745 [ph] as I've mentioned earlier. And those will go to fund those incremental acquisitions to fill out $200 million and then possibly beyond that as well because we'll go beyond. But if the question is just to close out the 11 Madison, I think what I said earlier was 1745 [ph] plus the refinancings closes out 11 [ph].

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as for the delivery end, Taio, we closed 11, you see corporate liquidity and corporate facilities. So now with every sale that we consummate, that will go down to as part of the [indiscernible] we'll go back to pay to repay those facilities taking a l
componenttext: And as for the delivery end, Taio, we closed 11, you see corporate liquidity and corporate facilities. So now with every sale that we consummate, that will go down to as part of the [indiscernible] we'll go back to pay to repay those facilities taking a leverage back down.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: But if you look at where we started the year and where we finished at the end of consummating all these transactions, all of our leverage ratios, based on 2015 EBITDA is, right back in line. And then in '16 it improves as we expect 2016 EBITDA to exceed 2
componenttext: But if you look at where we started the year and where we finished at the end of consummating all these transactions, all of our leverage ratios, based on 2015 EBITDA is, right back in line. And then in '16 it improves as we expect 2016 EBITDA to exceed 2015 EBITDA, so we should have improvement in all those ratios, notwithstanding the enormous activity, the enormous acquisition that we were able to achieve by ourselves with our partner, without issuing a common equity. And obviously, as markets improve, the ATM becomes an option down the road, but clearly, at the levels we've experienced, we've been relying solely on the asset sales and that's proven to be an excellent strategy, we think.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Just focusing on the leasing pipeline. Can you talk about how much of that pipeline is new versus renewal? And then also maybe break it out into the different sizes you're seeing? I know you mentioned there's a couple 100,000 square foot potential financial service users. And then just thinking about the different corridors, are you seeing more demand for Park Avenue, 6th Avenue, Midtown South?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Of the leases that are out, the majority of it is new deals. In the pipeline of deals that are being negotiated, it's probably sort of 50-50. As far as location, the majority of deals we're working on are all Midtown, I mean it's not only spread downtown
componenttext: Of the leases that are out, the majority of it is new deals. In the pipeline of deals that are being negotiated, it's probably sort of 50-50. As far as location, the majority of deals we're working on are all Midtown, I mean it's not only spread downtown or Midtown South, but the majority of it is Midtown. And what's interesting is that a good chunk of, I would say, a very large percentage of the deals that we are working on, both in pipeline and/or leases that are out, are for spaces that are becoming available for 2017, whether those are early renewals or whether they're forward commitments for space that we know we're getting back in 2017. So that's where a lot of our attention is right now. We have very good visibility, obviously, through the end of this year and for most of 2016 [ph]. But we've got a good deal of roll on '17. And the good news on that is we've got some very large deals in the pipeline that are going to [indiscernible] off the board.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you seeing any shifts in terms of the different avenues or parts of Midtown where people want to be or what they're willing to pay now that you've signed a Bloomberg deal earlier this year in Fifth Avenue?
componenttext: Okay. And are you seeing any shifts in terms of the different avenues or parts of Midtown where people want to be or what they're willing to pay now that you've signed a Bloomberg deal earlier this year in Fifth Avenue?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Park Avenue, this is the rents are up but the supplies are down. Park Avenue has the lowest availability Midtown, right around Grand Central compared to a year ago. There's been a lot of leasing velocity in the Grand Central submarket. But I really ca
componenttext: No, Park Avenue, this is the rents are up but the supplies are down. Park Avenue has the lowest availability Midtown, right around Grand Central compared to a year ago. There's been a lot of leasing velocity in the Grand Central submarket. But I really can't  point you to say that the demand is focused on one avenue, one submarket or one size or type of tenant. Interesting to note that 2 years ago, we would have been talking about how Third Avenue had a low supply. Now it doesn't, Third Avenue return to historical norm as far as availability. And if you take our availability on 711 Third Avenue with a number of deals that we're negotiating, the rent there, which is probably our most commodity-like building where you would think it's the sort of weakest part of the supply growth, we're seeing a good $10 increase on rents on a number of the deals that we're negotiating today versus where we would have been a year ago.

componenttext: Alex, it's a fee position. It's not -- you've only got like half the equation. There's a leasehold behind the fee. We own the fee. We traded the fee. This is like -- I would equate it to almost a AAA bond. [indiscernible]

This is a very secure fee asset with a lot of subordinate equity below it in the form of a long-term operating leasehold position owned by foreign, foreign entities and that are institutional in nature. componenttextpreview: I would look at it more as a low leverage mortgage fund we traded. A testament to aggregate. We structured 3 of these deals back in, I think, it was 2005 [ph] 2006 [ph], 2007 [ph]. 292 Madison, 2 Harold, 885 where we took kind of low LTV fee position and
componenttext: I would look at it more as a low leverage mortgage fund we traded. A testament to aggregate. We structured 3 of these deals back in, I think, it was 2005 [ph] 2006 [ph], 2007 [ph]. 292 Madison, 2 Harold, 885 where we took kind of low LTV fee position and gave out of the money purchase options that I think were generally 10 or 15 years forward. So 2 of those deals we fully resolved. We made I think a very significant on 2 Harold and 292. Now this deal upon closing fully resolved we will have achieved essentially a 10% to 10.5% IRR on what I look at essentially as a AAA bond position.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: I would expect our hold positions to be more on the overall average of our book in the 9%, 10% range. And they're just -- it's just reflective of the fact we have put more mortgage on the books syndicated portion of the deal.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: They're again, I would like to raise the point when you're talking about 10%. For earnings purposes, we modeled 8.5%, not 10%. But in a world that's a big difference. So we have been achieving 10% because we've been outperforming our projections. Our targ
componenttext: They're again, I would like to raise the point when you're talking about 10%. For earnings purposes, we modeled 8.5%, not 10%. But in a world that's a big difference. So we have been achieving 10% because we've been outperforming our projections. Our target just over the same page is not 10%, let's say guidance it indicates 8.5%, on a blended basis between whatever the profile book of mortgage for the debt has been Andrew is saying likely to continue. And if it does, then we should meet or exceed 8.5%, hopefully 10%. But I just wouldn't -- I would caution you on using that as sort of your target.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we've been running a captive insurance for a decade now. And part of that we have access for the Federal Home Loan Bank, which provides us very efficient capital to finance some of our structure positions list, so we are going to take advant
componenttext: Look, I think we've been running a captive insurance for a decade now. And part of that we have access for the Federal Home Loan Bank, which provides us very efficient capital to finance some of our structure positions list, so we are going to take advantage of it and it allows us to instead of selling A notes for senior positions and finance them and have higher retained yields. So we may do more of it later. But it's a big advantage for us on a go-forward basis.

componenttext: We always on equity type deals, we always pinpoint unlevered returns. This type of investment where we don't have the operating position. And it has a stated yield to take out 2020, we look at strictly as a structured investment akin to something that we'll be able in the BP portfolio and we're looking at IRR's on cash out the door. So the 10.5% I think IRR is equivalent to essentially like a 10.5% we achieved on an investment BPE. It just happens to be not BPE, it happens to be a structure [indiscernible] and levered by a kind of a low rate, low advanced rate, first mortgage.

componenttextpreview: We're telling our guys it's not nearly enough. So I don't know. There's a lot of square footage between 97 [ph] and 100 [ph]. So yes, the answer is no. Pockets of vacancy we're not happy it exists. We're attacking those. It won't be as diminishing. We've
componenttext: We're telling our guys it's not nearly enough. So I don't know. There's a lot of square footage between 97 [ph] and 100 [ph]. So yes, the answer is no. Pockets of vacancy we're not happy it exists. We're attacking those. It won't be as diminishing. We've acquired new vacancy that's not in the same-store portfolio like 46 [ph]. And the let's hear it for the first three transactions. I mean things have got a little lost today, but that was a great inaugural deal that 46 building the tenant, the terms, we're happy to tick that building off successfully with that rent. We've got a lot of good looking pre-builds that are basically done deals. Two weeks away from done and we hope and expect when those pre-builds are done, that they will be hot commodities in a very good building. So I think there's still an upside within that portfolio. But the upside really isn't just leasing up a vacant space. I mean, we've got a lot of development pipeline. We've got the vacant space pipeline in the growth portfolio that is not in the same-store. And we've got big, big mark-to-market in the office portfolio and that massive in the retail portfolio. I don't think we're suffering from a lack of areas to identify for where their growth is coming from, which is why I think we're very, very optimistic about their we're headed for 2016 [ph].

componenttext: I think we're covered in December. Right now, the focus for us for the past 4, 5 months has been on executing a very deliberate plan that we put forth in June. We're at the tail end of that. We are now putting in place our new plan, if you will, for the next batch of investments that we've been mining in particular coming to fruition, and how best we're going to fund those and from, which assess we're going to be selling or capital we're going to be raising in the form of JV equity, the capital raised in today's environment that we look at as an alternative to selling assets and JV of new assets. We've -- we like very much what we bought this year, so we didn't JV, I think, any of that product, right? I mean SoHo has JV but we didn't take any partners there or 11 Madison or on 187 or the Eastside portfolio. So we can always use that, the ability to access private equity, the partnership as a means of moderating what we sell or don't sell from those kind of deals. So that hasn't been decided nor does it need to be at this point. But we'll be over the next 3 to 5 months as we execute on those opportunities.
