headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded.At this time, the company would like to remind our listeners that during the call, ma
componenttext:
Thank you, everybody, for joining us and welcome to SL Green Realty Corp.'s Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. This conference call is being recorded.
At this time, the company would like to remind our listeners that during the call, management may make forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ from the forward-looking statements that management may make today. Additional information regarding the factors that could cause such differences appear in the MD&A section of the company's Form 10-K and other reports filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Also during today's conference call, the company may discuss non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC Regulation G. The GAAP financial measures most directly comparable to each non-GAAP financial measure discussed and the reconciliation of each differences between each non-GAAP financial measure and the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found on the company's website at www.slgreen.com by selecting the press release regarding the company's third quarter 2015 earnings. 
Before turning the call over to Marc Holliday, Chief Executive Officer of SL Green Realty Corp. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'll now turn the call over to Marc Holliday. Please go ahead, Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome. Just to confirm, you're dialed into the SL Green third quarter earnings call and what a quarter it was. We had an enjoyable summer executing on 9 different disposition transactions that were part of a designed and d
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome. Just to confirm, you're dialed into the SL Green third quarter earnings call and what a quarter it was. We had an enjoyable summer executing on 9 different disposition transactions that were part of a designed and deliberate strategy to take advantage of favorable market conditions that exist currently, reduce structural complexity where it exists and reduce overall leverage, and back fund the closing of the acquisition of 11 Madison Avenue, a $2.6 billion iconic asset located on Madison Square Park and housing in the U.S. headquarters of CS and Sony.
In total, these transactions aggregated to $1.7 billion of activity, which upon closings will generate almost $680 million of net proceeds for the company. And most importantly, the Manhattan sales, which transacted at an average cap rate of 3.3% on current cash NOI, that's less than the 3.5% cap rate bogie we had set forth to shareholders in June.
This should dispel, in my opinion, for now, any notion that macro external forces have reduced or repressed the desire of international investors to covet prime Manhattan real estate assets. And a list of very recent transactions that I'll run through right now and this recent is defined as the last 3 or 4 months since the end of Q2, was the purchase of a substantial interest in the Trinity portfolio by Norges, a Norwegian investor; a recently announced deal in excess of $5 billion to acquire the Stuy Town residential complex in combination with Canadian investor, Ivanhoé Cambridge, Alliances recapitalization of 114 Fifth Avenue, with German investor; 520 Fifth Avenue acquisition by a Chinese investor done not too long ago; 370 Lexington was purchased by a Japanese investor; and in the list of dispositions I mentioned earlier, there were 2 specific transactions that involve foreign capital.
So clearly, that market still seems to be, in our opinion, very much -- very, very much alive. And while we were busy negotiating and documenting the terms of these dispositions, we also managed to take advantage the several value opportunities, such as our acquisition of the SoHo building, at 110 Greene Street, the development assemblage of 187 Broadway and the development assemblage on the Upper East side.
I hope our shareholders will join me in extending my compliments to the men and women on the SL Green team that worked with urgency throughout the summer to bring about this extraordinary results.
The net result is that we will meet our funding goals for the $3 billion 2015 acquisitions, obviously, inclusive of 11 Madison, upon the sale of just one more asset, 1745 Broadway, which we have just introduced into the market and the completion of several pending refinancings.
Notwithstanding these achievements, we will continue to sell additional assets in order to accretively fund a significant pipeline of investment opportunities that we are currently working on.
We will -- we look at asset sales of the kind that we are executing right now as being the absolute, best form of equity capital to fund this opportunistic pipeline. And in looking at how the cap rate, the resulting sale cap rates relate to our portfolio and the valuation of our portfolio, [indiscernible] interested by the fact that at a $120 a share roughly where our stock price trades today, that's an implied cap rate on Manhattan assets of 5.3%. And to sort of get right through it, if you were to value that same portfolio, Manhattan Assets, at a 4 cap rate, that would be $153 a share. And at a 3.5 cap rate, that's $173 a share. So it's not an opinion of NAV per se. One way or the other, it's simply a straight math that results when you apply the kind of cap rates that we routinely see, not just in the deals that we've executed on during the last 3 or 4 months. But really, if you look back over the last year or 2, the kind of results we get when we put our prime stable Manhattan assets for recycling, these are the kind of results we get time and time again. So, however, that gets digested, we wanted to bring that to light.
I want to turn now to the leasing side. And the leasing should not at all be overshadowed by the enormous volume of activity on the transactional side. Because the leasing results for the quarter were once again exceptionally strong and in line with our increased goals for the year. We continue to achieve approximately 15% mark-to-market on New Manhattan office leases. And in fact, that number is higher for the same store leases we have executed during just the first three weeks of October.
So in total, we've leased 63,000 square feet in October in the first three weeks some of which were same-store some, which were not. And more importantly, we have a pipeline of leasing activity totaling 1.4 million square feet, which is substantially higher than each of the last 3 quarters, I would say each of the last 3 quarters averaged about 1 million square feet of pipeline. We announced it at 1.4 million square feet of pipeline, of which 750,000 square feet of leases are either in negotiation or out for signature, mostly that's in negotiation. But as I've said before, the leases in negotiation have a very, very high probability traditionally of closing. And we would hope to close most, if not all of that 750,000 square feet, although not necessarily all by year-end. But that pipeline is growing, not shrinking. So I'm sure we will be asked to expand upon that activity during the Q&A portion of the call. But the takeaway, I would hope, is a vibrant piece of the market that did not take a pause during the slow and more volatile summer months. 
So with that, I'm going to turn it over to Andrew Mathias, who I think is going to give you a little more insight into some of this activity as well as the structured finance activities for the quarter.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Our big announcement this quarter were the sales of our key position at 885 Third Avenue and our new student housing development at 33 Beekman. 885 brings to a close the last of the 2007, 2008 fee positions we purchased.Our returns in this
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Our big announcement this quarter were the sales of our key position at 885 Third Avenue and our new student housing development at 33 Beekman. 885 brings to a close the last of the 2007, 2008 fee positions we purchased.
Our returns in this program were extraordinary, taking highly secure senior positions and assets, applying appropriate fixed-rate long-term leverage and letting the positions appreciate. 885 will generate an IRR in excess of 10%, combined with over 17% IRR into Harold, and 15.5% IRR on the 292 Madison. Extraordinary returns for our shareholders on AAA risk type positions.
Don't think this business line is discontinued, as we continue to actively look for additional opportunities to compliment 635 Madison Avenue and 562 Fifth Avenue in our current key portfolio.
At 33 Beekman, on Tuesday our team joined Pace University's senior management team to cut the ribbon on what we believe to be the tallest student housing projects in the country, at 382 feet. I'm very proud of our construction team for delivering this ground-up project on time and on-budget, successfully navigating the many complexities of the site. Base is thrilled and Wednesday we announced a contract to sell the assets to a foreign buyer at a very compelling cap rate of 3.9%. 
In addition to an extraordinary return on our investment, with a projected property level IRR in excess of 40%, we expect to receive promote on a deal in excess of $10 million when it closes early next year.
Needless to say, we're hard at work identifying new sites to continue this business line as well where we've had extraordinary profits in our student housing division. We expect more news on the sales front in the fourth quarter as we continue to take advantage of great market conditions in Manhattan.
On DPE, debt & preferred equity, net originations slow down a bit this quarter as several repayments we anticipated rolled in over the course of the quarter. That said, we have a very fulsome pipeline for  fourth quarter. And debt market dislocation, which shook things up a bit in August, is giving us an extraordinary opportunity to maintain or in some cases, even increase, retained yields on positions in that pipeline. So we'd expect to close the year on target and with extraordinary profitability and high relative returns.
With that, I'd like to turn it over to Matt.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. Our third quarter results showcase the strong performance from both our real estate, and debt and preferred equity portfolios, as well as the successful execution of our disseminated real estate disposition and reinvestment strategy.Taki
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. Our third quarter results showcase the strong performance from both our real estate, and debt and preferred equity portfolios, as well as the successful execution of our disseminated real estate disposition and reinvestment strategy.
Taking into consideration these results and looking ahead to the fourth quarter after just increasing guidance back in July, we're again increasing our NAREIT defined FFO guidance range to $6.34 to $6.37 per share, putting us on track for almost 9% FFO growth year-over-year. 
Looking through the third quarter results, in the real estate portfolio, the effect of the acquisition of 11 Madison on August 18 and 110 Greene Street at the end of July contributed to an increase in several line items on the income statement as well as cash NOI, partially offset by the sale of an 80% interest in 131, 137 Spring Street on August 4.
Excluding the effects of those transactions, our property operating results continued to see the benefit of increasing portfolio occupancy in Manhattan, which now stands at over 97% on a leased basis in the same-store portfolio and mark-to-market in excess of our expectations, coupled with the continued containment of operating expenses. 
Historically, operating expenses are much higher in the third quarter than they are in the second, and that is what we saw, again, this year with a much more modest increase than expected. All these factors have contributed to same-store NOI growth of 4.6% through the first 9 months and put us on a past to end the year well ahead our goal of  3.6%.
The debt and preferred equity portfolio, the balance decreased to $1.5 million as we received repayments totaling $262 million during the quarter, which was consistent with our expectations. As Andrew outlined we have a significant pipeline of originations for the fourth quarter and yields that exceed the 8.5%, we expected to achieve in 2015. This pipeline of activity, which is weighted towards back half of the quarter, will bring our portfolio balance to between $1.7 billion and $1.8 billion by the end of the year with the overall portfolio yields remaining north of 10%.
In other income, the FFO from our real estate, and debt and preferred equity portfolios was complemented by a $5 million reduction in the prior year tax obligation of our taxable REIT subsidiary. This benefit comes as a result of an enormous amount of analysis by our tax professionals to review the cost sharing structure between our TRS and our operating partnership, including new reimbursement of corporate overhead by the TRS.
As you all know, we are very focused on creating efficiencies through tax structuring and strategy and everything we do. So kudos to our Tax Director, Michael Barber, for his efforts in this regard.
Also included in other income during the quarter was the recognition of lease termination payments totaling about $4 million. As we have said in the past, we don't view lease termination income as nonrecurring, which historically we've recognized some level of lease termination income virtually every quarter. This is simply the accelerated recognition of lease income that we otherwise would have received over time. 
On the expense side, given all of our investment activity during the quarter highlighted by the acquisitions of 11 Madison and 110 Greene. We recognized a significant amount of transaction costs somewhat more than we anticipated. As always, we are conservative in our view of transaction costs given that we are so active. And that conservatism remains as we head into the fourth quarter with a full pipeline of activity ahead.
All things considered, we are very pleased to be raising guidance for the second consecutive quarter. I think we are set up very nicely ahead into 2016. We're excited for the quarters ahead, and we look forward to unveiling our 2016 earnings guidance in early December.
In that regard before I turn it back to Marc, I want to remind everyone that our 18th Annual Investor Conference is being held on December 7 in New York City. It is hard to believe that we're holding this now for 18 years. It's a full day event, chock-full of information and may be a bit of entertainment. Invitations will be going out in the next couple of weeks. But if you like more information in the meantime, please email us. The email addresses in our press release, but it's slg2015@slgreen.com. 
With that, back to Marc.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Matt. And we're going to open it up for Q&A. I just do want to echo Matt's sentiments that we certainly hope everyone listening in will be able to make it to the shareholder event in December, and that's where we're going to really get in
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Matt. And we're going to open it up for Q&A. I just do want to echo Matt's sentiments that we certainly hope everyone listening in will be able to make it to the shareholder event in December, and that's where we're going to really get into not so much a review of the past, but really a look forward to 2016. Because we are extremely excited as we are sitting here now about the development opportunities, embedded growth within the portfolios and the -- all the other things that we have lined up and we're going to be ready to talk you about in 2016. So I look forward to seeing you in December.
And with that, we'll open it up to Q&A.

componenttext: Yes, go ahead.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the structured finance book? In particular, it sounds like you're actually pretty bullish about potential originations here stemming from some of the turmoils in fixed income markets. But I'm curious how you think about whe
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the structured finance book? In particular, it sounds like you're actually pretty bullish about potential originations here stemming from some of the turmoils in fixed income markets. But I'm curious how you think about whether what's going on in the fixed income market has been a bit of a canary in the coal mine. And perhaps, should you use as an opportunity to let some of the portfolio roll off and do you risk that part of the business alone, how do you balance those 2 views?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's more of an opportunity to get better risk-adjusted returns, which means either charging more for capital at a similar position in the capital structure, or taking the opportunity to move more senior in the capital structure and charge fo
componenttext: Yes, I think it's more of an opportunity to get better risk-adjusted returns, which means either charging more for capital at a similar position in the capital structure, or taking the opportunity to move more senior in the capital structure and charge for the same as we are previously getting for [indiscernible]. There was quite a bit of dislocation in the CMBS market in August. And every time there's that kind of dislocation, we find extraordinary opportunity sort of shaking out. We have capital structures that are short proceeds because people get carved back in the CMBS market. So I think it's less, we view it in as less time to pause and more time to take advantage, but make sure that we're increasing our risk-adjusted returns at sort of whatever portion of the capital structure we're lending at.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm going to let Nic Yulico ask our second question.
componenttext: Okay. I'm going to let Nic Yulico ask our second question.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you tell us a little bit more about New York City. Where you think the overall market is right now for rent growth? I mean, there is sort of debate about whether it's 5%, whether it's lower than that, whether it's 10% for the best buildings.
componenttext: I was hoping you tell us a little bit more about New York City. Where you think the overall market is right now for rent growth? I mean, there is sort of debate about whether it's 5%, whether it's lower than that, whether it's 10% for the best buildings. Maybe you can just talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the market for rent growth? And how it's trending this year? And how you think it might move into next year for the overall market?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well you can slice and dice it in 20 different ways deciding on the quality of the building, the submarket, the base versus the power, the various sizes of tenant requirements and the profile of the requirement itself. I would say, generally speaking, and
componenttext: Well you can slice and dice it in 20 different ways deciding on the quality of the building, the submarket, the base versus the power, the various sizes of tenant requirements and the profile of the requirement itself. I would say, generally speaking, and let's sort of focus on Midtown because Midtown has been extremely active this year. The rent growth this year has been strong across the board. We haven't really seen any let up in demand on whether it's the bottom or the top or on the more price-sensitive versus the high price point product. I would say that overall Midtown has got more opportunity for rent growth than the Midtown South, at least in the near-term because there's more inventory available. And the demand is going to follow where the supply is. And there's a lot of -- we've seen velocity in deals in the pipeline for Midtown right now. So to put a number on it, between now and 12 months from now, I'd be very surprised if we didn't see at least 7% to 8% of rent growth.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Manny Korchman of Citi.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. Two questions. one for me, Marc, in your opening comments, you talked about a pipeline of accretive and then you called them opportunistic opportunities. And I'm just wondering if you can share or maybe perhaps Andrew can share sort of what doe
componenttext: All right. Two questions. one for me, Marc, in your opening comments, you talked about a pipeline of accretive and then you called them opportunistic opportunities. And I'm just wondering if you can share or maybe perhaps Andrew can share sort of what does that encompass, in terms of sizing, but also the types of deals that we should be expecting from this pipeline?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that -- I mean, I don't think we want to completely give it away. So we generically describe it as this kind of stuff we didn't buy to some extent. So it's a mixture of high-quality office and more opportunistic, mixed-use, meaning they're r
componenttext: Well, I think that -- I mean, I don't think we want to completely give it away. So we generically describe it as this kind of stuff we didn't buy to some extent. So it's a mixture of high-quality office and more opportunistic, mixed-use, meaning they're resi retail or office retail products in some of the -- in the Midtown South market. So I think it's a combination of those 2 types of profiles. That's just on the equity portion, not speaking to the structured finance pipeline, which Andrew spoke to separately or can add more commentary to separate branches talking about fee opportunities that we are working on currently that if thinks set up with the right process and right pricing could result in some additional acquisitions over the next 3 or 5 months.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just add, Michael. I mean if you look at 110 Greene and 187 Broadway, the 2 transactions we announced in the quarter, those are completely off market. Never marketed one-on-one negotiations and structured deals where we were able to deliver the se
componenttext: I would just add, Michael. I mean if you look at 110 Greene and 187 Broadway, the 2 transactions we announced in the quarter, those are completely off market. Never marketed one-on-one negotiations and structured deals where we were able to deliver the seller equivalent or more net proceeds without them going and taking a full cash price from the market. We're still seeing those types of opportunities as sort of we always have. They're just -- they're longer lead time and they mature as they're ready without the pressure of a marketed process. So we still do have a lot of those types of deals in the pipeline.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Manny here with Michael. If we look at the 885 third deal. Can you just close in and say how that was structured and why there was such a big preferred equity component? And on the preferred, if you could just give us the term and the rate?
componenttext: It's Manny here with Michael. If we look at the 885 third deal. Can you just close in and say how that was structured and why there was such a big preferred equity component? And on the preferred, if you could just give us the term and the rate?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, I think -- the preferred equity term is 5 years. The rate will wind up being in the high 5% range. And I think -- our thinking there was the structure contains a lot of variability in 2020. And part of the motivation for selling the asset no
componenttext: Sure. I mean, I think -- the preferred equity term is 5 years. The rate will wind up being in the high 5% range. And I think -- our thinking there was the structure contains a lot of variability in 2020. And part of the motivation for selling the asset now was to have certainty as opposed to that variability of outcome in 2020. So us providing the preferred would have allowed us to get a good cash return in the interim and not be sort of first in line depending on what happens with the asset in 2020.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tony Paolone of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tony Paolone of JPMorgan.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This week, there's some concerns that have emerged around tax tenancy out on the West Coast. And with TAMI having driven a lot of the growth in New York. Can you give us some views on how you see that space, particularly, as it relates to tenant credit an
componenttext: This week, there's some concerns that have emerged around tax tenancy out on the West Coast. And with TAMI having driven a lot of the growth in New York. Can you give us some views on how you see that space, particularly, as it relates to tenant credit and venture funding and how you guys think about that right now?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you got to remember, Tony, we -- I don't have the number in front of me. I'm going to guess we have 5% or less exposure to pure tech tenant. And certainly, the type of TAMI tenant that you're talking about, with the credit concern tenets, I think it
componenttext: Well, you got to remember, Tony, we -- I don't have the number in front of me. I'm going to guess we have 5% or less exposure to pure tech tenant. And certainly, the type of TAMI tenant that you're talking about, with the credit concern tenets, I think it's a very small portion of the portfolio. And traditionally, we've had very little loss in that segment, even when there were time to distress back in 2000, 2001, et cetera. So I think that the way we think of that is, it's kind of the way we run the business, which is oriented towards companies that are largely investment-grade established bigger companies. We have made some investments in the Midtown South area, like 635, 646. But even in that building, which has a fair amount of tech tenants, they're all very high-quality, like Infor, Microsoft, and who else do we have there? And Yelp so, I don't know that, that doesn't raise any red flags for us on the credit side of things. I think we've sold properties in the past where we felt there were some credit exposures to try and head off what may be coming down the pipe. But I would simply say that just look at the supplemental with the disclosure of our tenant profile and you'll see that regardless of how that market developed over time and there's always going to be ups and downs and what's essentially a cyclical and emerging kind of industry. I don't see that having any impact, any material impact, on the portfolio as it has in years past.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a very small fraction of the 5% tech Marc referred to is that are all reliant on venture funding, which I think is 81% -- almost, I mean, 1% of the 5% may be. Not 20% of the 5%. I don't think venture funding is at all relevant to our tenancy, what
componenttext: I think a very small fraction of the 5% tech Marc referred to is that are all reliant on venture funding, which I think is 81% -- almost, I mean, 1% of the 5% may be. Not 20% of the 5%. I don't think venture funding is at all relevant to our tenancy, whatsoever. I mean, the tech tenants we have are large public tenants. And we took a measure this quarter to sell the 36th Street asset, which had an exposure to venture funded type tenant.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. My second question on One Vanderbilt. Can you give us a sense as to how you think about depth of market for tenants at that price point? I think there is some other product going up at a fairly similarly high price point. And then you have sort o
componenttext: Got you. My second question on One Vanderbilt. Can you give us a sense as to how you think about depth of market for tenants at that price point? I think there is some other product going up at a fairly similarly high price point. And then you have sort of the alternative of the West side or downtown at a much lower new construction price point. So as you guys move forward that project, how do you think about just the pot out there that you can go and get at that price point?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tony. I think we're going to go through that in an extensive amount of detail in December. And I would sort of urge you that wait till then to hear from Steve and some of the brokers we are working on the deal. We'll take you through the building, th
componenttext: Yes, Tony. I think we're going to go through that in an extensive amount of detail in December. And I would sort of urge you that wait till then to hear from Steve and some of the brokers we are working on the deal. We'll take you through the building, the special aspects of the way it's designed, the way it's amenitized, the kind of tenants it will appeal to, the way in which we are marketing, we'll begin marketing that building. It really, I think, when you say there's other buildings going up of a similar is really almost none. So I don't -- this maybe 425 Park, although, that already -- the majority of that is anchored and what's left is very small [indiscernible]. So I actually don't know anything that is going up that we'll be delivering in 2020 that I would call competitive product in a AAA location. And the tenants that we'll be looking for large blocks of uses between 500,000 and 1 million square feet and over on the West side really don't even enter or target market for the most part, because we see this building likely being tenanted by tenants ranging anywhere from 50,000 feet to 250,000 feet, looking for very high end, very highly amenitized, very high designed, very well located, brand-new office space, at -- with views that are sort of unparalleled in Midtown because of the height of the building. So I don't think there's a lot of competition. That doesn't mean we don't have to think long and hard about who is that tenant base and how we're going to attack them. And that will go into in great detail in December. But suffice it to say, the reception to the building from the tenant community so far has been excellent. And if anything, given that it's only 2015, and we're talking about occupancy in 2021, 2020 possession dates for occupancy in end of 2020, 2021. For tenants in that 50,000 to 250,000 square foot range, it's a little early, which I think is obvious, but I just wanted to state that. But the reception, generally, has been excellent. And I don't think the price points we have established for the building are going to be a resistance level for these types of tenants.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to guidance for a second here. Understanding that the second quarter in a row of raise here. But given the magnitude of each year in a quarter and some of the drivers there, I guess I would have thought it would involve in bigger
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to guidance for a second here. Understanding that the second quarter in a row of raise here. But given the magnitude of each year in a quarter and some of the drivers there, I guess I would have thought it would involve in bigger raise. So I was just wondering if you could provide some color on sort of what the key drivers of the upside here are, does seem like you are tracking well ahead on the same-store front and leasing of velocity sounds very strong as well relative to your expectations.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- with only 2 months left to go, I feel like our visibility to the end of the year is pretty solid at this point. A lot of what we reported in the third quarter was expected ups, downs and otherwise slightly ahead on a handful of things that put
componenttext: Yes, the -- with only 2 months left to go, I feel like our visibility to the end of the year is pretty solid at this point. A lot of what we reported in the third quarter was expected ups, downs and otherwise slightly ahead on a handful of things that put us in a position of generally increased sequentially 2 quarters, unless that's really outperformance and there has been. But by and large, this stuff as we saw in the third quarter with a lot of expectations, a lot of the leasing momentum that we have when I say, we're excited about 2016, now that's really going to have an impact in '16 and beyond, not for the last 2 months, 3 months of the year.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the real estate tax was contemplated, I guess. Okay. I guess just another question, in terms of the total overall demand that you're seeing, and here we talked about sort of the different component of it. I'm just curious if there's any shifts or
componenttext: Okay. So the real estate tax was contemplated, I guess. Okay. I guess just another question, in terms of the total overall demand that you're seeing, and here we talked about sort of the different component of it. I'm just curious if there's any shifts or changes that you've seen in sort where the demand is coming from in New York?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Financial services, what was missed in the last conversation was, it's not so much about where TAMI is as you know that was the big story for the last year. The difference this year is that financial services has been the driver of leasing activity across
componenttext: Financial services, what was missed in the last conversation was, it's not so much about where TAMI is as you know that was the big story for the last year. The difference this year is that financial services has been the driver of leasing activity across the Manhattan market. Certainly within our pipeline, we've got leases out 100,000 square feet of that is financial services related. And in the term sheet stage, we've got almost 300,000 square feet of the deals stemming with financial service type tenants. So strong demand there. The other driver, healthcare continues to be a big push in Manhattan. So does education, the administrative side of education. We're seeing some large leases come into the pipeline off that as well.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Had a couple of questions on retail. This period you signed a high rent deal at 125 Park Avenue. Can you provide some color on the type of tenant you signed there, whether or not this was a conversion space? And if it was conversion space, how many other
componenttext: Had a couple of questions on retail. This period you signed a high rent deal at 125 Park Avenue. Can you provide some color on the type of tenant you signed there, whether or not this was a conversion space? And if it was conversion space, how many other opportunities do you have to convert office or lobby into retail?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess at 125 Park I think we signed 2 deals this quarter. Haworth, which is the showroom tenant on that ground in second floor. And then we did convert a bunch of basement and storage space into retail, combined it with a unit on the first floor and sig
componenttext:
I guess at 125 Park I think we signed 2 deals this quarter. Haworth, which is the showroom tenant on that ground in second floor. And then we did convert a bunch of basement and storage space into retail, combined it with a unit on the first floor and signed a major fitness operator into the space open gym.
So I think that is very indicative of the work day and there a retail group is doing, diligence and the assets we own and in addition to the assets we're purchasing to try to find areas where we can expand the retail footprint and convert lower revenue generating space into higher revenue generating space. So there is a lot more of that opportunity in the portfolio.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have an estimate as to how much that may be?
componenttext: Do you have an estimate as to how much that may be?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have put up a slide in December. But that will have to be modified because some of the leasing has taken place this year. But the slide in December that I recall was something like $160 million of incremental NOI over the next 5 years, our share, that
componenttext: We have put up a slide in December. But that will have to be modified because some of the leasing has taken place this year. But the slide in December that I recall was something like $160 million of incremental NOI over the next 5 years, our share, that never represents our share, coming strictly from retail assets. Now in that regard, there's been some retail leasing but we've added retail assets. So we'll have to do that reconciliation for you in December. But suffice is to say, it's enormous. I look at that number as coming from the retail, which is not a segment of business we have a lot of capital devoted to like we do on the office sector, much more capital devoted there. So pound for pound, that kind of NOI lift over the next 5 years, coming from that segment, is enormous. But like I said, we don't -- I can't tell you at the moment the exact and kind of NOI expectation we have from retail over the next 5 years. We will have that for you in December.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question on retail is the potential re-leasing spreads going forward. Looking at Slide 50 in your -- you're asking rent estimates. It looks like it actually went down for 3 of the 4 weeks of buckets you have compared to the second
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question on retail is the potential re-leasing spreads going forward. Looking at Slide 50 in your -- you're asking rent estimates. It looks like it actually went down for 3 of the 4 weeks of buckets you have compared to the second quarter. And I was wondering how much of this was due to the mix that have changed compared to may be more conservative views on retail. I mean, there's some softness on the retail market.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, it's Matt. Yes that's -- it's more of a mix -- that portfolio sold from stock-based -- based on occupied space or depending on when space rolls in, rolls out, that could change. But certainly, our view of retail has not changed.
componenttext: John, it's Matt. Yes that's -- it's more of a mix -- that portfolio sold from stock-based -- based on occupied space or depending on when space rolls in, rolls out, that could change. But certainly, our view of retail has not changed.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing rental declines in any of our retail assets.
componenttext: We're not seeing rental declines in any of our retail assets.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The mark-to-market that was associated with the presentation I was referring to just earlier generated $160 million-ish of incremental NOI had a mark-to-market, as I recall, of about 100%. So I don't know where -- how that compares to the supplemental, we
componenttext: The mark-to-market that was associated with the presentation I was referring to just earlier generated $160 million-ish of incremental NOI had a mark-to-market, as I recall, of about 100%. So I don't know where -- how that compares to the supplemental, we've not experienced so far.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's all the same.
componenttext: It's all the same.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: About 100%. So I think its fair to say on average, there are some properties we have in local prime, prime retail segment, where rents may be marking 200%, 300%, 400% literally to market. And then there's other aspects, which are 20%, 30%, 40%. But on ave
componenttext: About 100%. So I think its fair to say on average, there are some properties we have in local prime, prime retail segment, where rents may be marking 200%, 300%, 400% literally to market. And then there's other aspects, which are 20%, 30%, 40%. But on average, at least as of last December, it was about 100%. And as Andrew said, we're not -- we have not reduced retail rents, I don't think anywhere in the portfolio. Do you see it anywhere? So it has to be solely mixed or the occupancy that is coming up in any given year, some has higher mark-to-market, some slower. But again, I would look at it more on a portfolio basis as opposed to any individual quarter or year. And on that basis, about 100% embedded growth.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Matt, just a quick one for you. And whether you expect all that to come from the debt refinancing that you're talking about? or the -- and if that is -- indeed is the case, if we do end up with excess proceeds is the idea to continue to delever going forward?

componenttext: So Marc talked about incremental assets there over and above 1745 as being sources of capital for other accretive opportunities just speaking to what we like to call the 11 Madison rubric, the totality of the acquisition and the sales and refinancing that fed into it.  But for 1745, the sales have all been completed consistent with our plan. So with that leaves us with financings and refinancings that are in process that generate incremental capital to the program.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And just to expand on that. In June, we put up a presentation, which showed a funding plan for 11 Madison, but also for $400 million of additional acquisitions. We are about $200 million of equity through that $400 million. So that we will sell mor
componenttext: Right. And just to expand on that. In June, we put up a presentation, which showed a funding plan for 11 Madison, but also for $400 million of additional acquisitions. We are about $200 million of equity through that $400 million. So that we will sell more assets likely beyond 1745 Broadway as I've mentioned earlier. And those will go to fund those incremental acquisitions to fill out $200 million and then possibly beyond that, as well, because we'll go beyond. But if the question is just to close out the 11 Madison, I think what I said earlier was 1745 plus the refinancings closes out 11.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as the delivering, Tayo, obviously, we closed 11 Madison using our corporate liquidity and corporate facilities. So now with every sale that we consummate, that will go down to as part of the [indiscernible] go back to pay, repay those facilities taki
componenttext: And as the delivering, Tayo, obviously, we closed 11 Madison using our corporate liquidity and corporate facilities. So now with every sale that we consummate, that will go down to as part of the [indiscernible] go back to pay, repay those facilities taking a leverage back down.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: But if you look at where we started the year and where we finished at the end of consummating all these transactions, all of our leverage ratios, based on 2015 EBITDA is, right back in line. And then in '16 it improves as we expect 2016 EBITDA to exceed 2
componenttext: But if you look at where we started the year and where we finished at the end of consummating all these transactions, all of our leverage ratios, based on 2015 EBITDA is, right back in line. And then in '16 it improves as we expect 2016 EBITDA to exceed 2015 EBITDA, so we should have improvement in all those ratios, notwithstanding the enormous activity, the enormous acquisition that we were able to achieve by ourselves with our partner, without issuing any common equity. And obviously, as markets improve, the ATM becomes an option down the road, but clearly, at the levels we've experienced, we've been relying solely on the asset sales and that's proven to be an excellent strategy, we think.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Feldman of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just focusing on the leasing pipeline. Can you talk about how much of that pipeline is new versus renewal? And then also maybe break it out into the different sizes you're seeing? I know you mentioned there's a couple of 100,000 square foot potential fina
componenttext: Just focusing on the leasing pipeline. Can you talk about how much of that pipeline is new versus renewal? And then also maybe break it out into the different sizes you're seeing? I know you mentioned there's a couple of 100,000 square foot potential financial service users. And then just thinking about the different corridors, are you seeing more demand for PI and Park Avenue, 6th Avenue, Midtown South?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This -- we got -- of the leases that are out, the majority of it is new deals. In the pipeline of deals that are being negotiated, it's probably, it's sort of 50-50. As far as locations, the majority of deals that we're working are all Midtown, I mean, it
componenttext: This -- we got -- of the leases that are out, the majority of it is new deals. In the pipeline of deals that are being negotiated, it's probably, it's sort of 50-50. As far as locations, the majority of deals that we're working are all Midtown, I mean, it's not ourselves spread downtown but -- or Midtown South, but the majority of it is Midtown. And what's interesting is that a good chunk of, I would say, a very large percentage of the deals that we are working on, both in pipeline and/or leases that are out, are for spaces that are becoming available for 2017, whether those are early renewals or whether they're forward commitments for space that were space that we know we're getting back in 2017. So that's where a lot of our attention is right now. We have very good visibility, obviously, through the end of this year and for most of 2016. But we've got a good deal of roll in '17. And the good news on that is we've got some very large deals in the pipeline that are going to not [indiscernible] that off the board.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you seeing any shifts in terms of the different avenues or parts in Midtown in terms of where people want to be, or what they're willing to pay. I know you've signed a Bloomberg deal earlier this year on Third Avenue?
componenttext: Okay. And are you seeing any shifts in terms of the different avenues or parts in Midtown in terms of where people want to be, or what they're willing to pay. I know you've signed a Bloomberg deal earlier this year on Third Avenue?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's Park Avenue, the rents are up but the supplies are way down. Park Avenue has got one of the lowest availability rates right now in town. Right around Grand Central compared to a year ago. There's been a lot of leasing velocity in the Grand Cent
componenttext: Well, it's Park Avenue, the rents are up but the supplies are way down. Park Avenue has got one of the lowest availability rates right now in town. Right around Grand Central compared to a year ago. There's been a lot of leasing velocity in the Grand Central submarket. But I really can't point you to say that the demand is focused on one avenue, one submarket or one size or type of tenant. Interesting to note that 2 years ago, we would have been talking about how Third Avenue had a low supply. Now all of a sudden, Third Avenue returned to its historical norm as far as availability. And if you take our building on 711 Third Avenue where we have number of deals that we're negotiating, the rents there, which is probably our most commodity-like building where you would think would be the sort of weakest part as part of, suppose, rent growth. We're seeing a good $10 increase on rents on a number of the deals that we're negotiating today versus where we would have been a year ago.

componenttext: Alex, Alex, it's a fee position. It's not -- you've only got like half the equation. There's a leasehold behind the fee. We own the fee. We traded the fee. The fee is a partial interest of the overall value of the property. There's a leaseholder out there that would like to think they have sizable, sizable equity value behind the fee position. It's actually over $100 million of institutional debt and then there's over $100 million of invested equity and whatever it's worth, it's worth. But no -- this is no 90% of value. This is like -- I would equate it almost to a AAA bond. That makes sense out.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It makes sense.
componenttext: It makes sense.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: That's why I wanted -- sort of just close your's there. I don't want those 90% number floating around, this is a very secure fee asset with a lot of subordinate equity below it in the form of a long-term operating leasehold division owned by a -- foreign, foreign entities and that are institutional in nature. And I think they have a lot of ton of equity value in that deal.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: I guess the reason the fee position is traded for the price it's traded is to -- it has limited upside because there is a fixed price we purchase of it.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would look at it -- this more as a low leverage mortgage bond that we traded. I mean, let's have a deal, this was a testament to entry. He structured 3 of these deals back in 2000, I think, it was '05, '06, '07. 292 Madison, 2 Harold 885 where we too
componenttext: So I would look at it -- this more as a low leverage mortgage bond that we traded. I mean, let's have a deal, this was a testament to entry. He structured 3 of these deals back in 2000, I think, it was '05, '06, '07. 292 Madison, 2 Harold 885 where we took kind of low LTV fee positions and gave out of the money purchase options that I think were generally 10 or 15 years forward. So 2 of those deals we fully resolved. We made -- I think a very significant returns on 2 Harold and 292. Now this deal upon closing fully resolved, we will have achieved essentially a 10% to 10.5% IRR on what I look at essentially as a AAA bond position.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful and that explains, I appreciate that. The second question is, on the originations in the quarter, the 7.2%. Is that just a reflection that of going after some senior mortgages and therefore we should expect more than 10% going forward
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful and that explains, I appreciate that. The second question is, on the originations in the quarter, the 7.2%. Is that just a reflection that of going after some senior mortgages and therefore we should expect more than 10% going forward? Or do you think that because you guys maybe going more senior, that the 10% may come down more towards 9%?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would expect our hold positions to be more in the overall average of our book in the 9% to 10% range. They just -- it's reflective of the fact that we have put a mortgage on the books and haven't syndicated the senior portion arrears.
componenttext: I would expect our hold positions to be more in the overall average of our book in the 9% to 10% range. They just -- it's reflective of the fact that we have put a mortgage on the books and haven't syndicated the senior portion arrears.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would -- there again, I would just like to raise the point because you talked about that 10%. For earnings purposes, we modeled 8.5%, not 10%. But yes, in the world of that big difference. So we have been achieving 10% because we've been outperforming o
componenttext: I would -- there again, I would just like to raise the point because you talked about that 10%. For earnings purposes, we modeled 8.5%, not 10%. But yes, in the world of that big difference. So we have been achieving 10% because we've been outperforming our projections. Our target just over on the same page is not 10%. Our, let's say, guidance in any case is 8.5%, on a blended basis between whatever the profile book of mortgage that's supporting the debt has been -- Andrew is saying that's likely to continue. And if it does, then we should meet or exceed 8.5%, hopefully 10%. But I just wouldn't -- I would caution you on using that as sort of your target.

componenttext: We had an internal list, I would say, that was all the assets we were selling and then some because we were kind of triangulating the market, if you will, to try and figure out of a universe of assets, which is larger than what we sold. Where can we get the best executions and, we think, we hopefully achieved that. So the answer is no list, all the assets we sold were within the universe of what we intend to sell and we say, we sold the ones that we could get the best execution on relative to our internal assessment value. That's one. Two, lender on $1.4 billion.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we've been running a captive insurance for over a decade now. And as part of that we have access to the Federal Home Loan Bank, which provides us a very efficient capital to finance some of our structure positions list. So we are going to ta
componenttext: Look, I think we've been running a captive insurance for over a decade now. And as part of that we have access to the Federal Home Loan Bank, which provides us a very efficient capital to finance some of our structure positions list. So we are going to take advantage of it and it allows us to instead of selling A notes originate more senior positions and finance them and have higher retained yields. So we may do more of it later. But it's a big advantage to us kind of on a go-forward basis.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: First of all, just to go back on 885, and I know it's very complicated structure that was put in place there. But Andrew I think when you described the pricing on the transaction, you talked about achieving a 10% IRR on the investment. As I recall, the -- at the 2020 reset on the lease, there's an option that I think you referred to earlier. And I thought that option was priced to deliver an unlevered IRR of about 7.5%. Is that -- do I have that right?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's 7% unlevered but it levers up to 10%. Yes, so it is -- its north of 10% and a levered IRR.
componenttext: It's 7% unlevered but it levers up to 10%. Yes, so it is -- its north of 10% and a levered IRR.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We always on rightful equity type deals, we always pinpoint unlevered returns. This type of investment where we don't have the operating position. And it has a stated yield and a take out in 2020, we look at strictly as a structured investment akin to som
componenttext: We always on rightful equity type deals, we always pinpoint unlevered returns. This type of investment where we don't have the operating position. And it has a stated yield and a take out in 2020, we look at strictly as a structured investment akin to something that would be almost in the BPE portfolio, and we're looking at IRR's on cash out the door. So the 10.5% I think IRR is equivalent to essentially like a 10.5% we had achieved on an investment BPE. It just happens to be not BPE, it happens to be a structure piece of it. And levered by a kind of a low rate, a low advanced rate, first mortgage.

componenttext: Well the run rate yield will be consistent with what we've shown on average over the last several quarters. The income stream will be affected by the lower balance that we're leading off the fourth quarter with that trends upward as we originate more deals towards the middle to back half of the quarter. But the portfolio yield remains fairly consistent. As I said, will end the year just north of 10%.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's mostly a function of us not controlling the timing of repayments, right? So it's -- we can anticipate them and try to model them coming in, but you don't know when exactly they're going to come in. And some of the exit fees are variable in am
componenttext: I think it's mostly a function of us not controlling the timing of repayments, right? So it's -- we can anticipate them and try to model them coming in, but you don't know when exactly they're going to come in. And some of the exit fees are variable in amount depending on timing of repayment.

componenttextpreview: Sure. And then just second question, occupancy level  97%, I think it's kind of an all-time-high. Your portfolio quality is higher than it's ever been as well. But is 97% occupancy sustainable? Or is that -- should we expect that to migrate down a little
componenttext: Sure. And then just second question, occupancy level  97%, I think it's kind of an all-time-high. Your portfolio quality is higher than it's ever been as well. But is 97% occupancy sustainable? Or is that -- should we expect that to migrate down a little bit over the next couple of quarters?

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're telling our guys it's not nearly enough. So I don't know. There's a lot of square footage between 97% and 100%. And thanks for asking -- so yes, the answer is no, there is, well, pockets of vacancy we're not happy it exists. We're attacking those, a
componenttext: We're telling our guys it's not nearly enough. So I don't know. There's a lot of square footage between 97% and 100%. And thanks for asking -- so yes, the answer is no, there is, well, pockets of vacancy we're not happy it exists. We're attacking those, albeit, diminishing. And we've acquired new vacancies that's not in that same-store portfolio like Tower 46. And like -- let's hear it for the first three transactions. I mean that's -- things have got a little lost today, but that was a great inaugural deal that's Tower 46 building, good tenant, good terms, we're happy to tick that building off successfully with that rent. And we've got a lots of really good looking pre-builds that basically are done 3 weeks -- 2 weeks away from done. And we hope and expect when those pre-builds are done, that they will be hot commodities in a very good building. So I think there's still upside within that portfolio. But the upside really isn't just leasing up a vacant space. I mean, we've got a lot of development pipeline. We've got vacant space pipeline in the growth portfolio that's not in the same-store. And we've got big, big mark-to-market in the office portfolio and then massively more so in the retail portfolio. So I don't think we're suffering from a lack of areas to identify for where their growth is coming from, which is why I think we're very, very optimistic about where we're headed for 2016.

componenttext: I think it was more -- we usually make the money on the lease, but if you can make the money we were going to make on the lease without building and doing the lease, then it seemed like a good opportunity to take money off the table and get -- take advantage of an extraordinary buy, which Brett and the retail team made and not at the build.

componenttext: Yes, 180 Maiden Lane is a good example of that same strategy, I mean most of what we buy we execute. As in the case with 180. And these properties on Fifth. Sometimes we get an offer that's so compelling, it's onto the next. There's a lot of property out there to reposition.

headline: SL Green Realty Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're -- I think we're covered in December. Right now, the focus for us for the past 4 or 5 months has been on executing a very deliberate plan that we put forth in June. We're at the tail end of that. We are now putting in place our new plan, if you
componenttext: Yes, we're -- I think we're covered in December. Right now, the focus for us for the past 4 or 5 months has been on executing a very deliberate plan that we put forth in June. We're at the tail end of that. We are now putting in place our new plan, if you will, for the next batch of investments that we've been mining and we think are coming to fruition. And how best we're going to fund those, and from which assess we're going to be selling or capital we're going to be raising in the form of JV equity, that's the capital raised in today's environment that we look at as an alternative to selling existing assets as JV-ing of new assets. We've -- we liked very much what we bought this year, so we didn't JV, I don't think any of that product, right? I mean SoHo has came as JV but we didn't take any partners there or 11 Madison or on 187 or the Eastside portfolio, right? So we can always use that, the ability to access private equity, the partnership as a means of moderating what we sell or don't sell from those kind of deals. So that hasn't been decided nor does it need to be at this point. But we'll be over the next 3 to 5 months as we execute on those opportunities.
